chunks.original_latin: ADVERSUS JOANNIS SCOTI ERIGENAE ERRONEAS DEFINITIONES LIBER

chunks.cleaned_english_translation: From the "Great Library of the Fathers." In the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, we begin the little book by Flori, which addresses the misconceptions and mistakes of a very vain man named John, focusing on predestination, divine foreknowledge, and the true freedom of human will.
chunks.original_latin:
(Ex Bibliotheca Patrum maxima.) In nomine Domini nostri Jesu Christi incipit libellus FLORI adversus cujusdam vanissimi
hominis, qui cognominatur Joannes, ineptias et errores de praedestinatione et praescientia
divina et de vera humani arbitrii libertate.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Preface. Some writings have reached us—that is, the Church of Lyon—from a certain boastful and talkative man. While he discusses topics like divine foreknowledge and predestination with what he claims are human and philosophical arguments, he fails to provide logical reasoning or cite the authority of the Scriptures or the holy Fathers. He boldly declares these ideas as truths to be held and followed based solely on his own presumption.

These writings, which are vain and full of lies and errors against the faith and truth of God, are easily judged and rejected by faithful readers trained in sacred doctrine, with God's help; indeed, they are even held in contempt and ridicule. However, because many, as we have heard, regard this man as scholarly and learned, and because his ramblings and writings cause some to hesitate and others to follow his errors, thinking he is saying something significant, he occupies all his listeners and admirers with pointless verbosity and windy talk in a most harmful way. This prevents them from humbly submitting to divine Scriptures and the authorities of the Fathers. Instead, they follow his nonsensical ravings.

We see it as absolutely necessary, out of love and our duty to our position and order, to respond to his insolence, with the Lord's guidance. Whoever wishes to read this faithfully, with the fear of God and concern for their salvation, may truly recognize how necessary it is, especially in these perilous and critical times, to hold firmly to the unchanging truth of holy Scripture. They must humbly obey the well-established authority of the holy orthodox Fathers and close their ears to undisciplined and utterly vain verbosity. They should take to heart with full attention the words of the Lord, which we almost see being fulfilled: "When the Son of Man comes, will he find faith on earth?" (Luke chapter 18, verse 8).
chunks.original_latin:

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
And the Apostle, quoting the Lord himself, warns us powerfully, saying: "There will come a time when people will not endure sound doctrine. Instead, they will gather teachers to suit their own desires and satisfy their itching ears; they will turn away from the truth and turn aside to fables." to Timothy, Chapter Four, Verses Four and Five.

Elsewhere, under the persona of the beloved and chosen disciple, he carefully advises all believers, especially those in the pastoral order, saying: "O Timothy, guard what has been entrusted to you, avoiding profane chatter and contradictions of what is falsely called knowledge. By professing it, some have strayed from the faith." First Timothy, Chapter Six, Verses Twenty and Twenty-One.

Therefore, with the words he arranged in the nineteen chapters of his work, as the Lord grants us wisdom, we proceed to respond not with our own understanding, but according to the holy Scriptures and the most blessed Catholic Fathers.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
CHAPTER ONE. In this first chapter, he introduces definitions of this nature.

1. All questions can be resolved by following the fourfold path of the rules of all philosophy. 2. There are not two predestinations.

However, the faith of the Church contrasts this by asserting that the truth of God's eternal judgment and ordinance, termed predestination, should be derived not from philosophers, but from the apostles and prophets of God. Not from worldly teachings of the fourfold paths, but from the one true way, which declares: "I am the way, the truth, and the life" John 14:6.

The blessed prophet Jeremiah encourages us, saying: "Stand at the crossroads, look, and ask for the ancient paths, the good way, and walk in it, and you will find rest for your souls" Jeremiah 6:16.

The prophet Isaiah assures the Church, saying: "And there will be a way, and it will be called the holy way. No lion will be there, nor any dangerous beast; it will be a direct way for us, so that even fools will not go astray on it" Isaiah 35:8.

Therefore, whoever chooses to be foolish in this world for Christ's sake and aims to follow the Apostle's words: "If anyone among you seems wise in this world, let him become a fool so that he may become wise" First Corinthians 3:18, should adhere to this true way, the good way, the direct way, which is the Lord Christ himself, consistently and steadfastly.

And they should avoid the cunning and deception of human wisdom, about which the same Apostle says: "For it is written: I will catch the wise in their craftiness" First Corinthians 3:19; and again: "The Lord knows the thoughts of the wise, that they are vain" Psalm 94:11.

Thus, through such philosophy and empty deceit, the question of divine predestination is not resolved, but rather confused and entangled, filled with various lies and errors.

Si quis videtur inter vos sapiens esse in hoc saeculo,

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
We're discussing the concept of God's eternal plan and judgment, which involves rewarding the righteous and condemning the wicked. This is based on God's singular, divine knowledge, where everything was preordained and predetermined simultaneously and eternally.

We can see it as two-fold because of its dual outcomes: some are mercifully saved, while others are justly condemned.

With the psalmist, we say to the judge of all: "I will sing of mercy and judgment to you, Lord" Psalm one hundred, verse one.

Listening to the judge declare this mystery of predestination, arranged with the Father and fulfilled through the blindness of some and the enlightenment of others, as revealed in the Gospel, we hear: "I thank you, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, because you have hidden these things from the wise and prudent, and have revealed them to little children. Yes, Father, for this was your good pleasure" Matthew eleven, verses twenty-five and twenty-seven.

What could be clearer than when he says that his coming blinds the proud and enlightens the humble?

This is expressed in: "Because you have hidden these things from the wise and prudent, and have revealed them to little children."

And what could be stronger about the just and merciful nature of predestination than when he adds: "Yes, Father, for this was your good pleasure."

Since the Father has given all judgment to the Son, and together they predetermined everything in eternal counsel, he says: "All things have been handed over to me by my Father" Matthew eleven, verse twenty-seven.

This includes all things—those to be saved and those to be condemned, those blinded justly and those enlightened mercifully—as he says elsewhere: "I have come into this world for judgment, so that those who do not see may see, and those who see may become blind" John nine, verse thirty-nine.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
This is the righteous judgment of God, which the Lord and Savior Himself praises and offers thanks for, to the glory of the Father.

In the same way, all divine Scripture and the entire holy Catholic Church, through psalms, hymns, and spiritual songs offered to God, faithfully celebrate it, praising and giving thanks as righteous, holy, and pious.

They echo the Psalmist: "The Lord is righteous in all His ways, and holy in all His works" (Psalm 145:17); and what the lawgiver says in the song of Deuteronomy: "Ascribe greatness to our God. His work is perfect, and all His ways are just: a faithful God, without iniquity; righteous and holy is the Lord" (Deuteronomy 32:3-4).

Also in the psalm, speaking both about delivering the chosen and condemning the rejected: "The Lord is near to all who call on Him in truth. He fulfills the desire of those who fear Him; He hears their cry and saves them: The Lord watches over all who love Him, but all the wicked He will destroy" (Psalm 145:18-20).

The righteous judgment of both groups is praised abundantly and generally when it continues: "My mouth will speak the praise of the Lord, and let all flesh bless His holy name forever and ever" (Psalm 145:21).

Similarly, in another psalm, after beginning with the praise of God, it quickly commemorates the righteous judgment of God in His praises, saying: "Praise the Lord, my soul. I will praise the Lord all my life; I will sing praise to my God as long as I live" (Psalm 146:1); and shortly after: "He remains faithful forever, executes justice for the oppressed, gives food to the hungry," continuing to where it says: "The Lord sustains the fatherless and the widow, but He frustrates the ways of the wicked" (Psalm 146:7-9).
chunks.original_latin:

Dei, sicut ipse Dominus et Salvator laudat, et cum
gratiarum actione ad Patris gloriam refert, ita omnis
Scriptura divina, et omnis sancta Ecclesia catholica

dicendo cum Psalmista: Justus Dominus in
omnibus viis suis, et sanctus in omnibus operibus suis
(Ps. XLIV, 17); et illud quod legislator in cantico

Deus fidelis, in quo non est iniquitas; justus et sanctus
Dominus (Deut. II, 3, 4). Item in psalmo, cum et
de electis liberandis, et de reprobis damnandis generaliter
dictum esset: Prope est Dominus omnibus
invocantibus eum in veritate. Voluntatem timentium
se faciet, et deprecationem eorum exaudiet, et salvos
faciet eos: Custodit Dominus omnes diligentes se, et
 omnes peccatores disperdet (Psal. CXLIV, 18-20). Utriusque partis justum judicium copiosa et generali
laudatione commendatur, cum statim subjungitur:
Laudationem Domini loquetur os meum, et
benedicat omnis caro nomini sancto ejus in saeculum,
et in saeculum saeculi (Ibid., 21). Sic et in alio
psalmo, cum praemisisset Dei laudationem, mox
utramque partem justum Dei judicium in ejus laudibus
 commemorans ait: Lauda, anima mea, Dominum. Laudabo Dominum in vita mea: psallam Deo
meo quandiu fuero (Psal. CXLV, 1); et post pauca:
Qui custodit veritatem in saeculum, facit judicium

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
In the Book of Revelation, after the final judgment, when the righteous are rewarded and the wicked are condemned, the saints offer praise and thanksgiving to God for both. The book states: The twenty-four elders who sit before God on their thrones fell on their faces and worshiped God, saying: We give thanks to you, Lord, Almighty God, who is and who was, because you have taken your great power and have reigned. The nations were angry, and your wrath has come, and the time for the dead to be judged, to reward your servants the prophets and the saints and those who fear your name, both small and great, and to destroy those who corrupted the earth. Revelation 11:16-18.

Many passages in the Holy Scriptures show that nothing is better for a faithful person than to recognize and faithfully praise God's just judgment in all cases by saying: You are just, Lord, and your judgment is right. Psalm 119:137.

This is also diligently advised by the holy Fathers and doctors of the Church, as the blessed Pope Leo exhorts in a certain place, saying: And blessed Augustine, when discussing the words of the psalm to the people where it is written: As smoke is driven away, so drive them away; as wax melts before the fire, so let the wicked perish before God. Psalm 68:3.

Who, he says, will boast of having a pure heart, or who will boast of being clean from sins? Therefore, when Scripture says: As wax melts before the fire, so let the wicked perish before God, who will not tremble, who will not leap up in fear? What then shall we do, and what hope do we have? For these things are not sung in vain. Or truly, when the Prophet says these things, does he wish them upon people, and does he not rather foresee what is to come? Indeed, the words appear to express a wish, but they are understood as a foretelling. Just as some things in the Scripture of the prophets are narrated as if they were done in the past when they predict the future, so some things are said as if they were a wish: but those who understand correctly what they hear recognize the vision of a foretelling.

Unde in Apocalypsi
post illud extremum judicium et remunerationis
justorum et damnationis iniquorum, talis laus
et gratiarum actio de utraque re a sanctis Deo offertur,
dicente eodem libro: Et viginti quatuor seniores

agimus tibi, Domine, Deus omnipotens, qui es, et
qui eras, et qui  accepisti virtutem tuam
 magnam, et regnasti. Et iratae sunt gentes, et advenit
ira tua, et tempus mortuorum judicari: reddere mercedem

nomen tuum pusillis, et magnis, et exterminandi eos
qui corruperunt terram (Apoc. XI, 16-18). Et multa
hujusmodi, quae in Scripturis sanctis multipliciter
inveniuntur, ut nihil melius sit homini fideli quam
justum Dei judicium in utraque parte agnoscere et
laudare fideliter dicendo: Justus es, Domine, et
rectum judicium tuum (Psal. CXVIII, 137). Hoc etiam sancti Patres et doctores Ecclesiae sollicite
admonent esse faciendum, sicut beatus papa
Leo in quodam loco exhortatur dicens:  Et beatus
Augustinus, cum tractaret de verbis psalmi ad
populum ubi scriptum est: Sicut defecit fumus,
deficiat; sicut fluit cera a facie ignis, sic pereant peccatores
a facie Dei (Psal. LXVII, 3): quis, inquit, gloriabitur
castum se habere cor, aut quis gloriabitur
mundum se esse a peccatis? Ac per hoc cum Scriptura
dicit: Sicut fluit cera a facie ignis, sic pereant
peccatores a facie Dei, quis non contremiscat, quis
non pavibundus exsiliat? Quid ergo faciemus, et
quae spes nobis est? neque enim haec frustra cantantur. Aut vero cum haec dicit Propheta, optat ea hominibus,
ac non potius ventura praevidet? In verbis
quidem figura optantis apparet, sed intelligitur praescientia
nuntiantis. Sicut enim quaedam in Scriptura
 prophetarum tanquam in praeteritum facta narrantur
cum futura praedicantur, ita quaedam tanquam
voto dicantur optantis: sed qui recte intelligunt
quod audiunt, visionem praenuntiantis agnoscunt.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Just as past words can signify future events, the intention of a prophet's prediction, even if expressed as a wish, must be understood.

Similarly, concerning Judas, the Lord's betrayer, the prophet appears to wish for what he predicted would happen to him.

Regarding the Jews, the prophet says: "Let their table become a snare, a trap, and a stumbling block" Psalm 69:23. The Apostle explains this as a prediction about them in Romans 11:9, just as Apostle Peter refers to what was predicted about Judas in a similar manner.

It's not without reason that future events are spoken of as if they have already occurred. To God, if something is certain, it is considered done. The prophet seems to speak as if wishing for what he foresees will certainly happen, showing, in my view, that we should accept God's known will, which is fixed and unchangeable.

In the Acts of the Apostles, a prophet named Agabus predicted that the apostle Paul would suffer greatly in Jerusalem at the hands of the Jews and would be bound. When the brethren heard this, they wanted to prevent him from going there, but Paul said, "What are you doing, disturbing my heart?" "For I am ready not only to be bound but even to die for the name of our Lord Jesus Christ" Acts 21:10 and following.

When the brethren saw Paul's unwavering determination to endure everything, they said: "Let the will of God be done." Did the apostles wish for such sufferings because they said: "Let the will of God be done," or did they devoutly submit their minds to the divine decree?

Similarly, when the Prophet says: "As wax melts before the fire, so let the wicked perish before God," he sees this fate looming over sinners and is pleased with what God has decreed, so he does not displease God.
chunks.original_latin:
Sicut ergo in verbis praeteriti temporis futura facta
significantur, sic in figura optantis praenuntiantis
mens intelligenda est Sic et de Juda Domini
traditore, tanquam  optat ei Propheta quod venturum

Deo enim si certa sunt tanquam pro factis habeantur,

quod certum praevidet esse venturum: nihil aliud,

praediceret apostolum Paulum in Hierosolyma a Judaeis

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
After these words, the most blessed teacher, wanting to make sure that the fixed and unchangeable nature of divine judgment's predestination wasn't seen as forcing anyone to do wrong, aimed to instill a healthy fear. This way, those who hear might flee from the coming wrath by repenting and correcting themselves, allowing them to escape what is certain to threaten those who persist in sin. He encourages this by saying:

So, the most faithful teacher affirmed the unchanging truth of divine predestination, even in the condemnation of sinners. Yet, he sincerely taught that if they correct themselves and change for the better, they will escape punishment. Divine predestination exercises just judgment in punishing sinners, but it doesn't take away the remedy of salvation from anyone who turns around, because His promise is true and faithful. Through the prophet, He not only promises but also swears, saying:

As I live, says the Lord God, I do not desire the death of the wicked, but that he may turn from his way and live. (Ezekiel Chapter 33)
chunks.original_latin:
Post haec verba beatissimus doctor, ne tam fixa
et immobilis divini judicii praedestinatio alicui male
agendi videretur necessitatem ponere, sed potius
salubrem terrorem incuteret, ut qui audiunt, poenitendo
et corrigendo fugiant a ventura ira, ut ita
possint evadere quod permanentibus in peccatis ex
impietatibus suis certissimum est imminere, ita exhortatur
dicens: 
Ita fidelissimus doctor et immobilem veritatem
 divinae praedestinationis etiam in peccatorum damnatione
asseruit, et tamen si seipsos correxerint, atque
in melius mutaverint, evasuros supplicia sincerissime
docuit. Quia divina illa praedestinatio in peccatoribus
puniendis justum exercet judicium, nulli
autem, si convertatur, aufert salutis remedium, quia
vera et fidelis est ejus promissio, qua per prophetam
non solum pollicetur, sed etiam jurat dicens: Vivo
ego, dicit Dominus Deus, quia nolo mortem impii, sed
ut convertatur a via sua et vivat (Ezech. XXXIII).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Chapter Two a presentation of eight definitions, stating as follows:

One: God's predestination and foreknowledge are His essence, just like His will, wisdom, and truth. Two: Foreknowledge and predestination are one and the same. Three: A person cannot reach God, whom they had abandoned with free will, without effort, the effort of work, and the gift of cooperating grace. Four: Predestination exists in God according to His substance, but cannot occur relatively. Five: Just as it is impious to duplicate, triple, or multiply two essences, wisdoms, knowledges, virtues, and all other things said about God, so too is anyone asserting two predestinations bound by the guilt of impiety. Six: There is one divine predestination, just as there is one divine operation, wisdom, and will. Seven: There is no compulsion by the necessity of predestination, just as there is none by will. Eight: Whatever is understood about the divine will should be felt about God's predestination.

Notice how much he proposed, as if to be followed by all and judged by none, without any testimony of divine Scripture or any attestation from the doctrine of the fathers, he defined so broadly.

But with the Lord's help, let's examine each point carefully and discern what should be believed about them according to the rule of faith.

He says: God's predestination and foreknowledge are His essence, just like His will, wisdom, and truth.

However, regarding the will, we indeed say it is essentially spoken of in the Lord because, in that supreme and simple essence of His, willing and being are not different, but what is being is also willing. Therefore, His will is such that He Himself is His will, and we do not doubt this at all. Similarly, regarding wisdom and truth: He possesses wisdom in such a way that He Himself is His wisdom; He possesses truth in such a way that He Himself is truth. In that simple nature of the Deity, there is no difference between having and being; but what is having is being, and what is being is having.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
So, if we say, as the blessed Augustine states, that God is eternal, immortal, incorruptible, unchanging, living, wise, powerful, beautiful, just, good, blessed, and a spirit, the last term, spirit, seems to refer only to the substance, while the others describe the qualities of this substance. However, in that ineffable and simple nature, what appears to be qualities should be understood as substance or essence.

Therefore, spirit should not be seen as God by substance and good by quality, but both should be seen as by substance, and the same applies to everything else we mentioned.

Since this is the case, and since will, wisdom, and truth exist in God in a way that fully reveals His nature, He is the highest will, wisdom, and truth, with all power, surpassing all understanding, and remaining unchangeable above all. It's clear that God's rule is to be understood as these being said of God substantially.

It's also clear that knowledge must be understood in God essentially, because for Him, being and knowing are not separate; for Him, to be is to know, and having knowledge is the same as being knowledge itself. Just as for Him, having wisdom is the same as being wisdom.

Whether God can be described as foreknowledge substantially, just as He is knowledge substantially, let those who can, judge according to reason and the rule of faith. However, it seems to us that while it can be truly said of God: It is not different for Him to be and to know, it cannot be said of Him except either falsely or too commonly: It is not different for Him to be and to foreknow.

It can rightly and commonly be said: God is knowledge, just as it is rightly and commonly said: God is wisdom, and no one doubts this. But to say: God is foreknowledge, as we've already mentioned, is either not true or too uncommon.

A similar or even stricter reasoning applies to the idea that God is substantially predestination.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Has anyone ever heard it said that, for God, being and predestining are different? Instead, what He predestines is His very being, just as it is truly said about Him: Being and knowing are not separate for Him; what He is, is what He knows.

So, we find ourselves expressing this in new words, saying that just as God is knowledge, wisdom, and truth, so too is He predestination.

However, it seems more appropriate and aligned with true faith and church doctrine to say that although these three—knowledge, foreknowledge, and predestination—appear separate to us, we distinguish them by certain properties: knowledge is spoken of absolutely, while foreknowledge and predestination refer to the foresight of future events.

Between these two, foreknowledge involves knowing both good and evil in advance, while predestination involves establishing and ordering only the good. We needed to speak and distinguish them this way so that, for us who are temporal and mortal, God's complete knowledge and His governance of creation might become clearer and more commendable through such distinctions or, if you will, distribution.

Yet, it is more convenient to understand these three in God under one name, knowledge, because whatever we understand and recognize distinctly in these three is all encompassed in His supreme and singular knowledge.

His knowledge is perfect and complete, unable to be diminished or increased, nor changed by any variety of circumstances. Therefore, what we attempt to discern about His knowledge, foreknowledge, and predestination is not different or varied in His perfect and unchangeable knowledge, but is eternally one and the same.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
We believe it's been correctly observed through proper ecclesiastical discipline that it's appropriate and customary to discuss God's foreknowledge and predestination, as He is the creator and judge of all things, in relation to His works. It's also fitting to speak of foreknowledge and predestination in God, meaning His eternal, perfect, and unchanging knowledge.

However, it's unusual or incorrect to say that God is foreknowledge or predestination Himself, because His knowledge pertains to Himself, while foreknowledge and predestination relate to His creations. Hence, in these matters, His actions towards or on behalf of His creations are demonstrated more than His essence or substance.

Therefore, it's said that there is foreknowledge and predestination of God or in God, just as there is the ordering or arrangement of God or in God. Yet, we've never heard anyone speak so absurdly as to suggest that just as there is the ordering and arrangement of God, God Himself should be called or defined as ordering and arrangement.

It's clear where this new and contentious definition has come from. It fears that if foreknowledge and predestination, like God's governance, aren't considered substantial in God but refer to the arrangement of His creations, they can't be called dual or in the plural.

Therefore, there's no contention among us about whether predestinations can be spoken of in the plural or not, as long as we faithfully and firmly hold that by the same judgment and counsel of divine foreknowledge and predestination, two things are certainly to be fulfilled: that the righteous are preordained to eternal glory, and the wicked, persisting in their impieties until death, are destined for eternal punishments.

For Scripture very clearly says this about the righteous: "And all who were appointed for eternal life believed" (Acts 13:48); and about the wicked, rightly condemned: "God endured with much patience the objects of wrath prepared for destruction" (Romans 9:22).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The way this operates in both the chosen and the rejected is through the effect of divine predestination and judgment. It's similar to how the same sun's ray invigorates healthy eyes but irritates weak ones, and how the same fire hardens clay while melting wax.

We should understand that God's predestination, like His justice, although singular and unchanging, clearly has a dual distribution. It delivers rewards to the deserving and punishment to the undeserving.

Indeed, it is asserted that God's will, like His wisdom and truth, is essentially singular, which is undoubtedly true. Even if one were to say that God essentially is justice, that would indeed be very true.

So why are these two, which are essential in God, spoken of in the Scriptures as plural—His will and His truth? As it is written in the Psalms, with the Lord Himself saying: "He has made all my wills wonderful in them," and elsewhere: "I have found David, son of Jesse, a man after my own heart, who will do all my wills."

Similarly, we read in the Psalms: "The Lord is just and loves justice." And again: "Truths have diminished among the sons of men." And in another place: "The Lord requires truths."

And while the light of God and the truth of God are not different but are simply and truly believed to be one in God—what is God's light is His truth, and what is His truth is His light—yet when the Psalmist said: "Send forth your light and your truth," he immediately added in the plural: "They have guided me and brought me to your holy mountain and your tabernacles."

Why is this? Because God's will, justice, and truth, although singular and simple in His nature, become manifold in the distribution of His gifts and in the arrangement of His creations.

This is why the Holy Spirit, who is one and simple in the Trinity of persons, is called the multifaceted grace of God and the seven Spirits due to this same distribution of gifts.

We're repeating this to ensure everyone understands that there should be no debate about the concept of predestination. Whether it can be discussed in the plural or not, it remains clear that there are two outcomes: mercifully preordained for life in the elect, or justly preordained for punishment in the reprobate.

Blessed Augustine teaches that just as we speak of the Lord's wisdom, we can also rightly speak of His prudence or knowledge, using these words: "Where even after some things he adds: 'Your knowledge is too wonderful for me; it is high, I cannot attain it' Psalm 139:6."

The excellent teacher, while confidently talking about God, acknowledged that God is both prudence and knowledge. However, when it came to calling God 'providence,' which involves the governance of creation, he refrained from making a hasty judgment. Instead, as if faced with a great challenge, he chose to conclude the discussion with admiration and prayer to God.

From this example, we should all consider how reverently we think about God, speak with moderation and discipline, and make cautious and respectful definitions.

Following this, the previously mentioned disputant, true to form, suggests: "And foreknowledge and predestination are one and the same." Rejecting this new error, let's adhere to the firm rule of faith. With God's help, we can discern that sometimes foreknowledge is mentioned, which cannot be predestination. The omnipotent God foresaw both good and evil, including human and angelic sins, but as a just and holy being, He could not predestine these to occur.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
However, his predestination relates either to the creation and governance of creatures, which is certainly good and just, or primarily to his works or judgments concerning rational creatures, namely, angels and humans. Among these, he justifies and blesses some through grace, while he abandons and condemns others through justice.

The good in them, meaning the holy people and angels, are his gifts or rewards, and the bad, referring to eternal punishments, are his just and rightful vengeance for all things. Therefore, his predestination must always be seen in the good and in his works, enacted in rational creatures, either mercifully or justly.

What he foreknew by predestining and eternally predestined by foreknowing is clear. Thus, it is evident that God’s predestination does not exist without foreknowledge; foreknowledge accompanies predestination in the good and just works of God, and exists without predestination in the evil works of wicked humans and angels.

The aforementioned Father, the blessed Augustine, briefly illustrates this in On the Predestination of the Saints, Chapter 10. Also, in another place, On the Gift of Perseverance, Chapter 14: From all the words of the holy doctor, it is very clear that foreknowledge and predestination should be distinctly and properly understood in sacred books.

They are so different from each other that they should not be understood as one and the same. However, sometimes even predestination, which never exists without foreknowledge, is also indicated by the name of foreknowledge, as the same doctor shows by saying, Chapter 18:

Behold what should follow for one who desires to think soundly, purely, and sincerely about divine foreknowledge and predestination according to the pious understanding of the holy Father. But the definition of the new debater, which defines these two distinctly different things as one and the same, should rightly be rejected for its falsehood and deceitfulness.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Whether he intended to define it this way to show, as he had already suggested, that these things are essentially one in God, his assertion is empty and trivial. Or, if he meant to teach that these matters should be understood indiscriminately, confusingly, and indifferently in the Scriptures, it is a most obvious error.

The same disputant adds: "A person cannot reach God, whom they had abandoned by free will without effort, without the effort and the gift of cooperating grace." In these words, what he says about the first person having abandoned God by free will is certainly not free will towards good in the one abandoning God and abandoned by God.

The blessed freedom, which the Apostle commends, saying: "Where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is freedom" (Second Corinthians 3:17), was no longer in the good nature created by God and the grace given by God. Rather, it was only free towards evil and captive under the dominion of sin.

About this most wretched freedom and servitude, the Apostle speaks to converted believers, saying: "For when you were slaves of sin, you were free in regard to righteousness" (Romans 6:20). And again: "Do you not know that if you present yourselves to anyone as obedient slaves, you are slaves of the one whom you obey, either of sin, which leads to death, or of obedience, which leads to righteousness?" (Romans 6:16).

Therefore, the Lord also says: "Everyone who commits sin is a slave to sin" (John 8:34). And the blessed Apostle Peter says: "For whatever overcomes a person, to that he is enslaved" (Second Peter 2:19).

And the blessed Paul does not remain silent about the captivity of sin, saying: "But I see in my body another law waging war against the law of my mind and making me captive to the law of sin that dwells in my body" (Romans 7:23).

Freed from original sin, if they pass away in this state, they undoubtedly reach God.

Therefore, to think otherwise—to believe that one cannot reach God without personal effort—is not Catholic but Pelagian. In the little book titled "Ecclesiastical Dogmas," Gennadius of Massilia provides a definition in chapter 21. However, as we've mentioned, this is entirely a Pelagian error.

So, for those reading it for other useful insights, when encountering such opinions, remember the Apostle's words: "Test everything; hold on to what is good" (First Thessalonians 5:21).

Following this, it's stated that predestination in God is according to substance, not relative. We've already discussed what seems more suitable to us. chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
<speak>
"Purity is the radiance of eternal light" (Wisdom 7:26), as Scripture testifies. This purity is not like a gift of God in the sense of being separate from Him; when referring specifically to the Holy Spirit, it relates directly to the Father and the Son, since the Spirit is their gift.
<break time="500ms"/>
In the holy and supreme Trinity, these relationships are unique: the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit are distinct, and none can be substituted for another. The Father is the only one who generates (begets), the Son is the only one who is begotten, and the Holy Spirit is the only one who proceeds. The Son is the Word, the image, and the radiance of the Father, and the Spirit is the shared gift of the Father and the Son.
<break time="500ms"/>
These roles and properties within the Trinity cannot be transferred from one person to another. For example, the Father cannot be called the Son, nor can the Son naturally be called the Father, nor can the Holy Spirit be identified as either the Father or the Son.
<break time="500ms"/>
It is clear, then, as we have said, that predestination (God’s plan and purpose) does not relate to God in the same way that the Father relates to the Son, the Son to the Father, or the Holy Spirit to both. Predestination is not a property of any one person within the Trinity; it belongs to the whole Trinity together. The entire Trinity is responsible for everything that is predestined.
<break time="500ms"/>
Just as governance belongs to the one governing, planning belongs to the one planning, and order belongs to the one creating order, so too predestination belongs to the one who predestines. No one would absurdly say that God, who plans everything, is the plan itself, or that God, who governs all things, is the act of governance. In the same way, it would be wrong to say that God, who predestines all things, is predestination itself.
<break time="500ms"/>
These terms—planning, governance, order, and predestination—should instead be understood as referring to the actions or works of the Creator, not as descriptions of God’s being.<break time="500ms"/>
</speak>

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Even if someone tries to argue that God is essentially predestination, like truth, goodness, and justice, and insists predestination should be singular like these qualities, they can't claim that God's predestination can be called God without a dual outcome and division of work. Specifically, this involves either preparing the righteous for life or preordaining the wicked for destruction.

Justice is truly called God, and when God is fundamentally associated with it, it's not correctly expressed in the plural. Yet, God's justice, which is also God, undeniably has two effects: rewarding the good or condemning the wicked.

Therefore, since predestination is rightly related to God who predestines, just as arrangement is to the arranger, governance to the governor, order to the orderer, operation to the operator, and creation to the creator, even if reason could show that predestination of God or predestination as God should be considered substantial, the twofold effect affirmed by the unchanging truth of the Holy Scriptures cannot be denied. What is the point of this unnecessary or even false argument?

Yet, he continues to say: Just as it is impious to duplicate, triple, or multiply two essences, wisdoms, knowledges, virtues, and all other things said about God, so is anyone who claims two predestinations guilty of impiety. To this, we respond that it is indeed true that when essence, wisdom, knowledge, and virtue are attributed to God, or when God Himself is described as such, He is understood to be essence, wisdom, knowledge, and virtue, not to be spoken of in the plural.

Because the Trinity itself is not three essences, but one essence; not three wisdoms, but one wisdom; not three knowledges, but one knowledge; not three virtues, but one virtue.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
However, when discussing the various arrangements or actions of God towards His creations, some things are clearly expressed in plural terms. For instance, it is said: "For the Lord is a God of knowledge" First Samuel 2:3. And if He is the Lord of knowledge, it's not someone else's knowledge, but His own.

How should this be understood unless it's because the knowledge itself, which is naturally one and simple in Him, becomes multiple for us when related to the arrangement or order of creation? Similarly, God is called strength, and yet, we read: "Proclaiming the praises of the Lord and His powers" Psalm 148:2. Just as God is rightly called strength, He is also called power, and yet we sing in the psalm: "Who can speak of the mighty acts of the Lord?" Psalm 105:2.

So, if God is one in knowledge, strength, and power, and yet, according to Scripture, we rightly speak of God in plural terms as the Lord of knowledge, and the powers of the Lord, and His strengths, why does this disputant claim it is impious when it comes from the source of truth and piety?

If these things, which truly exist in God's substance, are spoken of not impiously but piously, even in a plural sense, how can one be accused of impiety for wanting to speak of God's predestination plurally for the same reason, due to its double effectiveness?

Although we do not reject this because of the truly double effectiveness of predestination, nor do we consider it necessary to always say so, just as there is one justice of God, we must also understand that there is one predestination of God with multiple values.

He adds and says: There is one divine predestination, just as there is one divine operation, wisdom, substance, and will. In these words, he tries to convey what he mentioned earlier, that just as God is substantially wisdom, substantially will, and the highest substance, it is believed that the same God is predestination and operation.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
However, regarding predestination, we've already discussed in various ways what we believe should be held. Now, concerning the single operation of God, which is mentioned here, it seems he wants us to understand this operation as God Himself. It's crucial to carefully consider what this means according to the rule of faith.

We rightly say that the operation of God is certainly present in the creatures He has made, and we can rightly refer to it as an operation from God, because, as the Apostle says: "From Him, and through Him, and in Him are all things." But can we rightly say there is an operation in God, when God works nothing within Himself; rather, all creation, which He has made and continues to work in, exists outside Him, that is, outside His nature?

Although, in another sense, it can be said that creation is in Him, because it certainly subsists in His power and strength; hence the Apostle says, "In Him are all things"; and elsewhere: "For in Him we live, and move, and have our being" Acts 17:28.

Therefore, when God works nothing within Himself, that is, in His substance, but all His operation is understood in creatures, which are not of the same nature or substance as Him, how can we rightly say there is an operation in God? And if it isn't correct to say there is an operation in God, how much less can it be said that God Himself is an operation?

Although the same omnipotent God arranges all things with Himself and in Himself, He also works all things with Himself and in Himself, because to act, He certainly does not go outside Himself nor exceed Himself, whose will is His action: rather, He calls to Himself the things He works, so that each may receive its being from Him, who is supremely being, according to its manner; and let it be as the Apostle says: "He calls things that are not as though they are" Romans 4:17.

Therefore, He works nothing outside Himself, who by His will alone, eternal and without any effort, without any labor, without any craft, works all things. Nor does He work anything in Himself, for in the perfection and eternity of His substance, He creates nothing, increases nothing, decreases nothing, changes nothing.

However, because His will is to act, His willing and doing are not the same. This distinction highlights not the unity of Creator and creature, but the power of the Creator.

So, how can God's operation, or God Himself, be understood as operation in a substantial sense? Perhaps it could be said that God is operation, not because something operates within Him, but because He Himself works all things.

This idea is quite unusual, not based on the authority of Holy Scripture, and poses a danger to faith: If we claim God is operation, we risk the error of the Arians, who believed this about the Son and the Holy Spirit, suggesting He might have been created by someone. Indeed, we must restrain and avoid such presumptuous verbosity, as the Apostle warns against the novelty of words in First Timothy chapter six, verse twenty.

Yet, we who understand divine operation in His works and creatures read in Scripture that His operation is mentioned in the plural, as the Apostle clearly states: "There are different kinds of gifts, but the same Spirit; and there are different kinds of service, but the same Lord; and there are different kinds of working, but the same God works all of them in everyone" in First Corinthians chapter twelve, verses four to six.

Therefore, since God's operation is clearly mentioned in the plural and understood in various ways in His creations, what benefit does this kind of argument have? It serves no purpose, as the Apostle says, except for the subversion of those who listen in Second Timothy chapter two, verse fourteen.

He further states: Nothing is compelled by the necessity of predestination, just as neither by will. Both these claims—that nothing is compelled by God's predestination and will—are clearly false: Because, through the goodness of God's predestination, the elect are often compelled by various trials, labors, and tribulations to turn to God or to live according to His will. Just as the Apostle Paul was compelled when he was still Saul in Acts.

Struck by a terrifying voice from heaven and blinded by divine intervention, he was stopped from his errors and cruelty through such fear, so that he might turn to God.

By the same divine judgment and fairness, the reprobate are compelled to act; and if not to live unjustly and impiously, then certainly to face eternal punishment for their wrongdoings.

CHAPTER 3.

In this chapter, he established the following definitions:

1. God's predestination, like His essence, neither compels anyone nor imposes any necessity. 2. There are not two forms of predestination. 3. Death, sin, and misery do not originate from God. 4. Predestination, like love, is singular and lacks plurality.

We've already discussed these four points earlier, as guided by the Lord.

The first point states that God's predestination, like His essence, neither compels anyone nor imposes necessity. The second point affirms there are not two forms of predestination. The fourth point clarifies that predestination, like love, is not multiple or plural.

However, love wasn't previously mentioned among the examples of God's substance that he wanted to be understood earlier.

It's clear, as the blessed Apostle John teaches: God is love.

This is from First John, chapter four, verse sixteen.

According to true faith, we rightly say that love is from God, love is in God, and love is God. However, this love, being a substance in God like truth, justice, and goodness, is not called double when understood about God because it is singular and simple in Him.

Therefore, it cannot be described as double or triple, because the divine substance—God's essence as Trinity—is not doubled or tripled.

It is not lesser in one than in three, nor greater in two or three than in one. As much as deity, truth, and love exist in one person of the Holy Trinity, they exist equally in two, and in three, being perfect in each, and perfect in all. The Father is perfect God, the Son is perfect God, and the Holy Spirit is perfect God, and these three are one perfect God.

In us, however, this love is not a substance, but a gift from God, as the Apostle says:

The love of God has been poured into our hearts through the Holy Spirit, who has been given to us.

This is from Romans, chapter five, verse five.

So, it can be within us both twin and double, because of the two commandments of love: love for God and love for our neighbor. These create in us a dual affection: to love God with all our heart and to love our neighbor as ourselves. Matthew twenty-two, thirty-seven, thirty-nine.

It is indeed the grace of God, about which the blessed Apostle Peter says: "Each of you should use whatever gift you have received to serve others, as faithful stewards of God's varied grace." First Peter four, ten.

Who doesn't know that love isn't plural, nor is it found in the Scriptures in the plural form, either in God or in us? Regarding the idea that predestination does not accept a plural number just as love does not, it has already been sufficiently discussed above and doesn't need to be repeated continually.

The claim that in the first of these propositions, the predestination of God is compared to the substance of God, or rather said to be the substance of God, has already been addressed as much as we could. And when it is stated that God's predestination forces no one and imposes no necessity, if this means that through His predestination, Almighty God forces no one to do evil, to be evil, and to be unable to do otherwise, then this is entirely correct.

However, if this was stated ambiguously and without clarification to suggest that predestination forces no one and imposes no necessity, and did not add what it might force or what necessity it might impose, then it denies that those who persist in their wickedness until the end are justly punished by the eternal judgment of divine predestination. It clearly accepts divine predestination in part and denies it in part: that God, by the same predestination, prepared the righteous for the kingdom but did not predestine the wicked for punishment.

The third proposition remains, which he placed and defined here, that death, sin, and misery are not from God.

Indeed, regarding sin, as the universal Catholic faith holds, it's rightly said that sin isn't from God, because He neither willed, commanded, nor urged man to sin. On the contrary, before man sinned, He forbade him from sinning and warned him of the punishment of death to prevent him from sinning. After the sin, He justly punished him as one who rebelled against His will and opposed it.

Therefore, sin is not from God, who created man upright and without sin, as Ecclesiasticus says: "This alone I have found: that God made man upright, but they have sought out many schemes" (Ecclesiasticus 7:30).

Instead, the beginning of sin is from the one who first sinned in heaven and later deceived man to sin, killing him by deception in paradise, as the blessed Apostle John testifies, "The devil has been sinning from the beginning" (First John 3:8). And the Lord Himself teaches, saying, "He was a murderer from the beginning and did not stand in the truth, because there is no truth in him" (John 8:44).

In not standing in the truth, he destroyed himself; by offering sin to man, he killed man. As the first sinner, he also became the first murderer, because "the soul who sins shall die" (Ezekiel 18:4).

Therefore, he's said in the Scriptures to have the power of death (Hebrews 2:14), not by his own power, but because death has invaded and oppressed the whole human race through his malicious envy. Hence, Scripture says, "Through the devil's envy, death entered the world, and those who belong to his party imitate him" (Wisdom 2:24).

The Lord destroyed this wicked dominion of his through His own death, as the Apostle says about Him: "That through death He might destroy the one who has the power of death, that is, the devil" (Hebrews 2:14). He is indeed the Lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world (John 1:29).

Therefore, this speaker rightly said that sin is not from God. Yet he unnecessarily mentioned this when discussing divine predestination, because no believer says that God predestined sins.

However, the claim that death and misery are not from God is clearly contradicted by Scripture, which states: "Good and bad, life and death, poverty and wealth are from God" (Ecclesiasticus 11:14).

But Scripture also says: "God did not make death, nor does He delight in the destruction of the living" (Wisdom 1:13), so we must carefully consider how to faithfully understand both statements: namely, that God did not create death, and that both death and life are from God.

Thus, both can be rightly understood: God did not create death, as He made humans immortal if they had not sinned. And again, death is from God because He justly condemned the sinful human to death; so death is not from Him by creation, yet it is truly from Him as retribution.

Just as this physical death, which is understood as the first, is from God because it was justly inflicted on sinful humans by Him, so too the second death in hell is justly inflicted on those who persist in sin.

Therefore, both the first, which separates the soul from the body, and the second, where both soul and body are lost in hell, because they are just and inflicted by God's righteous judgment on humans, are from God.

Hence, elsewhere the same Scripture refers to the present physical death: "Do not fear the sentence of death; remember those who have gone before you and those who will come after you" (Ecclesiasticus 41:5). This judgment is from the Lord for all flesh.

And again: "Fire, hail, famine, and death, all these were created for vengeance" (Ecclesiasticus 39:35).

And how were famine and death created? Not as physical creations, but prepared in God’s hidden plan for His vengeance; so that their manifestation seems like a kind of creation.

And again, the same Scripture says: "Death, bloodshed, strife, and the sword, calamities, famine, tribulation, and the scourge: these were created for the wicked, and for their sake, the flood was made" (Ecclesiasticus 40:9-10).

Since the death of a person is said to result from just and divine vengeance, as clearly and truthfully understood from the Scriptures to be from God, it follows that when the blessed Elijah prayed for the son of the widow with whom he was staying, after the boy had died, he said to God: "Lord, have you also brought trouble upon this widow I am staying with by causing her son to die?" (First Kings 17:20).

And the Lord in the Gospel clearly states: "Fear him who, after he has killed, has the power to throw into hell." (Luke 12:5).

The clear truth of Scripture should be understood, and vanity should be silenced. Just as death, which is certainly the penalty for sin, so too are all the miseries of labor, tribulations, and calamities that followed humanity after sin. Because they are imposed and inflicted by divine arrangement and judgment, Scripture rightly says they are from God, as the testimonies we have provided clearly show.

Therefore, just as sin, which is contrary to God's justice, is truly not from God, the penalty for sin, that is, death, and all the calamity and misery that followed, are rightly understood to be from God, as Scripture attests, because they fit God's just judgment and are inflicted by his just vengeance.

Even if the devil and other malignant angels do anything, they are ministers of divine vengeance and retribution, not judges or authors, as the story of the blessed Job clearly shows. In that story, it is fully shown that not only did he harm Job with the worst sores from the sole of his foot to the top of his head, or kill his children by the collapse of their house, or destroy his abundant family either by the sword of raiding robbers or by fire from heaven, but he did not even dare to touch Job’s livestock and animals unless the Lord first permitted him, saying: "Behold, all that he has is in your hand; only do not lay a hand on him." (Job 1:12). And again: "Behold, he is in your hand; but spare his life." (Job 2:6).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Chapter four. In this chapter, he presents five definitions in the following order.

One: Three heresies. The first is the Pelagian heresy, which advocates for free will without acknowledging grace. The second focuses solely on grace. The third is Gottschalk's view, which introduces necessity through predestination.

Two: The essence of man consists of three elements: being, willing, and knowing. Man has not lost this essence through sin.

Three: No nature can perish, and it has not lost free will, meaning its inherent nature remains.

Four: After sin, freedom remained with man, but he lost its strength and power.

Five: Nature can always begin, but it can only be completed through grace.

Regarding the three heresies, the first, the Pelagian heresy, claims that free will alone, without God's grace, is enough for salvation. This view is well known and condemned by the Church. The Church follows the teachings of the Lord, who praises His grace in all things, saying: "Whoever remains in me, and I in him, bears much fruit, for without me, you can do nothing" (John 15:5).

In saying, "Whoever remains in me, and I in him, bears much fruit," He highlights the benefit of grace for those who remain in Him, allowing them to produce fruit for God, just as a branch receives sustenance from the vine's root. When He added, "For without me, you can do nothing," it clearly shows that human free will cannot accomplish good works without His grace.

As for the second heresy, described as solely of grace, it is unclear whether it exists or has existed in the Church, which holds that a man is saved by God's grace alone, thereby denying or nullifying human free will. This is not known to us.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The oldest and most notorious heretics, Marcion, Valentinus, and Manichaeus, introduced the idea of two or three fundamental principles. They claimed there were two natures for angels or humans: one good and the other evil.

They argued that the good nature was inherently good and could be nothing else, while the evil nature was inherently evil and could not change. They overlooked the grace of God, foolishly suggesting that nature was simply good or evil by itself.

In contrast, the Catholic Church, guided and strengthened by the teachings of the law and the Gospel, acknowledges and teaches only one principle for all creatures, both heavenly and earthly, visible and invisible. This is the Holy Trinity: the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit, one God, from whom everything originates, through whom everything exists, and in whom everything is sustained.

No nature exists apart from Him, the most excellent Creator, and therefore every nature, as far as it is a nature, is good. Evil is not a nature but rather a defect of nature.

Since this nature is changeable in angelic and human beings, it has the potential to fall from the good it was created in due to its own fault. However, for the human race, which is saved by God's mercy, it can rise and be restored to good.

As for the angels who are evil and condemned by eternal judgment, they fell from God through pride to such an extent that they no longer deserve to be restored by any remedy. They have lost not only the good will in which they were created but also the possibility of that good will, through the severe judgment of the Creator.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation: So, when those heretics we mentioned earlier either defended nature as unchangeably good or accused it of being unchangeably evil, they didn't demonstrate how they could speak about grace or free will. On the other hand, the Church of God maintains, as we briefly noted: what is this second heresy, so unknown, so new and unheard of, which denies free will and only preaches grace? For this reason, it seems that he very cleverly and cunningly proposed the heresy of grace alone, without revealing any author or followers of it in any way. chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
This monstrous and astonishing doctrine should have been kept far away from the ears of the faithful, yet it sits here, debating and spreading countless lies and insults against the truth of the faith. The Church's pastors have neither corrected nor expelled these things.

He clearly wanted to show that he wasn't talking about any older heresy that only proclaimed grace. He placed this heresy after the Pelagian, not before. From the time of Saint Augustine until now, no such heresy can be found in the Church, unless he accuses either the blessed Augustine, as mentioned, or us who follow him, of this error.

He identifies a third heresy as enforcing necessity and force upon predestination. He doesn't keep silent about its author, naming it after a certain most wretched and unfortunate monk named Gottschalk, who was long ago condemned and imprisoned for many years.

If he dared to teach something so significant and dangerous against the Catholic faith that it warranted such severe synodical judgment, it would have been appropriate, by the Church's ancient custom, to convey this grave error to other churches across the kingdom as a precaution, to prevent more people from being affected by it. This should have been done, if not when such a great evil was first uncovered, then at least after it was condemned so severely. It should have been shared through synodical and ecclesiastical letters with all brothers and fellow bishops.

If this had always been done according to the ecclesiastical customs followed by the Fathers, as we mentioned, we would now be better informed and more prepared to refute and disprove what he suggests he taught, claiming he imposed necessity and force on predestination.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Regarding his accusation about predestination in the plural form, it's evident, as we've pointed out many times before, that his issue isn't just with the plural use of the word "predestination," but with the very concept of predestination being plural in nature. This has a dual effect: as we've often stated and demonstrated from the Holy Scriptures, it involves the preparation of the elect for life and the preordination of the reprobate for punishment.

To counter this, against the faith of the Church, he has embarked on a lengthy and flawed mission to convince us with new arguments that predestination is the essence of God, or rather that God himself is predestination, and thus it shouldn't be viewed in the plural. Specifically, he argues that predestination should only relate to the elect and not at all to the reprobate.

Using this opportunity to dismiss the rightful predestination of the reprobate to eternal punishment, he has boldly claimed, openly contradicting the faith and truth of the Scriptures, that just as sin is not from God, neither is its punishment. He suggests that all misery and death, which has followed sinful humanity, is not from God.

However, it's clear that from God, who justly condemns and judges, both the misery of toil and sweat has been imposed on sinful humanity, along with the ultimate suffering of death itself. As the Lord said about the miseries of a laborious life: "Cursed is the ground because of you; through painful toil you will eat food from it all the days of your life. It will produce thorns and thistles for you, and you will eat the plants of the field. By the sweat of your brow you will eat your food" (Genesis 3:17-19). He immediately added the ultimate penalty of death: "Until you return to the ground, since from it you were taken; for dust you are and to dust you will return" (Genesis 3:19).

And to the woman, who sinned before her husband, he immediately imposed a punishment specific to her sin, besides the one she shares with her husband, saying: "I will make your pains in childbearing very severe; with painful labor you will give birth to children," etc.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
By denying the righteous divine judgment of predestination for the condemned, he claims that all human miseries and even death are not from God, suggesting they are not part of His judgment. If asked where death and misery originate, if not from God, what remains except to falsely claim they come from nowhere or from the devil? Since saying they come from nowhere would be utterly insane: the devil only suggested reasons to sin, but the punishment for sin was imposed by the just judge, not by him.

Regarding the claim that Gottschalk introduced necessity and force into predestination: if he means that the predestination of the condemned imposes force and necessity, making them inevitably evil and unable to be anything else, this is completely contrary to the Catholic faith. It is absurd and impious to suggest that Almighty God, who wants no one to be evil, forces and compels someone to be evil. As it is written: the Lord is righteous and loves righteousness Psalms eleven:seven, He compels no one to be unjust.

This pertains to all the condemned, regarding their sins and ultimate punishment, which was enacted with the first man's sin in the first judgment: just as he was not compelled by any urging, compulsion, or predestination from God to sin, but sinned of his own free will, yet unwillingly accepted the judgment and condemnation of his sin, which was the first punishment of man. Likewise, the entire multitude of the condemned, who descend from that condemnation, are not compelled to sin by God's predestination, as God predestined no sins. However, by the just and eternal judgment of divine predestination, they are compelled to bear punishment, receiving from God the force and necessity of just damnation, which had no force or necessity compelling the commission of iniquity.

a fide catholica: quia omnipotens Deus (qui neminem
 vult esse malum) nimis absurdum et impium
est, ut dicatur quod aliquem cogat et compellat esse
malum, et (de quo scriptum est: Justus Dominus
justitias dilexit (Ps. X, 8) aliquem compellat esse
injustum. Sed hoc agitur in omnibus reprobis, de
peccatis eorum et supplicio extremo, quod actum
est in primo homine peccante judicio primo: ut, sicut
ille nulla Dei impulsione vel compulsione aut
praedestinatione compulsus est ad peccandum, sed
sua tantum sponte peccavit, judicium tamen et damnationem
ipsius peccati nolens invitusque suscepit,
quod fuit supplicium hominis primum: ita et omnis
reproborum multitudo, quae ex illa damnatione descendit,
non Dei praedestinatione compellitur ad peccandum,
cum Deus nulla peccata praedestinaverit;
 sed tamen ipsius divinae praedestinationis justo et
aeterno judicio compellitur ad luendum supplicium;
recipiens a Deo vim et necessitatem justae damnationis,
quae nullam habuit vim aut necessitatem perpetrandae
iniquitatis.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Those who are judged to stand on the left and face eternal punishment will not accept it willingly. Instead, they will face it unwillingly and reluctantly, filled with grief and trembling without any remedy.

By the command of divine majesty and through the angels' service, they will be cast there, as the Lord clearly states in the Gospel: "So it will be at the end of the age: the angels will come and separate the wicked from among the righteous and throw them into the fiery furnace. There will be weeping and gnashing of teeth" (Matthew 13:40-42).

To these reapers, meaning the ministering angels, when the harvest comes, which is the end of the age, the judge himself will say: "Gather the weeds and tie them in bundles to be burned; then gather the wheat into my barn" (Matthew 13:30).

Behold the power and necessity of divine predestination towards the reprobate, which the Church of God believes in accordance with the truth of the Gospel. This is the power and necessity of judgment, not the power and necessity of sin.

But whoever claims that God imparts or imposes the power and necessity of sinning on humans is clearly blaspheming God horribly. Such a claim suggests that by compelling them to sin, He becomes the author of sin.

Therefore, we believe according to God's truth about the predestination of the reprobate: faithfully confessing Him as the author not of their sin, but of their just punishment. Thus, what this person claims—that preaching this predestination imposes a necessity to sin—we consider to be slanderous and vain, which is evident to everyone from what has been said.

After this, he adds that the substance of man consists of three things: to be, to will, to know; and that he did not lose this by sinning. However, we say that the substance of man is nothing else but what divine Scripture shows at the beginning of human creation, saying: "Then the Lord God formed man from the dust of the ground and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life, and man became a living being" (Genesis 2:7).
chunks.original_latin:
Neque enim illi qui a sinistris
stabunt in judicio, et puniendi sunt igne aeterno,
volentes suscipient tale supplicium, sed utique nolentes
et inviti, et irremediabiliter dolentes ac trementes,
divinae majestatis nutu, et angelico ministerio
illuc praecipitabuntur, sicut Dominus aperte in
Evangelio dicit: Sic erit in consummatione saeculi:
exhibunt angeli, et separabunt malos de medio justorum,
et mittent eos in caminum ignis: illic erit fletus,
et stridor dentium (Matth. XIII, 40-42). Istis
namque messoribus, id est ministris angelis, quando
 venerit messio, id est saeculi consummatio, ab ipso
judice dicetur: Colligite zizania, et alligate ea in
fasciculos ad comburendum; triticum autem congregate
in horreum meum (Ibid., 30). Ecce qualem vim
et necessitatem divinae praedestinationis erga reprobos
Ecclesia Dei juxta evangelicam veritatem credit,
id est vim et necessitatem judicii; non vim, et necessitatem
peccati. Qui autem vim, et necessitatem
peccandi Deum intulisse homini vel inferre
dicit, manifeste horribiliter in Deum blasphemat,
quem ad peccata compellendo, utique auctorem
peccati esse confirmat. Hoc igitur modo nos,
secundum veritatem Dei, de reproborum praedestinatione
sentimus: fideliter eum confitentes non peccati
 eorum, sed justi supplicii auctorem. Et ideo quod
iste delirat, quasi hujus praedestinationis praedicatio,
necessitatis ad peccandum sit irrogatio, quam sit
calumniosum et vanum putamus, quod ex his quae
dicta sunt omnibus clareat. Post haec iste subjungit: Substantiam hominis esse
tria, id est esse, velle, scire; et hanc peccando non
amisisse. Nos autem substantiam hominis non aliud
esse dicimus, nisi quam Scriptura divina in principio
conditionis humanae demonstrat dicens: Formavit
igitur Dominus Deus hominem de limo terrae, et
inspiravit in faciem ejus spiraculum vitae, et factus
est homo in animam viventem (Gen. II, 7).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
This captures the essence of a human being, known by both the learned and unlearned: the soul and the body, which are vitally connected. The body is fashioned from the dust of the earth, while the soul comes from God's inspiration. Together, they form a person, making man a living soul.

Since divine authority teaches this, and the Catholic truth holds it, what does this additional claim mean, suggesting man's substance consists of three things: to exist, to want, to know? It's clear that man's substance is not three things, but two, as we've already said: the soul and the body. Yet, this perspective dismisses the body, which naturally belongs to man's substance, and claims that man's substance is to exist, to want, to know. These indeed reside only in the soul, as if man's substance is nothing but the soul alone.

It seems that this idea may have been taken from Saint Augustine's discussions in the books about the Trinity. However, it's unlikely that such a great teacher would have said something so absurd and unskilled, defining man's substance as to exist, to want, to know, when it is the soul and body.

Therefore, upon careful reading and consideration of his words in those books, one can understand that he did not say man's substance is these three: to exist, to know, to want. Rather, he spoke about the internal substance of man, the rational mind, where man was created in the image and likeness of God, as stated in Genesis 1:26. He taught that these qualities are naturally and substantially instilled by God in the rational and intellectual mind itself.

Thus, he rightly says in those discussions that these three qualities are of one substance with the mind itself and within the mind itself. Just as the mind inherently possesses existence, it also inherently possesses the will. This means it naturally and substantially has the ability to know and the ability to will. This is indeed a great gift of nature, created wonderfully by the best Creator.
chunks.original_latin:
Haec est
enim substantia hominis, qua subsistit et vivit, sicut
docti indoctique noverunt, anima scilicet, et corpus
 sibi vitaliter connexum; sed corpus de limo terrae,
anima ex inspiratione Dei. His constat, et ita factus
est homo in animam viventem. Cum ergo ita doceat
divina auctoritas, et ita teneat catholica veritas, quid
sibi vult ista superfluitas, substantiam hominis esse
tria, id est esse, velle, scire? cum manifestum sit
substantiam hominis non tria esse, sed duo quaedam,
id est (ut jam diximus) animam et corpus. Sed iste,
praetermisso corpore, quod naturaliter ad substantiam
hominis pertinet, substantiam hominis esse dicit,
esse, velle, scire; quae utique in sola anima consistunt:
quasi substantia hominis non sit, nisi
anima sola. Videtur tamen ex disputationibus sancti
Augustini in libris de Trinitate occasionem dicendi
ista sumpsisse: sed absit ut tantus doctor tam
