hominis sit anima et corpus, ille definierit
substantiam esse hominis, esse, velle, scire. Non
ergo ait (sicut manifeste intelligere poterit qui dicta
ejus in eisdem libris diligentissime legerit et perpenderit)
substantiam esse hominis haec tria, id est
esse, scire, velle: sed in substantia esse hominis
non exterioris, sed interioris, id est in mente rationali,
ubi creatus est homo ad imaginem et similitudinem
Dei (Gen. I, 26). Docens ea esse in ipsa mente
rationali et intellectuali, naturaliter et substantialiter
a Deo insita. Unde et rectissime in eisdem disputationibus
dicit haec tria unius cum ipsa et in ipsa
mente esse substantiae. Quia videlicet ipsa mens sicut
substantialiter habet esse, ita substantialiter habet
 velle: id est substantialiter et naturaliter habet
scire posse et velle posse. Magnum est utique bonum istud naturae ab optimo
Conditore bene et mirabiliter conditae.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
If the human mind can only exist, know, and desire, but lacks the gift from its Creator to exist well and happily, to know rightly about its Creator, and to desire to be with Him through love, then what is the value of having existence, knowledge, and will? Without this gift, these abilities can lead to one's own detriment. It will exist unhappily, know falsely, and desire harmfully and wickedly.

Just as the angelic nature, condemned in the devil and his angels, indeed possesses these three things in its spiritual substance—to exist, to know, and to will—but its existence is painful, and all its knowledge and will are directed towards error and evil.

So, why boast that human nature hasn't lost the ability to exist, know, and will by sinning, when it has completely lost the goodness and happiness of these abilities? It begins to exist in misery instead of blessedness, loses divine knowledge, and loses heavenly desire. Only to the extent that the grace of the Creator later helped and uplifted it, allowing it to recognize the good things it lost, grieve over them, and by grieving and repenting, implore divine help. Thus, what it lost through its own fault, it regained through divine goodness.

Therefore, the ineffable mercy of the Creator did not take away these natural goods—existence, knowledge, and will—even after sin, so there would be someone to have mercy on.

For if He did not want it to exist after sin, then certainly, along with existence, knowledge and will would perish in it. He wanted it to exist so there would be someone to have mercy on; He wanted it to know so there would be someone to enlighten with His knowledge; He wanted it to will so there would be someone to bless with His love.

Thus, the devil, who wanted to destroy God's creation, remained defeated, and the Creator's goodness and mercy remained undefeated. But why this was proposed by him will become clearer from his subsequent propositions. For he immediately added, following these two connected propositions, and said: No nature can perish, nor did he lose free will, that is, his nature.
chunks.original_latin:
Sed si hoc
solum habeat mens hominis ut possit esse, possit
scire, possit velle, et non habeat ex dono ejusdem
Conditoris sui ut possit bene et beate esse, possit pie
et recte de auctore suo scire, possit, amando illum,
cum illo esse velle, quid ei proderit habere esse,
scire, velle, cum totum hoc malo suo habeat, si illud
donum Creatoris sui non habeat? habebit enim esse
infeliciter, scire fallaciter, velle perniciose et nequiter:
sicut etiam angelica natura, in diabolo et angelis
ejus damnata, utique habet haec tria in substantia
 sua spirituali, id est esse, scire, velle: sed
tamen esse in poenale est: scire autem et velle totum
ad errorem, totum ad malum conversum est. Quid est ergo quod iste gloriatur naturam humanam
peccando ista non amisisse, id est ut possit esse,
scire, velle, cum omnium horum bonum et felicitatem
omnino amiserit, esse incipiens, misera ex
beata, scire amittens divina, et velle perdens coelestia:
nisi quantum ea postea adjuvit et erexit gratia
Conditoris, ut amissa bona recognosceret, recognita
doleret, dolendo et poenitendo divinum auxilium
imploraret: atque ita quod amiserat suo vitio,
divina bonitate reciperet. Propterea igitur ineffabilis
misericordia Conditoris non abstulit ei etiam post
peccatum haec naturalia bona sua, id est esse, scire,
 velle, ut haberet cui misereri potuisset: si enim
post peccatum noluisset eum esse, simul utique cum
ipso et in ipso periret, et scire, et velle: voluit itaque
eum esse, ut haberet cui misereretur; voluit
eum scire, ut haberet quem sua cognitione illumiminaret;
voluit eum velle, ut haberet quem suo
amore beatificaret. Ita et diabolus qui creaturam Dei
disperdere voluit, remansit victus, et Creatoris bonitas,
et misericordia permansit invicta. Sed iste
cur hoc proposuerit, ex sequentibus ejus propositionibus
manifestius apparebit. Subjunxit enim statim post istas duas propositiones
sibi cohaerentes et ait: Nullam naturam posse perire,
nec liberam voluntatem eum perdidisse, id est
naturam suam.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
In these words, he expressed that no nature can perish; he was generally speaking about the nature of all things. How did he come to know this, or how did he prove it to be true? Clearly, just as the entire nature of things could come into existence from nothing by the will of the Creator, so too, if He wills, it can perish and return to nothing, ceasing to exist. Scripture illustrates this by speaking of the greatness and power of the Creator: "He is higher than heaven, and what can you do? Deeper than the depths of the underworld, and how can you know? His measure is longer than the earth and wider than the sea. If He overturns everything or confines it in one place, who can resist Him? Or who can say to Him: Why do you do this?" Job 11:8-10.

Certainly, when the all-powerful Creator was preparing to destroy the world with a flood due to the excessive wickedness and impiety of humans, as Scripture bears witness, He said: "I will destroy man whom I have created from the face of the earth, from man to animals, from creeping things to the birds of the sky." Genesis 6:7.

And again: "The earth is filled with violence because of them, and behold, I will destroy them with the earth." Genesis 6:13.

Therefore, just as in that great and terrible flood, the nature of the world was largely destroyed and altered for the worse, as it was said: "And I will destroy them with the earth," nearly all the nature of animals in the world, including both humans and livestock, was destroyed by the waters. Even the souls of the wicked, who deserved to perish in such a dreadful punishment, were kept and passed on to greater, infernal punishment, with only a few being saved by God's mercy in the ark. If He willed, couldn't He destroy the entire nature of the world, and all worldly and heavenly things with the amazing power of the Creator? As clearly written in the books of Maccabees, certain holy men preparing to fight against their adversaries are recorded to have said: "We, however, trust in the almighty God who can with one nod destroy these opposing forces and the entire world." Second Maccabees 8:18.
chunks.original_latin:
In quibus verbis, quod definivit nullam
 naturam posse perire; quod utique generaliter
de omnium rerum natura dixit, unde didicit, aut
unde verum esse ostendit? cum manifeste omnis
rerum natura sicut voluntate Creatoris potuit ex
nihilo subsistere, ut esset quae ante non erat; ita
etiam, si ipse velit, possit perire, et redire in nihilum,
ut non sit. Hoc namque et Scriptura ostendit
dicens de magnitudine et potentia Creatoris: Excelsior
coelo est, et quid facies? profundior inferno, et
unde cognosces? Longior terra mensura ejus et latior
mari. Si subverterit omnia, vel in unum coarctaverit,
quis resistet ei? aut quis dicere ei potest: Quare ita
facis? (Job XI, 8-10.) Certe ipse omnipotens
Conditor cum propter nimiam malitiam et impietatem
hominum pararet delere mundum diluvio, attestante
 Scriptura, sic ait: Delebo, inquit, hominem
quem creavi a facie terrae, ab homine usque ad animantia,
a reptili usque ad volucres coeli (Gen. VI, 7). Et iterum: Repleta est terra iniquitate a facie eorum,
et ego disperdam eos cum terra (Ibid., 13). Sicut
ergo illo magno et horrendo diluvio magna ex parte
natura mundi deleta est, et in deterius commutata,
sicut dictum fuerat: Et ego disperdam eos cum terra:
et omnis pene natura animalium, quae in mundo
erant, id est tam hominum quam pecorum, aquis
deleta est: etiam animae impiorum, qui tam horrendo
supplicio interire meruerunt, reservatae sunt
et transierunt ad majus, id est infernale supplicium;
salvatis his solis qui tam exiguo numero in arca Dei
 misericordia liberati sunt: nonne (si ita vellet) delere
omnem naturam mundi, et mundalium sive coelestium
rerum facillime hoc posset admiranda potentia
Creatoris, sicut manifeste in libris Machabaeorum. Quidam sancti viri contra adversarios suos
dimicaturi dixisse leguntur: Nos autem in omnipotenti
Deo qui potest et istos contrarios venientes, et
universum mundum uno nutu delere, confidimus (II
Mach. VIII, 18).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
However, we must ask him about the final destruction of the world, which the blessed Apostle Peter describes as: "In which the heavens will pass away with a great noise, and the elements will melt with fervent heat" (Second Peter 3:10), what does he think will happen to the nature of the world's four elements then? If they remain as they are now, how is this apostolic statement true? But if they are mostly changed or perish, how is it true that no nature can perish?

Certainly, the four seasons that guide the year—spring, summer, autumn, and winter—have their own distinct natural qualities. But when there is a new heaven and a new earth, and the course of the sun, moon, and stars ceases, causing days and nights to no longer follow each other for the rest and refreshment of mortals, those four seasons, which depend on the sun's course, cannot exist as they do now. So, how will their nature not perish?

We must also ask what he believes will happen when heaven and earth are renewed by fire and transformed into a form suitable for the immortal bodies of the saints, in a miraculous way. What, I ask, does he believe will happen to the entire nature of birds, quadrupeds, reptiles, and swimmers? If they are thought to be completely consumed by that immense conflagration because the renewed world will accept nothing mortal, how can it be true that no nature can perish?

Especially since it is written about the sea of great immensity in that remarkable change of things: "And the sea was no more." If he had said that human nature cannot perish, he might have been heard, not because God cannot dissolve it if He wills, but because the promise of our Lord cannot be invalid, as He Himself promised, saying: "But even the hairs of your head are all numbered" (Matthew 10:30). And in another place: "But not a hair of your head will perish" (Luke 21:18).
chunks.original_latin:
Requirendum autem ab isto est in
illa ultima mundi conflagratione, de qua beatus Petrus
apostolus dicit: In qua coeli magno impetu
transient: elementa vero calore solventur (II Petr. III,
10), quid sentient tunc futurum de quatuor mundi
elementorum natura? Si enim sic permanebunt ut
nunc sunt, quomodo est vera apostolica ista sententia? sin autem maxima ex parte immutabuntur, vel
peribunt, quomodo est vera ista definitio, quod nulla
possit perire natura? Certe quatuor vicissitudinum
tempora quibus annus ducitur ac reducitur, id est
veris, et aestatis, autumni, et hiemis, habent propriae
et distinctae qualitatem naturae suae: sed cum
fuerit coelum novum, et terra nova, et cessaverit
cursus iste solis et lunae ac siderum, quo nunc ad refectionem
et quietem mortalium dies noctesque sibi
continuatim succedunt, et idcirco etiam illae quatuor
vicissitudines temporum, quae solis cursu peraguntur,
sicut nunc sunt esse non poterunt, quomodo
non peribit eorum natura? Sed et hoc interrogandus est, quid credat tunc
futurum innovato coelo et terra per ignem, et in
 aliam qualitatem, quae immortalibus sanctorum corporibus
congruat, mirabiliter translatis. Quid, inquam,
tunc futurum credat de universa natura volucrum,
quadrupedum, reptilium, natatilium? Si
enim illa tam immensa conflagratione penitus consummanda
credenda sunt, quia nihil jam mortale
ille mundus innovatus recipiet, quomodo verum erit
nullam posse perire naturam? Maxime cum et de
ipso tantae immensitatis mari in illa tam mirabili
rerum commutatione scriptum sit: Et mare jam
non est; si ergo dixisset iste humanam naturam non
posse perire, utcunque audiendus esset, non quia
Deus non possit eam dissolvere, si velit: sed quia

Et capillus de capite vestro non peribit (Luc. XXI, 18).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
When he generally says that no nature can perish, he should consider what happened to rational beings, like the devil and his angels, through divine and severe judgment. They lost not only the will to do good but also the ability to desire the good. After he claims that no nature can perish, he immediately explains his point by saying that man has not lost his free will, which is his nature. He seems to argue, falsely and deceitfully, that since no nature can perish, man did not lose free will by sinning, because, according to him, man's free will is his nature.

However, according to the truth of the Catholic faith, we assert that the nature of the first man was created entirely good and endowed with a good will by a benevolent Creator. This aligns with Scripture, which states, "God created man upright" (Ecclesiastes 7:30). Yet, he needed divine grace to remain steadfast in his original state and to be supported by it.

Thus, the psalm reflects this perspective, saying: "In my prosperity I said, I shall never be moved" (Psalm 30:7-8). It immediately follows with a mention of his downfall, where he sorrowfully tells God: "You hid your face from me, and I was troubled." What was once abundant in good will and blessed freedom before sin came from God; to whom he also declares: "Lord, by your favor you made my mountain stand strong." But when God turned away and did not enlighten him with His presence, he became troubled, which was the consequence and punishment of sin.
chunks.original_latin:
Cum autem generaliter dicat, nullam
naturam posse perire, attendat quid etiam in
natura rationali, id est diaboli, et angelorum ejus
actum sit divino et terribili judicio, qui non
solum velle bonum, sed etiam posse velle ipsum
bonum perdiderunt. Postquam autem dixit nullam
naturam perire posse, statim qui haec omnia dixerit
ostendens subjungit: Nec liberam voluntatem hominem
perdidisse, id est naturam suam. Videlicet quasi
illa falsa et fallaci argumentatione sua, qua ait nullam
naturam posse perire, hoc nobis probaverit quod
homo peccando liberam voluntatem non amiserit;
 eo quod, secundum istum libera voluntas ejus, ipsa
sit natura ejus. Nos autem, juxta fidei catholicae
veritatem dicimus quod natura illius primi hominis
a bono Creatore ex toto bona, et bona voluntate
praedita, condita sit. Hoc est enim quia creavit Deus
hominem rectum (Eccle. VII, 30), sicut Scriptura dicit,
ita tamen ut non tantum naturali bono esset in eo
voluntas bona et libera, sed ut vere in eo quod conditus
fuerat stare posset, divinae gratiae indigeret, et
adjuvaretur. Unde illa vox ex persona ejus intelligitur

Deum: Avertisti faciem tuam a me, et factus sum conturbatus. Quod enim in abundantia erat, et bonae
 voluntatis, et beatae libertatis ante peccatum, ex Deo
illi erat; cui et dicit: Domine, in voluntate tua praestitisti
decori meo virtutem. Quod autem, avertente Deo
faciem suam ab illo, nec eum vultu suo illuminando,

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
This person praises the goodness of human nature without divine grace to such an extent that he argues people haven’t lost their free will, even by sinning, and claims that free will is part of their nature, clearly showing he's entangled in Pelagian error. He asserts that humans had free will by their nature both before and after sinning, and that free will is their nature. However, it wasn’t truly free unless it remained good and humbly submitted to God. But when it sinned by proudly disregarding God and breaking His command, it immediately became enslaved to sin. Because, as the Lord says: “Everyone who commits sin is a slave to sin” John 8:34, 36.

Thus, what was once free to do good, after that disastrous fall, could only be free to do evil by itself. It cannot rise from the deep evil of damnation to the freedom of good will unless liberated by Him who said: "If the Son sets you free, you will indeed be free."

This person, who thinks that humans did not lose their free will by sinning because they were created with a good and free will, and therefore naturally inclined to good will, should know that Almighty God created every rational creature, both humans and angels, with a good and upright will. So that as long as they maintained their order, humbly subjected to God and aided by His grace, they would remain in their dignity, which is both the goodness of nature and the gift of His grace. If, however, they proudly opposed the Creator and relied more on themselves, they would desert the order of submission and obedience, and by the just judgment of the Creator, they would immediately be deprived of the gift of grace, and their nature would be corrupted. As it is written in the psalm: “Man was in honor, but he did not understand; he has been compared to senseless animals and has become like them” Psalm 84:13, 21.
chunks.original_latin:
Iste autem qui, absque illo divinae gratiae adjumento,
in tantum in eo solum naturae bonum praedicat, ut
liberam voluntatem, nec peccando illum amisisse
contendat, ita ut etiam ipsam liberam voluntatem
naturam ejus esse dicat, manifeste Pelagiano errore
involvitur; asserens hominem sola natura, et ante
peccatum liberam voluntatem habuisse, et post peccatum
eamdem liberam voluntatem eum non amisisse,
et ipsam liberam voluntatem naturam ejus esse:
cum profecto non fuerit libera, nisi quandiu Deum pie
 subdita permansit bona; ubi autem, Deum contemnendo,
et mandatum ejus superbe transgrediendo,
peccavit, statim facta sit sub jugo peccati. Quia, sicut
ipse Dominus dicit: Omnis qui facit peccatum, servus
est peccati (Joan. VIII, 34, 36). Et ita quae ante
erat libera ad bonum, post illam miserabilem ruinam,
per seipsam non potuit esse libera, nisi ad malum. De quo profundissimo damnationis mala nullatenus
valet assurgere ad libertatem bonae voluntatis,
nisi illo liberante qui ait: Si vos filius liberaverit,
tunc vere liberi eritis. Iste autem, qui propterea eum putat non amisisse
peccando liberam voluntatem, quia cum ipsa bona
et libera voluntate est conditus; et ideo naturaliter

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Before sin, man was honored for the goodness of his nature created by God and for the grace bestowed upon him by God. Yet, he didn't recognize that this honor of divine goodness and grace came from God. He abandoned the Creator and relied on himself. Following the serpent's suggestion, he wanted to be like God, as if he had no Lord. Because of this, he was justly abandoned by the Creator and was completely changed for the worse, both in soul and body. The soul, having lost the freedom of righteousness and goodwill, was oppressed by the dominion of sin. It stopped seeking the things above and desired lowly things, like a brute or beast. The body, condemned to the condition of death, was destined to return to earth and dust, from which it was taken, according to the just judgment.

Look at how greatly human nature has fallen, entirely changed for the worse due to sin, having lost the freedom to do good and only free to desire evil, unless it is healed and restored by the grace of the one who came to seek and save what was lost, as stated in the Gospel of Luke, chapter nineteen, verse ten. As for angelic nature, it has been corrupted and horribly changed for the worse in the devil and his angels, having lost the free will to do good, so they cannot even desire it and have turned to evil malice never to be changed. Who can fully comprehend this, let alone explain it in words?

For the nature of the body is the same, whether healthy or sick. Yet, what is strong and flourishes in good health, when lost, turns for the worse and is weighed down and afflicted by the disease of illness. But those who do not believe that free will and the freedom to do good are the good of the human mind, but rather consider it to be the mind itself, seem to take occasion, as we have already said, from some words of Saint Augustine in his books on the Trinity.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Chapter ten, sections eleven and twelve explain that there's truly one single natural substance. This substance is both the mind and the knowledge by which the mind understands itself, as well as the will by which it desires and loves itself. This substance exists, knows itself through understanding, and desires itself through love. In essence, the mind, its knowledge, and its love are fundamentally one. However, it's argued that the knowledge and will the mind uses to know and love itself are not the mind of a person but are within the mind of the person. Therefore, this presents a clear error in the argument.

When discussing free will, where a person freely chooses between good or evil, it's not about the will by which the mind loves itself. Instead, it refers to the will that loves the highest good when correct—meaning God—or the lowest good when incorrect—meaning the world. This will, while sharing the same nature as the will by which the mind loves itself, greatly differs in affection: as much as the difference between loving oneself and loving God, and between loving oneself and loving the world. With that will, one loves oneself; with this will, one either loves God above oneself or the world below oneself. Yet, as mentioned, this will is singular in nature but becomes different in affection. It is consistent in self-love but varies in the love of good or evil things to which it is drawn or distracted.

Therefore, the natural will, which Blessed Augustine discusses, meaning the will by which the mind loves itself, has nothing to do with free will and free choice, which concern the desire for good or evil, but belongs solely to the mind and is attributed to it. This person unwisely or foolishly links freedom to it and calls it free will or free choice. Blessed Augustine does not make this claim at all, and it's far from anything he would suggest. For who does not know that this will of the mind, by which it wants and loves itself, is naturally common to all people and always exercises free choice in loving itself?

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
What mind exists in people, except perhaps those of the insane or foolish, whose will does not naturally desire for both itself and the mind it contains to exist, live, and remain unharmed? In this regard, the will of all minds is free. What could be freer than a will that loves the mind it resides in, loves to live, and loves not to perish? Isn't it redundant to call such a will free, when it can only love itself or the mind it belongs to? And why call it free choice, when choice requires different things to discern, judge, choose, or reject?

The will of the mind finds no diversity within itself; it always loves itself equally and is united with itself in natural peace and unity. Let's stop saying, when discussing human free will—by which either good things for salvation or harmful things are loved—that such a will of the mind is nature. Even though the mind's will loves itself and these things, it loves itself with an unchanging natural affection; it loves other things with a variable affection that changes when it turns to love either good or bad things.

If the mind's will, which loves other things instead of itself, either good or bad, making it happy or miserable, were the nature of man, it would be either only good or bad and could not change. Therefore, this will, this affection of human will according to the truth of God's Scriptures, is good and right as instilled by the good Creator in man when he was created. With God's grace, it remained good and right as long as he obediently followed the Creator. But because human nature was created changeable by the unchangeable Creator, and such an affection of the human mind is similarly changeable, it stood in good with the help of God's grace and fell into evil by God's hidden judgment, once that grace was abandoned.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
As it has often been said, what was once free for good, after losing that joyous freedom, fell under the miserable bondage of sin.

He adds, as if defining it: Freedom remained for humans after sin, but its strength and power were lost.

In these words, we need not dwell too long, because, as we've often mentioned, the one who possessed free will before sin, of good nature, and by the gift of grace aimed at the highest and eternal good—created to love, desire, seek, find, and contemplate—fell from such a great good by sinning and became a slave to sin.

As the Lord Himself testifies by saying: "Everyone who commits sin is a slave of sin." John, Chapter 8, Verse 34.

And the blessed Apostle Peter says: "For by whom a person is overcome, by him he is also brought into bondage." Second Peter, Chapter 2, Verse 19.

Thus, having lost the gift of grace, with the good of nature corrupted, tainted, and depraved, he fell miserably from such happiness, unable to return to that good to love and enjoy it, which he ought to have clung to, unless through the help of the most merciful reconciler and mediator, and the price of His blood, by which we are redeemed from such captivity.

So that we might receive our original freedom and be made friends from enemies. About this mediator it is written: "For there is one God and one mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus, who gave Himself as a ransom for all." First Timothy, Chapter 2, Verse 5.

And again: "When we were enemies, we were reconciled to God through the death of His Son." Romans, Chapter 5, Verse 10.

Therefore, whoever says, after that most unfortunate fall of transgression, by which, having lost original freedom, he became a slave to sin, became a slave to the one by whom he was also overcome, became an enemy of God, and needs one mediator and reconciler, through whom he might receive redemption from bondage and reconciliation to God.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
After such a profound and devastating ruin, anyone who claims that a person can freely desire, love, and attain true good without being redeemed, justified, reconciled, and reformed by the grace of the true mediator, contradicts the faith of the Church entirely. They go against the truth of the Gospel and apostolic doctrine, effectively nullifying the cross of Christ and His death.

Because if, after sin, a person could possess or regain true freedom of mind without the redemption from the cross and death of Christ, as the Apostle addressed those who believed they could be justified by other means: "Then Christ died for nothing" Galatians 2:21. This is the wisdom of the word that nullifies the cross of Christ, as mentioned in First Corinthians 1:17.

Indeed, if after another sin a person could have true freedom, there would be no need for redemption or a redeemer, rendering Christ's coming and death unnecessary. But the claim that a sinning person did not lose freedom, only the strength and power of it, is incorrect because it is not thought through properly.

The good of freedom was not partly retained and partly lost; rather, as they lost the strength and power of freedom, they lost freedom itself, meaning they cannot freely pursue the true good from which they fell. However, they remained free to do evil; just as they left the good with free will, they attached themselves to evil with it.

Thus, after condemnation, a person has free will, which inclines them towards evil by their own choice. They have free will to rise towards the good; but that ascent is not by their own power, but by the grace of God's mercy.

They have the free will to want good, live well, and adhere to God; but that they do so is not by their own strength, but by the grace of God's mercy. Just as someone who is gravely ill can be said to have the potential to recover health, they still need a remedy to actually heal.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Someone who has died can rise again and live, not by their own power, but by God's power. Similarly, human free will, once wounded or dead, can be healed, but not by its own strength—only by the grace of a merciful God. Therefore, it is right to advise everyone and to preach the word of God to all, because they have the ability to believe and turn to God. This is so that, when the word is given as an external warning and God awakens within, those who hear may come back to life. It is rightly said of such a person: 'Because he was dead and came back to life; was lost and is found.'

Regarding this potential of human nature, which is worthless without the generosity of divine grace, the blessed Augustine teaches in "On the Predestination of the Saints," chapter 5: 'The ability to have faith, like the ability to have love, is inherent in human nature, but having faith, like having love, is the grace of the faithful.' But when the Lord prepares some to believe and not others, we must discern what comes from His mercy and what from His judgment. For all the ways of the Lord are mercy and truth Psalms twenty-five, verse ten. However, His ways are unsearchable Romans eleven, verse thirty-three. Therefore, both the mercy with which He freely saves and the truth with which He justly judges are unsearchable.

After he vainly and deceptively claimed that freedom remained for man after sin, he added another conclusion, saying: 'Nature can always begin, but it cannot be perfected except by grace.' If he suggests that human nature, through its free will, can always begin to do good but perfects it only through God's grace—implying that the beginning of all goodness is attributed to man and its perfection to God—then such a view is entirely Pelagian and contrary to the truth of the Gospel and the Apostles. Even the Lord himself, to show that the beginning of our good comes from Him and not us, said: 'You did not choose me, but I chose you' John fifteen, verse sixteen.

The Apostle tells the faithful: The one who began a good work in you will complete it until the day of Christ Jesus Philippians chapter one, verse six. And again, he says: It has been granted to you on behalf of Christ not only to believe in him but also to suffer for him Philippians chapter one, verse twenty-nine.

The blessed John the Apostle says: Not because we have loved God, but because he first loved us and sent his Son as an atoning sacrifice for our sins First John chapter four, verse ten.

Again, the blessed Paul the Apostle says: Let us run with perseverance the race marked out for us, looking unto Jesus, the author and finisher of our faith Hebrews chapter twelve, verses one and two.

Therefore, if we truly wish to be Catholics, we must faithfully attribute everything to divine grace, from the beginning to the end of our good works. As clearly shown by the aforementioned testimonies of Holy Scripture, it is the Lord who chooses his saints, not the other way around. God begins and completes the good work in his faithful; believers receive both the beginning of faith and the end of martyrdom. He first loved his saints so that they could also love him. Our faith has the Lord Jesus as its author, initiating it in us, and as its finisher by perfecting it. Therefore, let us hold these truths faithfully, so that, grounded in true faith, we may be safe from heretical error. Or, if these words have another rightful and acceptable meaning, let the one who wrote them show it.

Chapter Five the following propositions are presented:

First, God's foreknowledge and predestination do not compel anyone. Second, God foresees even those things that will not happen, but predestines only those that will. Third, just as there is no cause of sin in God's foreknowledge and predestination, neither is there a cause of punishment or death. Fourth, God does not compel anyone to sin, nor does He compel anyone to live righteously. Fifth, if any cause precedes the will, that is, nature to think or do good or evil, it is not nature.

Of these five propositions, three have already been sufficiently discussed above, to the best of our ability, and need not be redundantly repeated: namely, the first, second, and fourth. Therefore, two remain, which are now addressed for the first time.

In the third proposition, it is stated: Just as there is no cause of sin in God's foreknowledge and predestination, neither is there a cause of punishment or death. To these words, we respond that if God's foreknowledge and predestination are not a cause of sin for anyone, which is absolutely true, then the same divine foreknowledge and predestination are neither unjust nor in any way blameworthy for knowing beforehand and predestining the wicked, who persist in their wickedness, to be condemned to eternal punishment. For, through His foreknowledge and predestination, Almighty God is not the cause of their sin, but a just avenger of sin, nor does He compel them to sin, but justly consigns them to suffer punishment.

Therefore, as the true and faithful God, He foresees the future sins of humans, as Scripture says: "Eternal God, who knows the hidden things, who knows everything before it happens" (Daniel, chapter thirteen, verse forty-two). Not that His foreknowledge compels anyone to sin, but that He justly orders or condemns the sinners with His eternal providence. By His predestination, by which He has decreed to punish the wicked, as already mentioned, He did not make them wicked, but justly determined that those persisting in their wickedness would not go unpunished.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
However, this person emphasizes and clarifies that, just as God, through His foreknowledge and predestination, is not responsible for anyone's sin or the punishment and death that come from sin, it is essential to understand this faithfully: Specifically, when a person sins, they become the cause of their own punishment and death. Yet, because Almighty God is a just judge, while the cause of punishment and death does not lie in His foreknowledge and predestination but in human actions, there is an eternal justice in that foreknowledge and predestination, which allows punishment and death for those who persist in wickedness. Therefore, according to this reasoning, as this person suggests, God's predestination, by which He imposes eternal punishments on the wicked, remains intact; for even though His predestination does not cause punishments, it upholds justice and the rightful judgment to inflict them.

The fifth proposition is this: If any cause precedes the will, that is, nature, in considering or doing good or evil, it is not nature. Here, he clearly speaks against the truth. For if no cause precedes a person's will in thinking about or doing good, then where does a person get a good will, or a pious inclination, to think or do something good? A person does not have a good will from themselves, as it is said: "Peace on earth to people of good will" (Luke 2:14). Nor do they have the ability to do good works from themselves, as it is written: "Glory, honor, and peace for everyone who does good" (Romans 2:10); but they receive these from Him, of whom the Apostle tells the faithful: "For it is God who works in you both to will and to act according to His good purpose" (Philippians 2:13). He precedes a person's will with His mercy, as the Psalmist says: "My God, His mercy will come to meet me" (Psalm 59:10). He inspires a person with the grace of right thinking, as the Apostle says: "Not that we are competent in ourselves to claim anything for ourselves, but our competence comes from God" (Second Corinthians 3:5).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
He himself is the reason for our goodwill: he inspires our good desires and actions. He is the source of mercy and grace for us, allowing us to think, desire, act, and complete things well. This isn't just for the present; even before the world's foundation, he predestined his chosen ones by his grace to be holy and blameless before him.

The Apostle testifies, saying: "He chose us in him before the foundation of the world, that we should be holy and blameless in his sight in love" Ephesians one, verse four.

With such a profound and noble cause, the source of all good things, whether in creation or rewarding his creatures, being our ultimate reason for goodwill by preceding us with his grace so we can desire and act well, how can anyone say there is no cause before our good will and actions?

Or, if there is a cause for these, claim that it is not nature, when Almighty God, who inspires our goodwill, is the highest and best nature above all.

So, anyone who does not believe that this highest and most effective cause, the same supreme and best nature, precedes our will to wish and act rightly, clearly resists the truth and is proven to be in error, like the Pelagians.

If this blessed cause did not precede human wills, there would be no predestination of the good, no redemption of the miserable, and no reward for pious deeds.

However, for thinking or doing evil, let it not be that this highest and best cause precedes our will! Instead, it is preceded by a deficient cause, not an efficient one, which is the abandonment of the highest good and the desire for something lesser, when the soul turns away from the love of God and yearns for lower things.

Thus, the will of fallen human nature becomes evil, having no other cause for being evil except, as mentioned, the departure from the highest good.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The lack of will led angels to become bad by abandoning God, and in a similar way, it led humans astray by disobeying Him. However, this absence isn't a part of nature; it's about either humans or angels turning away from the Creator and focusing on themselves or even the lowest creatures. This is the root of all bad intentions, corrupt desires, and actions. While God isn't the source of our bad intentions or any existing nature, it's the inclination of rational creatures lacking love for the Creator that causes this. Yet, He is still the judge and avenger of our thoughts, and the eternal decider of His just judgment and retribution. This is something that this person tries to dismiss with various twists and arguments.

Regarding his repeated claim that the will itself is nature, we've already noted that he misinterpreted this idea from Saint Augustine's words. When Augustine talks about the will of the human mind, which loves itself, it's always good in loving its own nature and can't be otherwise. This person erroneously applies this to the will in the context of free will. As we've mentioned, the will of the mind is different when it naturally loves itself, when it loves God with the help of grace, or when, corrupted by its own vice, it loves the world. It's not different in nature, but in the diversity of its affections. Therefore, it can be both good and bad, depending on what it loves, either well or poorly.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
CHAPTER 6. In this chapter, three main points are defined:

First, no sin and its punishment come from anywhere but a person’s own misuse of free will. Second, it's extremely foolish to doubt that human will aligns with nature. Third, there's no doubt that it is a rational substance.

Why these definitions were made and what they aim to achieve isn't entirely clear. Perhaps the main intention is to defend free will as natural, which aligns with Pelagian views, or to challenge the predestination in God’s just judgment, which reflects Ciceronian ideas. Cicero, as mentioned by blessed Augustine in his "City of God," particularly in Book Five, Chapter Nine, tried to nullify divine providence so much that he denied not only predestination but also God's foreknowledge, supposedly defending human free will with this logic. This led his listeners to become sacrilegious, believing they were so free by their will that they were not subject to divine providence or predestination, essentially denying God. This challenges what is supremely God's—His foreknowledge of all future events and the predestination of His plans. To deny this is to imply that God is not truly God.

For how can He truly be God if He has no foreknowledge of future events? We must be cautious and avoid this perspective, lest in trying to assert human freedom, we become sacrilegious. It is part of our faith to believe in the just and complete nature of God's predestination. To deny it is against the faith and indeed sacrilegious.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
As we mentioned earlier, the main goal of this discussion is to either defend free will as it naturally occurs or to partially refute the idea of predestination by God's justice. He might also use these three arguments to support free will.

When he says that no sin and its punishment come from anywhere but the person's own will, through the misuse of free will, it holds true because sin is committed by the person's own choice. Consequently, the punishment, which includes death, misery, and suffering, follows the sin.

However, there's a significant difference between sin and its punishment: the sin is committed solely by the individual. But the punishment for sin is both deserved by the person and justly administered by God through His judgment.

Thus, this argument does not conclusively prove what he intends, which is that no punishment for sin, no misery, or suffering imposed on sinners comes from God. Therefore, the eternal punishment of the wicked could not have been predestined by God: because, just as sin is not from Him, neither is the punishment.

As we have shown earlier, Scripture clearly challenges this error: Good and evil, life and death, poverty and prosperity come from God. Certainly not the evils that people commit by sinning and acting unjustly, for which God is not the author at all. But those that are inflicted upon people by God's just judgment because of sins, such as famine, slaughter, hostilities, devastations, and other hardships and calamities.

The prophet Amos also says: If there is evil in the city, has not the Lord done it? And the Lord Himself says through the prophet Isaiah: I am the Lord, who makes peace and creates evil.

From which He also threatens certain evils, saying: I will bring upon them disaster, the year of their punishment. And again: I will heap disasters upon them and spend my arrows against them.

All these things are said to be created by God, not by forming any nature, but by decreeing, instituting, and inflicting them through His just judgment.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
So, how should we properly distinguish and understand the idea that God did not create death, as stated in Wisdom 1:13? Yet, death is from God, as mentioned in Ecclesiasticus 11:14.

Blessed Augustine explains this clearly by saying:

It's true that it's foolish to doubt that human will is according to nature. The will of the rational soul is indeed according to nature and inherent in the nature of the rational soul itself.

However, as has often been stated, we must understand this natural will differently when it focuses on and loves itself, which is naturally good. And differently when it either piously loves the Lord or wrongly loves the world, referring to things it loves either above or below itself.

The will is not related to its own mind when naturally present; but when related to external things, it can be good or bad, not by nature, but by affection: either by rightly loving higher things, which bring blessing, or by wrongly desiring lower things, which bring corruption.

In this context, it is not just nature but either virtue or vice of nature, virtue from divine grace, vice from the corruption of its own will. This is the free will of the human mind when a person is inclined to desire one thing or another.

This inclination is not outside nature, as it is moved by spontaneous will in either direction, nor is it just nature. To be moved towards good, it is stirred by divine grace; towards evil, it is corrupted by its own desire.

We felt it was necessary to briefly and diligently explain this here, so it can be understood how absurdly and deceitfully one might claim the natural freedom of choice alone, due to the will of the human mind, which naturally loves itself.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
He doesn't pay attention, or perhaps pretends not to, to the fact that this kind of will is irrelevant when discussing free will. Instead, free will refers to a will that moves differently, with a unique inclination, either towards loving good or seeking evil, whether aided by divine grace or corrupted by its own fault.

Therefore, it's clear that his stubborn and contentious effort to naturally defend free will is ultimately vain and ineffective. Although free will exists within human nature and the human mind naturally has the ability to desire good, live rightly, and be happy, it doesn't have the power to actually achieve these from its own strength, but only through the generosity of divine grace.

However, he tries to constrain us with such reasoning, so that we either partially deny divine predestination or, by fully affirming it, seem to undermine free will, similar to Cicero's argument. Cicero attacked and denied divine foreknowledge, claiming that if God's foreknowledge truly existed, then humans couldn't have free will. Conversely, if humans had free will, then there couldn't be divine foreknowledge.

Thus, that most impious and detestable blasphemer of God chose to defend human free will at all costs and deny God's foreknowledge. Anyone who carefully examines this can easily see how much he seems to follow and imitate him in this argument. Because whoever denies God's foreknowledge also denies God's predestination, which cannot exist without foreknowledge.

Therefore, to more clearly and lucidly understand how both divine predestination and human free will truly coexist without destroying one another, we find it absolutely necessary and beneficial to include here the very words of Saint Augustine, with which he defends both against Cicero's impious argument and gently teaches that both should be upheld. (Augustine, The City of God, Book Five, Chapter Nine).

CHAPTER 7. In this chapter, he offers a specific definition.

Free will should be viewed as one of God's intermediate gifts, allowing the possibility of sin. It's important to clarify that, although he describes free will as a gift from God, he refers to it in a natural sense, similar to the Pelagians.

The Church's faith clearly distinguishes between natural gifts and gifts of grace. For instance, God naturally endowed humans with a rational and intellectual mind, which includes memory, understanding, and will. He also naturally gave the human body its substance, form, appearance, health, and the senses of sight, hearing, smell, taste, and touch, all animated by the soul. These are clearly natural gifts, implanted by God from the beginning.

However, gifts like faith, hope, charity, piety, good will, and the ability to do good works are gifts of grace from the Holy Spirit, as the Apostle mentions: "All these are the work of one and the same Spirit, and he distributes them to each one, just as he determines" First Corinthians 12:11.

He also explains that the Psalm states, "When he ascended on high, he took many captives and gave gifts to his people" Ephesians 4:8; Psalm 68:18. Therefore, the Catholic faith, the true faith, considers free will a gift of grace.

Although God originally implanted it in humans, making them good and with good will, it still requires the Creator's grace to maintain its original goodness. Weakened, damaged, and corrupted by the first sin, it cannot reach the eternal and supreme good for which humans were created unless healed, restored, enlightened, and freed by God's grace. It can only truly be free if made free by God's grace through Him who says: "So if the Son sets you free, you will be free indeed" John.

In the Gospel of John, chapter 8, verse 36, it states: "So that what the Apostle says may happen in us: where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is freedom," as echoed in Second Corinthians, chapter 3, verse 17. Therefore, as we've mentioned, it's a false and Pelagian error to believe that free will, lost due to Adam's sin, can be free in any way other than through the grace of Christ.

The claim that free will, which was good and upright and elevated by a good will to the heavenly and divine, as it was created in the first man, could be without sin and able not to sin if he wished, is considered not among the highest, but among the average gifts of God, is very far from the truth. Because, as we have said, the good of free will in that first man was so great that it's not found in any of the saints in this present life. In them, although free will is now liberated and healed by the grace of Christ, their condition is such that as long as they live mortally, they can't be without sin. And even though they greatly wish and desire not to sin, they still can't avoid sinning.

Hence, they need to pray daily and sincerely say to the heavenly Father: "Forgive us our debts, as we also forgive our debtors." Therefore, it wasn't an average gift, but the highest gift, according to the way man lived in paradise then, free from sin, and having the freedom not to sin by his own will, as long as he piously subjected himself to be guided and assisted by God. Although he was still to be perfected for the better, if he had remained obedient to God, he would have received such strength that he couldn't sin anymore.

But that such a free will in that first man could sin was caused by the abandonment of God and reliance on himself. While neglecting to be under God and wanting to be in his own power, he lost the gift of divine grace, lost the good of nature, and found himself under the condemnation of misery.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
CHAPTER EIGHT. In this chapter, he presents these definitions.

One. The essential trinity within a person comprises essence, will, and knowledge.

Two. There is no distinction between being and willing, nor between willing and knowing. These three form one nature, and the entire nature of the soul is will.

Three. Free will is inherent to humans. Their ability to choose freely is a gift from the Creator.

Four. Just as the physical body could die because it wasn't yet perfect, or spiritual, free will, being still physical and mortal, could sin because it wasn't yet perfected. This perfection of freedom would be achieved after obeying the command, when the desire to sin would be completely removed.

Five. This ability is given only to humans, not to animals.

Six. There is a difference between human free will and its essence. Nature is in rational will, but free will is in its freedom, whether in the movement of naturally free will or in the gift of intelligence.

Seven. These three—freedom, movement, and intelligence—together compose free will. Just as the essence in which it exists is threefold: existing, willing, and knowing, so it is made threefold: free, moving, intelligent.

Therefore, he says that the essential trinity of the inner person is found in essence, will, and knowledge, partly drawing from Saint Augustine's discussions in the books on the Trinity and partly from his own ideas.

For the blessed Augustine, in his discussions about the holy and supreme Trinity, particularly in Book Nine, Chapter Two, and Book Fifteen, Chapter Seven, explores the human mind created in the image and likeness of God. He draws parallels with God so that through this image of the trinity in the human mind, we might be inspired to contemplate the Trinity, which is God.

He says, I say, these three things—being, knowing, and willing—are present in the human mind in such a way that they are distinctly three yet one in substance. This becomes clear when the mind, which naturally exists, naturally knows itself and naturally wills, meaning it loves itself, with its knowledge and will directed solely at itself. Even though these three—being, knowing oneself, and willing oneself—are distinctly understood to exist in the mind, the very being is the nature, or essence, of the mind, and it naturally knows and wills itself.

The mind is whole, and just as it fully exists, it also fully knows and fully wills and loves itself. Therefore, the greatness of its essence is matched by its knowledge and will. From this comparison, the blessed teacher encourages us to rise from the likeness of our mind to contemplate the true Trinity, which is God: just as these three—being, knowing oneself, and willing oneself—are found in the human mind, distinctly recognized yet substantially and naturally one.

As great as the mind is, so is its knowledge and love of itself, because it fully knows and loves itself. Thus, from this image and likeness of God, let us elevate our understanding to the Trinity of the Lord and recognize in the blessed and highest Trinity, distinctly and properly, the three persons: the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit. These three are essentially and naturally one and equal, so that as great as the Father is, the Son and the Holy Spirit are also recognized to be. In this way, as if through a mirror and in the enigma of our mind, let us learn to understand the holy Trinity, distinct in persons, united in substance, and equal in nature and power.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Upon reading this enlightening text, which was so usefully and beneficially written to strengthen our faith, he wasn't content with the guidance and piety of the holy teacher, choosing to push beyond the boundaries set by him. Instead, he added his own idea that the three things contemplated in the human mind represent a substantial Trinity.

However, a substantial and substantive Trinity, meaning one that exists tangibly in persons, can only be found in the one God. Therefore, the same teacher carefully warns against errors in such matters, teaching in the same books that these three are not the man himself, but are of the man or within the man.

Conversely, in the holy Trinity, the three things distinctly recognized should in no way be said or considered as parts of one God, but rather as truly one God. Indeed, we do not say the Trinity exists in God, but that the Trinity itself is God.

As the holy teacher himself states in Book Fifteen of "On the Trinity," chapter Six: "Those three things are in the mind or are the mind itself; thus, these three are not the man, but they belong to the man or are within the man."

Even if the body is removed, if the soul alone thinks something, its mind is like its head, eye, or face, but these should not be thought of as bodies. Therefore, it is not the soul, but what excels in the soul that is called the mind.

Can we say that the Trinity is in God in such a way that it is something of God, yet it is not God itself? After incorrectly stating that the substantial Trinity is contained in the essence, will, and knowledge of the mind, he further adds something more problematic by claiming about the human mind itself: "Neither is being and willing different for it, nor is willing and knowing different; and the whole nature of the soul is will; but these three are one nature."

On the contrary, faith firmly holds that there is no creature, neither angelic nor human, of such a simple nature or essence, that its existence is the same as its understanding, because it can exist without understanding. Neither is its existence the same as its willing, because it can exist without willing. Nor is its existence the same as its knowing, because it can exist without knowing.

However, this person argues the opposite, claiming that for the mind, being and willing are not different; nor are willing and knowing different. If this is accepted, what's being asserted with this new and unheard-of presumption, except that just as God has a simple nature, the human mind is also believed to be of a simple nature?

For if being for the human mind is the same as willing, then clearly, essence is not different from will; essence itself is will, and will itself is essence. Similarly, if for the human mind, willing is not different from knowing, then will is not different from essence; will itself is knowledge, and knowledge itself is will.

From this incredible reasoning, it follows that, as this person also claims, the mind itself, just as it is entirely essence, is also entirely will and entirely knowledge. And just as it is truly believed about God that it is rightfully said of Him alone that what He has, He is; for He has justice, but He Himself is justice; He has wisdom, but He Himself is wisdom; He has goodness, but He Himself is goodness. It follows, I say, that it may also be said similarly of the human mind: that what it has, it is; namely, because it has will, but it is will itself; it has knowledge, but it is knowledge itself; so that, just as we believe about God, there is nothing different between being and having for Him.

Behold, therefore, with this author, or rather deceiver, against all truth of faith, against the authority of Holy Scripture, against the purity of the teachings of the Fathers, and indeed against all divine and human reason, a creature has been invented, that is, the human mind, which is of a simple nature, and hence unchangeable, just as God is of a simple and unchangeable nature. Whereas, on the contrary, truth proclaims, and Saint Augustine himself, as we have shown above, clearly affirms that every creature is complex, and in no way truly simple; and again he says: nothing changeable is simple, but every creature is changeable.

scire, ergo non est ibi aliud voluntas et aliud essentia;

veraciter dicatur quia quod habet, hoc est; habet
enim justitiam, sed ipse justitia est; habet sapientiam,
sed ipse sapientia est; habet bonitatem, sed
ipse bonitas est; sequitur, inquam, ut et de humana
mente similiter dicatur: quia quod habet, hoc est:
videlicet quia habet voluntatem, sed ipsa est voluntas;

auctoritatem, contra paternorum dogmatum sinceritatem,

rationem, inventa est creatura, id est mens humana,
quae sit naturae simplicis, ac per hoc incommutabilis,
sicut Deus naturae simplicis et incommutabilis, est. Cum e contrario veritas clamet, et ipse sanctus Augustinus,
sicut supra ostendimus, manifeste affirmet
quia omnis creatura multiplex, nullo autem modo
vere simplex; et iterum dicat: nihil mutabile simplex,
omnis autem creatura mutabilis.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Let him choose one of two options: if the nature of the mind, as he claims, is simple, then it cannot change. Because, as the teacher himself rightly says, nothing changeable is simple.

However, if the nature of the mind, like all creatures, is truly changeable, then it is not simple. It's unthinkable that blessed Augustine, who affirms that every creature is changeable and complex, would have thought or written such things about the nature of the human mind, suggesting it is not only similar but also equal to God, if he had claimed it was unchangeable and simple! Anyone who wants to and is able to should read diligently and examine attentively his statements on this matter in the books on the Trinity, and they will find that he said the three things found in the human mind, which have often been discussed, are one because of the unity of the substance of the mind in which they reside, and that there is one mind and one substance.

They will find that he said these things are substantially present in the mind, and that the mind is a substance, self-awareness is a substance, and self-will is a substance. They will also find that he said the whole mind knows itself, wants itself, or loves itself; yet nowhere will they find that he said the mind itself is knowledge or the mind itself is will.

It has already been shown from his words that knowledge is one thing, by which the mind knows itself, and will is another, by which the mind loves itself. So, why, when the whole mind knows itself, did he not say that the mind itself is knowledge? And when the whole mind wills itself, did he not say that the mind itself is will? Except because the mind itself is a creature and not simple; and being, knowing, and willing are different for it.

But if someone, or he who said this, argues: how then are these three one, one mind, one substance, if there is something different there, let him acknowledge that these three can substantially be called one because they are in one substance. And potentially different, because, as the teacher himself shows, in the mind, memory can be one thing, intelligence another, and will another.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
In contrast, within the divine Trinity, we can say "one, and another, and another," but we can't say "one thing, and another thing, and another thing" because of its perfect unity and simple nature.

Therefore, there is supreme simplicity where one thing and another can never be found.

There was an ancient debater who discussed the incorporeal nature of the soul and said:

"And when the soul wills, if it wills completely, it is entirely will," indicating that the soul, in a certain way, can be called entirely will when it wills completely, because it wills not outside itself, but within itself and with itself.

Thus, he did not define it as will absolutely, but conditionally, saying, "if it wills completely, it is entirely will."

From this, we should understand, and each person should recognize in themselves, that if it does not will completely, it is not entirely will.

It is possible to will one thing and not will the same thing at the same time, which the whole does not will at all.

Consequently, due to this changeable and variable movement of will, the nature of the soul should not be said to be entirely will in an absolute manner, because it is not, neither when it wills partially nor when it completely stops willing what it had willed, always having the natural ability to will.

However, while its nature and substance remain constant, the willing of that same thing may stay the same, change, or cease, according to what it desires or rejects.

Therefore, let this person stop saying that the entire nature of the soul is will, that is, that the soul itself is will.

For it is not the nature of a simple being, like God, that what it is to be is the same as to will, nor is its being different from having will.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Therefore, let's cast aside this impious and profane opinion from the ears of the faithful. Those who admire and willingly listen to such a teacher should remember they are Christians. They should remember to keep the Catholic faith and the true understanding of God, whole and unbroken. Let them remember to faithfully guard the teachings passed down from their fathers and to avoid irreverent assumptions with all devotion, as the Apostle strongly advises, saying, "O Timothy, guard what has been entrusted to you, avoiding profane and idle babble and contradictions of what is falsely called knowledge, which some have professed and thus have strayed concerning the faith" (First Timothy six, twenty to twenty-one).

Let's learn not to have itching ears, eager and craving for meaningless and old wives' tales. About this harm, the Apostle says, "For the time will come when people will not put up with sound doctrine. Instead, to suit their own desires, they will gather around them a great number of teachers to say what their itching ears want to hear. They will turn their ears away from the truth and turn aside to myths" (Second Timothy four, three to four).

What else is left for those who say or accept such things, equating the human mind with God, as if it were of a simple nature like God? Unless, as the worst ancient heretics said, they blaspheme by claiming that God and the soul are of the same nature.

He also mentions that free will is the nature of humans, along with their free movement and the power to make choices, which is the Creator's gift. However, as we've already said, and as the truth clearly shows, we do not say that humans are will, but that will belongs to humans; it's clear that being and willing are different for a person. Hence, it is not that man is will, but that will is a human attribute.

Nevertheless, he shows that, through the Pelagian error, he considers free will to be solely a human nature and not a gift of grace, referring to the free movement and power of the human will.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
This clearly shows that human will not only has the natural freedom to choose between good and evil, but also the power to act on those choices.

However, in contrast, the Catholic faith asserts, against all such misconceptions, that free will, although naturally right and complete in humans before sin, has been corrupted and even lost due to sin. It has no movement, meaning no desire for good will or the power to fulfill it, except through hidden grace, given and inspired by the one about whom the Apostle most truly says:

"For it is God who works in you both to will and to do for His good pleasure" Philippians 2:13.

As we mentioned before, it is naturally instilled by the Creator that one can will and be able to do what is good; however, the ability to will and do this does not come from oneself, but from the one who works in the hearts of the faithful to will and perform according to His good will.

Hence comes the most faithful ecclesiastical definition, which the blessed Pope Celestine includes in his Decrees, saying: And again:

From this apostolic and ecclesiastical definition, it is clear that free will in humans cannot desire or perform good unless liberated by the grace of Christ. However, it remains free to do evil, because when one sins, it is not compelled by any necessity but is corrupted by one's own will.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
He goes on to say that just as a physical body could die because it wasn't yet perfect—that is, not yet spiritual—similarly, free will, still in a natural and mortal state, could sin because it wasn't yet perfect. This perfection of freedom would be achieved after obeying the commandment, when the will to sin would be removed.

What else can be said about the physical and spiritual body except what the Apostle teaches, saying: "If there is a natural body, there is also a spiritual body," as it is written: "The first man Adam became a living being; the last Adam became a life-giving spirit" (First Corinthians 15:44-45).

Earlier, when discussing the resurrection of the dead, he said: "It is sown a natural body, it is raised a spiritual body" (First Corinthians 15:44).

In these words, how is the natural body distinguished from the spiritual body, except that the natural body is given life only in a mortal and corruptible way by the soul? Such was the body of Adam even before sin; because, although it wasn't yet destined for death and corruption, it could still be corrupted and die due to sin: which indeed happened to him and continues to happen to all his descendants as a just judgment and punishment from Him who said: "Until you return to the ground, for from it you were taken; for you are dust, and to dust you shall return."

A spiritual body, however, is not called such because it ceases to be a body and becomes a spirit. Although it is spiritual, it is still truly called a body by the Apostle. It will be a spiritual body when it is given life by the spirit in an immortal and incorruptible way. This is the kind shown by the last Adam, that is, the Lord Jesus Christ, in the resurrection. Through this, He transformed the mortal body He had taken on into immortality and incorruption, and through this same grace of incorruptibility, He will manifest it in His saints on the last day.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
As the Apostle states, "This perishable body must put on the imperishable, and this mortal body must put on immortality, so that what is mortal may be swallowed up by life." And then the prophecy will be fulfilled: "Death is swallowed up in victory." First Corinthians 15:53-54. Thus, the body that is now a natural one, sown in death, will be raised as a spiritual body. First Corinthians 15:44. It will no longer need sustenance from food, won't be troubled or dissolved by death, but will be given life by the spirit with eternal immortality.

This was also intended for Adam's future body, had death not intervened, with God rewarding his obedience, had he not sinned. Therefore, Adam's body remained natural, not yet transformed into the immortality that would have been his if he had stayed obedient to God. So, if he hadn't sinned, he wouldn't have died, but because he sinned, he could die. It's clear he could die because he hadn't been granted immortality yet.

However, Adam still had a natural will, driven by human desires, not yet living or understanding according to God's spirit. So, his inner self wasn't yet spiritual, but still natural, perceiving things in a natural, not spiritual, way. The Apostle explains this, saying, "The natural man does not accept the things that belong to the Spirit of God." First Corinthians 2:14.

The Apostle doesn't show this when he speaks of the great mystery in Christ and the Church, which was prophesied by Adam when, filled with the divine Spirit, he said, "For this reason, a man will leave his father and mother and be united to his wife, and the two will become one flesh." Ephesians 5:31.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The Apostle elaborates further with these words: Ephesians chapter five, verse thirty-two: "This is a great mystery: But I am speaking about Christ and the Church." How, then, was his will not spiritual for living rightly, aided and enlightened by the Spirit, elevated by prophetic grace? Even a spiritual will could fall into sin if it succumbed to greater temptation. The same Apostle shows that even the spiritual can be tempted, as he says: Galatians chapter six, verse one: "Brothers, if someone is caught in a sin, you who are spiritual should restore him gently, considering yourself, lest you also be tempted."

So, even a spiritual man’s will could be tempted and overcome. However, if he achieved perfect happiness where he could no longer sin, the desire to sin wouldn't be taken from him; rather, the good will he possessed would be perfected to the point it couldn't turn to evil. We can understand the threefold state of human will: the first man was created with such a good will that he could choose not to sin. But now, even holy men, born from his flawed lineage, cannot avoid sinning, even if they wish. Therefore, they earnestly say to God every day: Matthew chapter six, verse twelve: "Forgive us our debts."

In the happiness promised to them, they will be strengthened with such virtue that they will no longer be capable of sinning, just as they will be clothed with the grace of incorruption, making them incapable of death. It's curious why he wanted to add that this movement, free will, is granted to no animals except humans, since it's evident that where there is no rational nature, as in brute and irrational beasts, no rational will exists to seek good or evil. They are led by mere natural and unthinking instincts.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Therefore, whatever actions they perform cannot be labeled as good or bad, nor as vices or virtues. Unless, perhaps, we compare the movement of human free will to the appetite of irrational animals, because just as that irrational appetite is driven by natural impulse, so human free will is guided by the instinct of its nature to whatever it desires.

How contrary this is to the truth has already been shown many times before. This speaker has presumed to deceive the senses and ears of his listeners so much that he dared to, like some creator and shaper of lies, craft a new definition of free will, presenting it as if it were something marvelous.

He then added and said: Let there be such a difference between human free will and its essence, that its nature is in rational will, while true free will lies in its freedom, either in the movement of naturally free will, or in the gift of intelligence. Behold the kind of free will he teaches: certainly Pelagian, not Christian!

Its nature is rational will, but its effect lies in its natural freedom of will, and it possesses freedom, movement, and the gift of intelligence solely from or in natural will. However, we, according to the truth of faith, recognize free will in humans in such a way that, although it is naturally implanted in the rational mind by God, good, and rightly bestowed in the first condition;

Yet, through the merit of sin, it is corrupted and stripped of natural virtue, and can have no freedom for true good, no movement of goodwill, no light of intelligence, unless it is renewed by the grace of Him who said: "If the Son sets you free, you will be free indeed" John 8:36; And who, by his inspiration, moves the hearts of those he wills to faith, as the prophet says: "And I will shake all nations, and the Desired of all nations will come" Haggai 2:8: And to whom we daily pray, saying: "Give me understanding, that I may learn your commandments" Psalm 119:73.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
And again: Give me understanding, and I will live. (Psalm 119:144) For this understanding, we thank the giver by saying: I will bless the Lord, who has given me understanding. (Psalm 16:7)

This is truly free will: not a gift of nature, as suggested by this proponent of Pelagian error, but a gift of grace; and it is free because it is liberated by the grace of Christ. This person, after mentioning three things—freedom of choice, movement, and understanding—which he claims all depend solely on the power of nature, goes on to present a new image of free will, as if it were composed of three parts, and says:

These three, that is, freedom, movement, and understanding, together make up free will: just as the substance in which it exists is threefold: For it exists, wants, and knows; so too, it becomes threefold, that is, free, moving, understanding.

He says all this to assert that free will consists solely in these, that is, in nature itself, and in what is inherent in nature, suggesting that, just as the human mind naturally possesses three things—being, willing, knowing— since these two, will and knowledge, are understood only of themselves and not of anything else, so free will, proceeding from the mind and residing within it, derives freedom, movement, and understanding from it alone; so that by this kind of will, a person is naturally free, moving, and understanding.

He does not say that the human mind possesses these three things within itself, but that it is threefold in simple nature. And similarly, who has ever heard of such a contentious heresy claiming that free will is threefold?

He works to confine and surround free will with certain limits, concluding it entirely within the power of human nature, completely excluding God's grace from it. So what should be said to him, to whom so many responses have already been given on this matter?

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Unless someone wants to be, or appear to be, a Christian, they should reject this insane, deadly error. The more cleverly they seem to follow and assert it, the more they are unhappily trapped and blinded by the devil.

By setting aside the false and deceptive arguments of human inventions, they should humbly submit themselves entirely to the truth of Holy Scripture, the authority of the Church Fathers, and the simplicity of faith. Otherwise, while they trust in their own freedom and distance themselves from Christ, they truly deserve to be alienated from Christ.

For cursed is the person who trusts in humans and makes flesh their strength, and whose heart turns away from the Lord. Jeremiah 17:5. But blessed is the person who trusts in the Lord, and the Lord will be their confidence. Jeremiah 17:7.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
CHAPTER 9. In this chapter, he offers the following definitions:

1. Foreknowledge and predestination are attributed to God by analogy with temporal things. 2. All predestination is foreknowledge.

So, when we consider temporal things, which change with the past, present, and future, they relate mostly to future events. This is because foreknowledge and predestination essentially concern the future: However, with God, nothing is past or future, as everything is eternally present in His knowledge. Thus, these terms are used about God more metaphorically than literally; as he has often stated, foreknowledge and predestination not only exist in God (which we also acknowledge), but are also God's very essence?

If his argument is so inconsistent that what he asserts initially, he later contradicts, why should we bother to refute him when he effectively refutes himself? But if his method of sophistical argument, which he exclusively follows, is such that what is claimed in one part is overturned in another, who wouldn't see how contemptible and utterly dismissible it is, where there is no solidity of truth, and such bold and shameless manipulation of falsehood?

Regarding his statement that all predestination is foreknowledge, it is partly true: because all predestination of future events involves foreknowledge, through which those future events are foreseen. However, if this implies that predestination does nothing more concerning future events than foreknowledge, it is clearly false: Foreknowledge merely foresees future events, while predestination also establishes, defines, and determines them. Therefore, the predestination of the wicked to eternal punishment not only foresaw but also, through just and eternal judgment, established and defined what they would endure.
