chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Chapter Ten he presents four definitions as follows:

First, it should be understood in contrast to the idea that God foresees or predestines sins, or the death or punishments of humans or angels. Second, every evil is a sin and its punishment, and these are nothing. Third, sin and its consequences, rooted in death and misery, are merely the corruptions of a complete and blessed life, with each opposing the other. Sin is opposed to integrity, death to life, and misery to happiness. These things exist, while those things do not exist at all. Fourth, every defect or deprivation of a perverse will, or sin, along with its culmination in death and eternal misery, are absolutely nothing; therefore, they can neither be foreseen nor predestined.

See how far this diabolical argument has been taken, so that someone who wishes to appear Christian, using pagan and diabolical arguments, undermines and destroys all faith in divine foreknowledge and predestination, through which He foreknew and predestined the wicked to be condemned, as much as it depends on him. Not only does he invalidate the just judgment of God and His eternal and unchangeable plan in their condemnation, but he also argues that sin and all punishment and damnation that followed sin are nothing. And therefore, because they are nothing, they could neither be foreseen nor predestined by God.

Thus, wherever the Holy Scriptures or the teachings of the Fathers mention that such things were foreseen and predestined, it should be understood oppositely, meaning they were not foreseen or predestined at all. What else is this but to openly declare madness? For who among the faithful ever dared to think or say that what truth has declared is not truth; what faith has taught is false; what all believers hold is nothing?

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Certainly, this person argues that sin, all punishment, misery, and calamity, whether temporary or eternal, are nothing because they lack their own essence to exist or subsist, unlike the substance of existence we see in earth, water, fire, plants, trees, and similar entities. Just as we know and believe that human souls and the spirits of both good and evil angels have the substance of existence and subsistence.

Therefore, with the audacity of diabolical presumption, he claims that God could only know, foresee, and predestine the substances of things. However, those things which are contrary and penal to these substances, because they do not have a substance of existence, cannot in any way be foreseen or predestined by God, and thus, they could not be known.

Therefore, he did not foresee the sin of the first man because sin does not have a substance of existence; nor did he foresee the punishment of sin, that is, death, misery, or eternal punishment because these similarly do not exist substantially in themselves.

And where is it that the faith firmly and immovably holds that Almighty God is truly all-knowing of all future events? Where is it that through his prophets, in the holy Scriptures, he foretells so many sins of men, so many punishments, and the calamities and miseries of sinners with his spirit?

Where also is it that his only begotten Son, who is the eternal Truth, foretells so many persecutions of his Church, so many upheavals of wars, pressures of labors and terrors, earthquakes, and even plagues and famines, foreseeing them and advising that they be endured most patiently by his followers?

Why has this impious person dared to utter such an open lie, indeed such unheard-of and wicked blasphemy, against the faith of the entire holy Church, against the truth of the heavenly Scriptures, and against the majesty of Almighty God with sacrilegious mouth and impious words?

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
How can we understand someone trying so hard to imitate and support the deceit of the devil by claiming, with deceitful lips and a sly tongue, that what God truthfully and certainly foretells and threatens the wicked with—eternal punishments—is nothing? Just like the serpent in the beginning, who tried to remove the fear of death that God warned about from the heart of man and entice him to sin, by saying, "You will not surely die" Genesis 3:4.

In the same way, this imitator of the serpent claims that the eternal torments God warns sinners about are nothing, removing healthy fear from the hearts of listeners and making them reckless in sinning. Therefore, we must hold with the most steadfast and unwavering faith that the all-powerful God foresees all future things, both good and evil, and not only foresaw the nature of all things before creating them but also anticipated whatever could be contrary and painful to those natures.

Not because these things exist substantially, but because they harm the substances He created in a punitive way. Scripture confirms this faith, saying: "Eternal God, who knows what is hidden, who knows all things before they happen" Daniel 13:42.

And the Lord Himself, in the Gospel, warns His followers about these things, saying: "I will show you whom to fear: Fear Him who, after He has killed, has the power to cast into hell; yes, I tell you, fear Him" Luke 12:5.

However, this person contradicts by saying that all the penalties of eternal punishments, both for humans and evil angels, which are threatened and prepared, are absolutely nothing. But if the eternal punishments of wicked angels and the worst humans were not predestined, what does the just judge and condemner say He will declare in that judgment: "Depart from me, you cursed, into the eternal fire prepared for the devil and his angels" Matthew 25:41?

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
If indeed it is ready and predestined for the condemned and those angels to be condemned, is it not also prepared or predestined for the wicked, who are to be punished in the same eternal fire? However, the blessed Enoch, the most ancient patriarch, who walked with God and was no longer seen because the Lord took him, prophesied about the punishments and eternal torments predestined for the wicked even before the flood. The blessed Jude, the apostle, testifies when speaking of the very wicked heretics who began to attack the Church of God in the times of the apostles, saying: "Enoch, the seventh from Adam, also prophesied about these men, saying: Behold, the Lord comes with thousands of his holy ones to execute judgment upon all and to convict all the ungodly of all their ungodly deeds which they have done in an ungodly way, and of all the harsh things which ungodly sinners have spoken against him" Jude 14, 15.

This judgment of condemnation for the ungodly, wicked, and blasphemous people, so marvelously predicted from the beginning of the world and to be truly fulfilled at the end of the world, is also announced by the blessed Peter, the apostle, in these words, saying: "But there were also false prophets among the people, just as there will be false teachers among you, who will secretly introduce destructive heresies and even deny the Master who bought them, bringing swift destruction upon themselves" Second Peter 2:1. Of whom he adds a little later: "Their condemnation has long been hanging over them, and their destruction has not been sleeping" Second Peter 2:3.

So if we seek the eternal predestination of this judgment with God, let us listen carefully to what he says: "Their condemnation has long been hanging over them," meaning they are not judged for the first time now; nor will it be the first time when they depart from the body to eternal punishment. But this judgment of their condemnation has long been decreed, long predestined from eternity, and it has long been prepared for them without ceasing.

judicium jam olim non cessat, et perditio eorum non
dormitat (Ibid., 3). Si ergo quaerimus istius judicii
aeternam apud Deum praedestinationem, audiamus
vigilanter quod ait: Quibus jam olim judicium
non cessat, id est, non nunc primum judicantur;
nec tunc primum quando de corpore exient ad supplicium
sempiternum. Sed hoc judicium damnationis
eorum jam olim est decretum, jam olim ex aeternitate
praedestinatum; et jam olim eis praeparari non
 cessat.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
When we wonder what punishment awaits them under such judgment, it says, "Their destruction does not slumber," and about the same wicked and blasphemous people, the same apostle says: "These are springs without water and mists driven by a storm, for whom the gloom of darkness is reserved." Two Peter, chapter two, verse seventeen.

How is it reserved for them unless it was prepared for them from the beginning and will be given at the end? The blessed apostle Jude confirms this with similar words, saying: "These are clouds without water, blown by the wind; autumn trees, twice dead, uprooted; wild waves of the sea foaming up their shame; wandering stars, for whom the storm of darkness is reserved forever." Jude, verses twelve and thirteen.

Against these dreadful, terrible things that Almighty God threatens to the wicked and sinners through His prophets and apostles, this person claims: "All evil, sin, and its punishment do not exist." And again, he asserts: "The integrity of nature, life, and happiness exist. On the contrary, however, sin, death, and misery do not exist at all."

He further added: "Every defect or absence of perverse will, or sin, and its end, death and misery of eternal punishments, is entirely nothing: and therefore neither foreseen by God nor predestined." Of all these things, if anything should be said individually, faith clearly knows that the evil which is contrary to good, like vice to virtue, darkness to light, weakness to health, does not exist substantially. Because, as already mentioned, it does not have the substance of existing and subsisting on its own, like heaven, earth, water, air, fire, and other corporeal or spiritual creatures.

But the abandonment of the highest good, to which the rational creature, angelic or human, must adhere to be blessed, has taken this name to be called evil. Therefore, by abandoning the highest good, the rational creature, whether in angels or in sinning humans, has fallen away from that good and has been deprived of good, and this is the greatest evil for them.
chunks.original_latin:
Si autem quaerimus quae poena illis inferatur
tali judicio, et perditio, inquit, eorum non dormitat,
item de eisdem impiis et blasphematoribus idem apostolus
dicit: Hi sunt fontes sine aqua, et nebulae turbinibus
exagitatae, quibus caligo tenebrarum reservatur
(II Petr. II, 17): Quomodo eis reservatur, nisi quia
ipsis ab initio est praeparata, et in fine reddenda? Quod eisdem pene verbis beatus Judas apostolus attestatur
dicens: Hi sunt nubes sine aqua, quae a ventis
circumferuntur: arbores autumnales, bis mortuae,
eradicatae: fluctus feri maris despumantes suas
confusiones; sidera errantia, quibus procella tenebrarum
in aeternum servata est (Jud. 12, 13). Contra haec tam horrenda, tam terribilia, quae
 omnipotens Deus per prophetas et apostolos suos
impiis et peccatoribus comminatur, dicit iste:
Omne malum, peccatum et ejus poenam non esse. Et
iterum asserit: Naturae integritatem, vitam, beatitudinem
esse. E contrario autem peccatum, mortem, miseriam
penitus non esse. Addidit adhuc: omnem perversae
voluntatis defectam vel privationem, vel peccatum,
finemque ipsius mortem et miseriam suppliciorum
aeternalium omnino nihil esse: ac per hoc nec praesciri
a Deo, nec praedestinari. De quibus omnibus si
aliquid singillatim dicendum est, manifeste novit
fides quia malum quod est contrarium bono, sicut
vitium virtuti, tenebrae luci, infirmitas sanitati, substantialiter
non est. Quia, sicut jam supra dictum
est, substantiam per se existendi et subsistendi non
 habet, sicut coelum, terra, aqua, aer, ignis, et reliqua
sive corporea sive spiritalis creatura. Sed desertio
summi boni, cui, ut beata esse possit, inhaerere
debet creatura rationalis angelica vel humana,
hoc nomen accepit ut dicatur malum. Deserendo
ergo rationalis creatura, in angelis sive in hominibus
peccantibus, summum bonum, defecit ab ipso
bono, et privata est bono, et hoc ei est summum
malum.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Whether we say that evil is the abandonment of good, a deficiency of good, or the absence of good, we are speaking correctly. Just as vice is the abandonment of virtue, darkness is the absence of light, and illness is simply a lack of health.

Similarly, sin clearly has no substance of its own to exist and endure. Instead, the abandonment and deficiency of justice have been given this name. In the same way, death has no substance of its own, but the loss of life is what we call death.

Likewise, what we call punishment has no substance of its own, but pain and suffering have been given this name. It's merely the disturbance or loss of natural tranquility and peace. Punishment acts by disturbing or taking away the peace and tranquility of nature through pain and suffering.

But all these things—evil, sin, punishment, death, and misery, which is essentially the loss of happiness—although they have no substance to exist or endure on their own, must occur in or arise from some substance. The abandonment of good, called evil, and the abandonment of justice, called sin, clearly occur in the mind, whether angelic or human.

Similarly, the loss of life, termed death, and the loss of natural tranquility or peace, termed punishment, as well as the loss of happiness, termed misery, are found to occur in both the soul and the body.

The soul dies by the abandonment of its life, which is God, and the body dies by the loss of its life, which is the soul. These two forms of death, the death of the soul and the death of the body, are essentially the loss of either happiness or tranquility.
chunks.original_latin:
Sive ergo dicamus malum esse desertionem
boni, vel defectum a bono, vel privationem boni,
rectissime dicimus, sicut et vitium desertio virtutis,
et tenebrae privatio lucis, et infirmitas nihil aliud,
quam defectus est sanitatis; similiter et peccatum
manifeste nullam habet substantiam in se existendi
et subsistendi. Sed desertio justitiae et defectus a

in se existendi et subsistendi non habet, sed
vitae amissio tale nomen accepit. Item quod dicitur
poena nullam in se existendi substantiam habet, sed
dolor et ex dolore cruciatus tale nomen accepit:
quod nihil est aliud quam tranquillitatis et quietis
naturalis perturbatio, vel amissio, hoc namque agit
poena, ut tranquillitas et quies naturae ipso dolore
et cruciatu turbetur vel amittatur. Sed haec omnia, id est malum, peccatum, poena,
mors, miseria, quae et ipsa nihil est aliud quam
amissio felicitatis, licet per se et in se existendi vel
subsistendi nullam habeant substantiam, tamen omnino
necesse est ut in aliqua vel ex aliqua substantia
fiant. Nam et desertio boni, quod dicitur malum,
 et desertio justitiae, quod appellatur peccatum, manifeste
in animo fiunt vel angelico vel humano. Sic
amissio vitae, quae appellatur mors, et amissio tranquillitatis
vel quietis naturalis, quae appellatur poena;
et amissio felicitatis, quae vocatur miseria, in
utroque fieri inveniuntur, id est et in anima, et in
corpore. Nam et anima moritur desertione vitae suae,
quod Deus illi est: et corpus moritur amissione vitae
suae, quod anima illi est: et haec duo, id est
mors animae et mors corporis, quid aliud in utroque
nisi vel felicitatis vel tranquillitatis amissio est?

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The punishment experienced as torment and pain clearly occurs in either the soul or the body. When it happens in the body, it's often inflicted by another body. For instance, when someone is whipped, wounded with swords, or tormented by other means, similar to what will occur in eternal punishments, where the bodies of the damned will be tortured with fire and sulfur.

All these pains and torments inflicted on bodies by bodies affect the soul through the body. Indeed, the soul can feel pain and torment without the body. Like the story of the rich man in hell, whose soul was tormented as he said, "I am tormented in this flame" (Luke 16:24). However, the body cannot feel pain without the soul.

Concerning Almighty God, it is written: "Before they were created, everything was known to the Lord God: thus, after their completion, He observes everything" (Ecclesiasticus 23:29).

And again: "From eternity to eternity He observes, and nothing is new in His sight" (Ecclesiasticus 39:21).

Again, when Scripture speaks of people, it says: "All their works are like the sun in the sight of God: no thought escapes Him, and no word is hidden from Him" (Ecclesiasticus 17:26).

Thus, I say, the most omnipotent and ineffable Creator, to whom everything was known in His eternal knowledge before being created, who, even after completing everything, observes the facts not differently, but just as He saw them to be done, seeing everything within Himself, not outside Himself.
chunks.original_latin:
Poena autem quae in cruciatu et dolore sentitur, manifeste
vel in anima agitur vel in corpore; et cum
in corpore agitur maxime ex alio corpore irrogatur:
 ut cum flagellis caeditur, gladiis vulneratur, vel quibuscunque
tormentis vexatur: quod etiam in suppliciis
aeternis futurum est, ubi damnatorum corpora
igni et sulphure torquebuntur. Qui tamen omnes
dolores et cruciatus, corporibus de corporibus illati,
sic fiunt in corpore, ut per corpus etiam animae
sint. Anima namque sine corpore et dolere et cruciari
potest; sicut illa damnati divitis in inferno,
anima cruciabatur qui ait, quia crucior in hac flamma
(Luc. XVI, 24); corpus vero sine anima dolere
non potest. Omnipotenti itaque Deo de quo scriptum est: Domino
enim Deo, antequam crearentur, omnia fuerunt
agnita: sic et post perfectum respicit omnia (Eccli. XXIII, 29). Et iterum: A saeculo et usque in saeculum
 respicit, et nihil est novum in conspectu ejus (Ibid.,
XXXIX, 21). Et iterum cum de hominibus Scriptura
loqueretur ait: Et omnia opera eorum quasi sol in
conspectu Dei: non praeterit illum omnis cogitatus, et
non absconditur ab eo ullus sermo (Eccli. XVII, 26):
Isti, inquam, omnipotentissimo et ineffabili Creatori,
cui, antequam crearentur, in aeterna scientia sua
omnia fuerunt agnita, qui, etiam postquam omnia
perfecit, non aliter, sed sic respicit facta, sicut vidit
facienda, nihil videlicet extra se, sed in se omnia
cernendo.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
And so, nothing is new in His sight, nor when it was first created, because it has always existed in His eternal knowledge. All human actions, just like under the brightest sun, are not hidden from Him; no thought of humans escapes Him, and no word of theirs is concealed from Him.

This wondrous Creator and ruler has always known the nature, form, and order of all things in His eternal foreknowledge. He has also eternally foreseen their state, whether they would progress toward improvement or decline toward worse conditions. The just planner of His work has both foreseen and predestined the rewards for those who progress toward Him and the punishments for those who fall away from Him, and has declared that He will fulfill them.

Therefore, whether it is evil and sin, which are a departure from good, or death and punishment, which are justly due to that departure, they have always been in the foreknowledge of the Creator. He alone truly knows the measure of progress and decline in His creatures and is the sole just judge of their progress and decline.

Thus, death and sin and all punishment and misery that follow sin, because they do not have any substance in themselves for existing, are nothing. And because they greatly harm the rational creature, whose decline and corruption are signified by these names, they are truly felt in its substance, whether bodily or spiritual. What does not exist as a substance is completely harmful in causing harm.

Therefore, let this kind of blasphemy cease, and let Almighty God be acknowledged as the creator of all natures, the truest knower of their state, and the most just planner.
chunks.original_latin:
Et ideo in conspectu ejus nihil est novum,
nec quando primum est creatum, quia semper fuit
in ejus scientia aeternum: quem omnia opera hominum,
sicut in clarissimo sole non latent; quem nullus
hominum praeterit cogitatus, a quo nullus eorum
 sermo absconditur; iste tam mirabilis Creator et
gubernator, sicut omnium rerum quae futurae erant,
naturam et speciem et ordinem in sua aeterna praescientia
semper novit, ita etiam ipsarum rerum statum,
et sive ad meliora profectum, sive ad deteriora
defectum aeternaliter praevidit; et quae ad se proficientibus
praemia, quae autem a se deficientibus supplicia
deberentur, justissimus operis sui ordinator,
et praescivit et praedestinavit, et se impleturum praedixit. Et ideo sive malum et peccatum, in quibus
est defectus a bono; sive mors et poena, quae illi defectui
juste debetur, semper fuit in praescientia Conditoris;
qui mensuram proficiendi et deficiendi in
creaturis suis solus veraciter agnoscit, et ipsorum
profectuum atque defectuum solus judex justus existit. Ita et mors et peccatum et omnis poena ac miseria
quae peccatum consequentur, quia substantiam
nullam habent in se existendi, nihil sunt. Et quia
creaturae rationali, cujus defectus et corruptio his
nominibus significantur, nimis nocent, in ejus substantia
vel corporali, vel spiritali, veraciter sentiuntur. Et quae non sunt substantia existendo, sunt omnimodis
perniciosa nocendo. Desinat ergo hujusmodi
blasphemia, et omnipotens Deus sicut omnium
naturarum conditor, et status earum verissimus
agnoscatur cognitor, et justissimus ordinator.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
CHAPTER 11.

In this chapter, it states:

1. God's predestination is only for those destined for eternal happiness. 2. It's a misuse of language to claim that God foreknows and predestines: He foreknew what He would do, and likewise, what He wouldn’t do, which implies He didn’t know. In the same way, He predestined those He prepared for grace. Conversely, He predestined the wicked for destruction or eternal punishment: if they are predestined, they will inevitably perish and face unavoidable punishments. If this is true, how can a world, compelled to perish by predestination, be judged fairly? 3. The Holy Scriptures attribute foreknowledge and predestination, or just predestination, only to those chosen by God for eternal happiness. 4. The Apostle linked foreknowledge and predestination solely to the saints, while Augustine sometimes applied them to the reprobates in contrast. Initially, he mentioned that God's predestination is only for those prepared for eternal happiness. Whether this was his own belief or learned from others, it is recognized as a modern error by many, as they do not see God's predestination in the Scriptures except concerning the elect; nor do they believe that Blessed Paul the Apostle mentioned predestination in his Letters solely for the elect, as he elaborates further. We must humbly accept and follow the truth, not stubbornly adhere to our prior beliefs, but instead diligently explore the holy Scriptures, both apostolic and prophetic, from which all apostolic authority originates. Blessed Paul himself clearly states at the beginning of the Epistle to the Romans, indicating he is set apart for the Gospel of God, which was promised beforehand through His prophets in the holy Scriptures. Romans chapter 1, verse 1.
chunks.original_latin:
CAPUT XI. Undecimo capitulo sequitur iste, et dicit. 1. Non esse Dei praedestinationem, nisi de his qui
praeparati sunt ad aeternam felicitatem. 2. Abusive translateque dici praescire Deum et praedestinare:
a simili praescivit quae facturus esset; a
contrario praescivit, quae facturus non esset, pro nescivit. Similiter a simili praedestinavit quos praeparavit
ad gratiam. A contrario praedestinavit impios ad
interitum vel supplicium aeternum: si enim praedestinati
sunt, necessario peribunt, poenasque patientur
inevitabiles. Quod si ita est, quomodo juste judicabitur
mundus, quem necessitas praedestinationis cogit
perire. 3. Sanctas Scripturas praescientiam simul et praedestinationem,
aut solam absolutam praedestinationem,
non nisi in iis quos Deus elegit ad aeternam beatitudinem
 possidendam, inveniantur posuisse. 4. Apostolum praescientiam et praedestinationem in
solis sanctis, Augustinum aliquoties in reprobis a contrario
posuisse. Imprimis quod dicit, non esse Dei praedestinationem
nisi de his qui praeparati sunt ad aeternam felicitatem. Sive ex suo sensu hoc dixerit, sive ab aliis
audierit, nos tamen veraciter scimus quia iste est
error moderni temporis apud plurimos, dum non
putant praedestinationem Dei, nisi in parte electorum,
in Scripturis inveniri: nec ipsum beatum Paulum
apostolum in Epistolis suis, nisi de solis similiter
electis praedestinationem posuisse, sicut et in sequentibus
dicit. Sed acquiescendum et obediendum
est humiliter veritati; et non quod semel nobis persuasum
 est, contentiose defendendum, sed potius
Scriptura sancta diligentius perscrutanda, non solum
apostolica, sed etiam prophetica, ex qua omnis apostolica
auctoritas descendit. Sicut ipse beatus Paulus
statim in principio Epistolae ad Romanos evidenter
declarat, segregatum se esse dicens in Evangelium
Dei, quod ante promiserat per prophetas suos in Scripturis
sanctis (Rom. I, 1).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
At the end of that same letter, he confirms that the entire mystery of the Gospel's preaching, which includes the profound mystery of God's foreknowledge and predestination, has been revealed through the prophetic Scriptures. He says: "Now to him who is able to strengthen you according to my gospel and the preaching of Jesus Christ, according to the revelation of the mystery kept secret for eternal times, but now revealed through the prophetic Scriptures," from the Book of Romans, Chapter 16, Verses 25 to 26.

In the Acts of the Apostles, he speaks about himself, saying: "To this day I stand testifying to both small and great, saying nothing beyond what the prophets and Moses said would happen," from the Book of Acts, Chapter 26, Verse 22.

So, when the Apostle shows and confirms that he is set apart for the Gospel of God, promised beforehand through the prophets in the holy Scriptures, and that the entire mystery he preaches is revealed through the prophetic Scriptures—saying nothing beyond what is written in the law and the prophets—it is clear that the depth of this matter, that is, divine foreknowledge and predestination, should be diligently explored not only in the Apostle, who bases all his preaching on prophetic Scriptures, but also in the Scriptures of the prophets themselves.

What is found in both, with a clear declaration of truth, should be faithfully followed by us, without dispute or controversy. Therefore, first, let us hear what the Apostle himself, who testifies that he says nothing beyond what is written in the law and the prophets, says about this matter.

Let us not be so absurd or contentious that, when the truth of predestination appears, we deny it was said for predestination just because the name of predestination is not explicitly found there. Whether predestination is expressly mentioned or the truth of predestination is most clearly evident, let it be received with equal and unquestioning faith.
chunks.original_latin:
Et in fine ejusdem Epistolae
omne mysterium evangelicae praedicationis, in
qua est etiam profundissimum mysterium praescientiae
et praedestinationis Dei, per Scripturas propheticas
confirmat esse revelatum, ita dicens: Ei autem
qui potens est vos confirmare, secundum Evangelium
meum, et praedicationem Jesu Christi, secundum revelationem
mysterii aeternis temporibus taciti, quod nunc

seipso loquitur dicens: Usque in hodiernum diem
sto testificans minori, atque majori, nihil extra dicens,
quam ea quae Prophetae sunt locuti futura esse, et
Moyses (Act. XXVI, 22). Cum ergo ipse Apostolus
ostendat atque confirmet in illud Evangelium Dei,
quod ante promisit per prophetas suos in Scripturis
sanctis se segregatum, et omne illud mysterium
quod evangelizat per Scripturas prophetarum testetur
patefactum, nihilque se extra dicere, quam quae
scripta sunt in lege et prophetis, manifestum est
hujus rei, id est divinae praescientiae et praedestinationis,
altitudinem non solum in Apostolo, qui ex
 Scripturis propheticis omnem suam praedicationem
confirmat; sed etiam in ipsorum prophetarum Scripturis
diligentius investigandam, et quod in utrisque
festa veritatis declaratione fuerit inventum, fideliter
nobis, et sine ulla controversiarum disceptatione
omnimodis sequendum. Primo itaque quid ipse Apostolus, qui se nihil
extra dicere nisi quae scripta sunt in lege et prophetis
testatur, de hac re dicat audiamus, nec tam absurdi,
nec contentiosi simus ut, ubi ipsa res, id est
praedestinationis veritas apparet, ideo negemus pro
praedestinatione dictum, quia nequaquam ibi praedestinationis
nomen positum inveniatur: sed, sive
sonet ibi expresse praedestinatio, sive ipsius praedestinationis
veritas certissime clarescat, una et pari
 fide suscipiatur.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
He begins by discussing the predestination of the elect, saying: "For those he foreknew, he also predestined to be conformed to the image of his Son, so that he might be the firstborn among many brothers. And those he predestined, he also called; and those he called, he also justified; and those he justified, he also glorified." (Romans 8:29-30)

Even if nothing more was said about the rejected, we would still need to infer by contrast how they are to be understood. Namely, that from the predestination of the elect to glory, we should recognize that there is also predestination of the rejected to punishment.

Just as in the creed, we seem to profess only eternal life as the reward for the saints; yet, by contrast, we must equally believe and comprehend eternal death as the damnation of the wicked. For the Apostle himself teaches us this rule of understanding in the Scriptures.

When he discussed resurrection, he said, "It is sown a natural body, it is raised a spiritual body" (First Corinthians 15:44), and to ensure he wasn't speaking of a spiritual body without scriptural backing, he added a contrasting understanding: "If there is a natural body, there is also a spiritual one."

He then confirms both by presenting Scripture, stating: "As it is written, 'The first man Adam became a living being'; the last Adam a life-giving spirit" (First Corinthians 15:45).

Similarly, it's understood that when God told the first man, "From the tree of the knowledge of good and evil you shall not eat; for in the day that you eat from it you shall surely die" (Genesis 2:17), He was certainly threatening death to the disobedient; but doesn't faith also recognize by contrast that life was prepared for the obedient?

Again, when God speaks to Abraham: "Any male who is not circumcised in the flesh of his foreskin on the eighth day shall be cut off from his people; he has broken my covenant" (Genesis 17:14).
chunks.original_latin:
Dicit itaque ipse primum de sola
praedestinatione electorum ita: Nam quos praescivit
et praedestinavit conformes fieri imaginis Filii sui,
ut sit ipse primogenitus in multis fratribus: Quos
autem praedestinavit, hos et vocavit; et quos vocavit,
hos et justificavit; quos autem justificavit, illos et
magnificavit (Rom. VIII, 29, 30). Post quae verba si
nihil omnino dixisset de parte reproborum, etiam
utique e contrario intelligere debueramus quid de
eis esset sentiendum, videlicet, ut ex praedestinatione
electorum ad gloriam agnosceremus etiam
praedestinationem esse reproborum ad poenam. Sicut
et in symbolo tantummodo vitam aeternam, quod
est praemium sanctorum videmur confiteri; et tamen
e contrario similiter indubitanter credere et

iniquorum. Hanc enim regulam intelligendi in
Scripturis ipse nos Apostolus docet, qui cum dixisset,
de resurrectione disputans: Seminatur corpus
animale, surget corpus spirituale (I Cor. XV, 44), ne
sine auctoritate Scripturae spirituale corpus dixisse
videretur, statim quod e contrario veraciter intelligendum
esset adjunxit, dicens: Si est corpus animale
et spirituale (Ibid.). Et continuo utrumque
confirmans ponit testimonium Scripturae, et dicit:
Sicut scriptum est, factus est primus homo Adam
in animam viventem: novissimus Adam in spiritum vivificantem
(ibid., 45). Similiter et illud utique intelligitur
quod, cum Deus primo homini dixisset: De ligno
scientiae boni et mali ne comedas; quocunque
 die comederis ex eo, morte morieris (Gen. II, 17). Utique inobedienti comminatus est mortem; sed
nunquid non agnoscit fides quid e contrario sentiendum
sit; id est quod obedienti praeparaverit vitam? Item cum loquitur Deus ad Abraham: Masculus cujus
praeputii caro non fuerit circumcisa octava die, peribit
anima illa de populis suis: quia pactum meum irritum
fecit (Gen. XVII, 14).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
It's clear that this man, who wasn't circumcised on the eighth day, will be cut off from his people because he's broken God's covenant. Not in his mother's womb, nor in his early infancy when he could neither do good nor bad, but indeed in paradise, in Adam's transgression, where all have sinned, as the Apostle says in Romans chapter five, verse 12. Those who descend from that condemned origin.

Just as this man, not circumcised on the eighth day, is clearly declared lost due to the guilt of the first transgression, it's faithfully understood that he who is rightly and lawfully circumcised is absolved from that guilt.

We've said this to make it clear that even if the Apostle, in his discussion of predestination, had remained silent about the part of the reprobate, our faith should still observe and understand what to think of them, in contrast. However, he doesn't remain silent because immediately after comparing both the elect and the reprobate, he places them together in the two twins of Isaac and Rebecca, adding: Before they were born, or had done anything good or bad, so that God's purpose according to election might stand, not by works but by Him who calls, it was said, "The older will serve the younger," as it is written: "Jacob I loved, but Esau I hated" in Romans chapter nine, verses 11 through 13, and Malachi chapter one, verses one and two.

Therefore, clearly in this example, and in Jacob, loved and chosen without any merits, who was similarly held liable to original sin, as a brother and coming from the same condemned mass in Adam, the predestination of the elect to life is declared. In Esau, however, hated only for the guilt of original sin, the predestination of the reprobate to destruction is shown.

This is also what is added shortly after concerning both sides: "Therefore God has mercy on whom he wants to have mercy, and he hardens whom he wants to harden," as stated in Romans chapter nine, verse 18.
chunks.original_latin:
Manifestum est masculum istum,
qui non est octava die circumcisus, periturum de
populis suis, quia pactum Dei irritum fecit: Non
utique in utero materno, nec in illa tam recenti infantia,
quando aliquid bonum aut malum nullatenus
agere potuit, sed utique in paradiso, in praevaricatione
Adae, in quo omnes, sicut Apostolus dicit, peccaverunt

essent, aut aliquid egissent bonum aut malum (ut secundum

minori, sicut scriptum est: Jacob dilexi, Esau
autem odio habui (Rom. IX, 11, 12, 13; Mal. I, 1, 2). Manifeste igitur in hoc exemplo, et in Jacob, absque
ullis meritis dilecto et electo, qui similiter tenebatur

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
And then he adds: Doesn't the potter have the right to make from the same lump of clay one vessel for honor and another for dishonor? Romans chapter nine, verse twenty-one.

About these vessels of honor and dishonor, he immediately adds: What if God, wanting to show his wrath and make his power known, endured with much patience the vessels of wrath prepared for destruction, to make the riches of his glory known to the vessels of mercy, which he prepared for glory? Romans chapter nine, verses twenty-two to twenty-three.

In all of this, it is clearly recognized that the Apostle speaks not only of the predestination of the elect, which he mentioned first, but throughout his argument, he discusses the predestination of both groups, whether to life or to death. He uses examples and prophetic testimonies, presenting Jacob as a model of the elect, and Esau as a model of the rejected.

In these two groups, God shows mercy to whom he wills, and hardens whom he wills: but he shows mercy by helping mercifully, and hardens by justly abandoning. Like a potter with the same lump of clay, all at once condemned, he makes one vessel for honor by mercifully freeing, and another for dishonor by justly condemning.

Thus, two orders emerge: some are vessels of wrath, and others are vessels of mercy; the former prepared for destruction, the latter prepared for glory.

Those prepared for destruction are so by their own merit and God's just judgment; while those prepared for glory are by no merit of their own, but by the grace of God alone.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
So, when the Apostle clearly states, "And vessels of wrath prepared for destruction, and vessels of mercy prepared for glory, and from the same lump one vessel is made for honor, and another for dishonor," it's evident that these words highlight the divine predestination of both groups.

While the chosen are predestined to life solely by God's goodness, without any merit of their own, those rejected are destined for destruction not due to any bias from God, but because of their own merit, whether original or actual. Divine predestination does not force them to perish or sin, but it does require them to face just punishments. This means that those who remain in sin by choice are subjected to necessary punishments.

Thus, if we carefully and faithfully consider the Apostle's discussion from this point to the end, where he says, "For God has concluded all in unbelief, that He might have mercy on all" (Romans 11:32), it becomes clear regarding the predestination of both groups, whether among the Jewish people—those who were blinded and those saved according to the election of grace—or among both Jews and Gentiles. While the former were broken off like natural branches and the latter grafted into the good olive tree (Romans 11:17), you will find him discussing this with his words and especially with prophetic testimonies.

In these prophetic testimonies, which the blessed Apostle presented with such authority, he intended to teach us about the depth and mystery of divine predestination on both sides, relying solely on their firmness and clear testimony.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
When discussing devotion, it's important to note that even though the word predestination isn't directly mentioned, the concepts themselves, concerning both types of predestination, are clearly evident. The Apostle used these concepts confidently to confirm and teach this significant topic, passing them on to the Church to be understood in this manner. He instructs us by his authority and example so that we do not engage in contentious or unnecessary arguments about the word predestination found in the sayings of the holy prophets, or, God forbid, even fight about it. Instead, with a peaceful and pious understanding, wherever the concept itself is most clearly expressed, we must undoubtedly acknowledge and affirm divine predestination.

The first prophetic testimony he referenced is from Genesis, where it says: "For this is the word of promise: At this time I will come, and Sarah will have a son" Romans 9:9. Here, while predestination might not seem to be mentioned, the promise is clearly there. It's not rightly understood unless the promise itself is faithfully accepted as the predestination of Abraham's chosen offspring—those who are considered children of God and set apart by divine grace from the children of the flesh. As the Apostle explains in the same passage: "It is not the children of the flesh who are the children of God, but the children of the promise are considered the offspring" Romans 9:8.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Second, he mentioned the account from Genesis about the twins, Isaac and Rebecca, where it was said, "The older will serve the younger" Genesis 25:23. While predestination might not seem directly mentioned here, the concept is demonstrated so deeply and profoundly that the Apostle urges us to observe and carefully consider the entire oracle that was divinely given to Rebecca about the twins. We are to understand that they were not condemned from their mother's womb, having done nothing good or bad in their own lives, and indeed they were conceived from one act of intercourse. Yet, Almighty God made a distinction between them, not based on any previous good or bad deeds, but solely by His goodness and judgment, preferring one over the other and subjecting one to servitude.

And lest we think it is a small matter, as if it only concerns human affairs, that "the older will serve the younger," as if this were only to be fulfilled in the temporal world, where in their descendants one was raised to a kingdom, ruling over the other who was subject and serving: The Apostle elevates our understanding to consider something greater by adding a testimony from the prophet Malachi, where God speaks of the same twins, not temporally but eternally distinguished, not only in temporal matters but also separated by a great distance in eternal matters, saying: "Jacob I loved, but Esau I hated" Malachi 1:2. Therefore, this prophetic testimony cannot be rightly understood unless it is faithfully joined with the testimony from Genesis, so that, just as it was said there, "The older will serve the younger," so also what God speaks through the prophet: "Jacob I loved, but Esau I hated," before they were born and before they had done anything good or bad. In divine and just judgment, both are understood to have preceded: both God's love for Jacob and God's hatred for Esau.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
With these two examples—God's love for one and hatred for the other, their birth, and all the worthiness of their lives according to true and apostolic understanding—it is clear that neither could have evil attributed to them for acts they had not yet committed, nor good for acts they had not yet performed. Therefore, these actions are considered just. Almighty God, who had eternally determined both the election of one and the rejection of the other, foresaw their original guilt stemming from Adam's transgression, which both were equally subject to.

He mercifully loves one and frees him, while justly hating and rejecting the other, condemning him. From this, we can faithfully understand the deeper and more hidden nature of divine judgment, and more clearly perceive the general condemnation of the entire human race in Adam. With enlightening apostolic understanding, we see that the almighty God, by his grace alone, frees those he wills and condemns those he does not will, with eternal fairness.

Although in this prophetic testimony, where God says: I loved Jacob, but Esau I hated, the word predestination is not mentioned, the truth is clearly evident in the election or rejection of both. Nothing could be said more strongly or explicitly.

From the example of these twins, it is shown by God's testimony that the almighty God loved some with eternal mercy and hated others with eternal judgment. This prophetic testimony and apostolic understanding—where God's love and hatred for the twins still in the womb is understood through his mercy and judgment—aligns with what the prophet Isaiah says. The almighty God is shown as the helper of the elect people from the womb and, conversely, as the condemner of the reprobate people, as if from the womb of the transgressor. The prophet first speaks to the chosen people: Thus says the Lord who made and formed you, your helper from the womb (Isaiah 44:2).

Then, after addressing the rebellious people, it adds from God's perspective: "I called you a transgressor from the womb" Isaiah chapter sixty-eight, verse eight, to show that what the Apostle demonstrated with the example of the twins is meant to illustrate the two types of people: the chosen and the rejected.

Romans chapter nine, verse twenty-one.

Similarly, in the third prophetic testimony, which he presents as follows: "For he says to Moses, 'I will have mercy on whom I have mercy, and I will have compassion on whom I have compassion'" (Exodus chapter thirty-three, verse nineteen), the concept of predestination isn't explicitly mentioned. However, the meaning is so clear that it cannot be doubted.

Since Almighty God, after the first transgression, condemns all equally, not because of any preceding good merits, but by His grace alone, He has mercy on whom He chooses and shows compassion to whom He wills. It is evident that for those He does not choose to give this grace, they are hated and condemned by His just and eternal judgment.

Following this, he presents the fourth prophetic testimony, similar to the third from Exodus, adding: "For the Scripture says to Pharaoh, 'I raised you up for this very purpose, that I might display my power in you and that my name might be proclaimed in all the earth'" Romans chapter nine, verse seventeen.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation: Here, although the term "predestination" isn't explicitly mentioned, the concept of predestining the wicked to eternal destruction due to their own actions is shown so clearly that anyone who listens and understands faithfully cannot doubt it. When the wicked, stubborn, and unyielding king of Egypt was moved by divine judgment—whether because of his condemned nature or due to the power of his royal status—he was led to increase his defiance of the Lord by adding sin upon sin. As a result, he deserved to be punished by the incredible power of God through great and terrible plagues and ultimately to be erased with his equally wicked people through eternal submersion and destruction. In this way, they would receive what they justly deserved, and the almighty power of God would be made known more magnificently to all, whether through their punishment or destruction, allowing many to come to know God and seek their salvation through the punishment of one. As the blessed Ambrose discusses this matter very clearly, he says: These are the words of the blessed Ambrose. The Apostle, mentioning two preceding testimonies—one about the mercy given to the chosen and the other about the judgment on the rejected—explains that both occur through the merciful and just will of God, adding: "Therefore God has mercy on whom he wishes, and he hardens whom he wishes" (Romans chapter 9, verse 18). Shall the thing formed say to the one who formed it, 'Why have you made me like this?'" (Isaiah chapter 45; Romans chapter 9).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Even though the word "predestination" isn't mentioned, the justice of predestination in both directions is so clearly and perfectly defended that it compels the faithful listener to truly understand that the Almighty Creator is the true potter. All humans, made from the clay of the earth by Him, are His creation. Therefore, it's only just that the creation cannot judge its potter. Instead, the potter judges his creation, as He alone knows, with His eternal counsel, how to kindly shape each vessel of His great creation and arrange and dispose of them for uses that are indeed just and appropriate.

To make this even clearer, he adds a sixth testimony from the prophet Jeremiah and says: "Does the potter not have power over the clay to make from the same lump one vessel for honor and another for dishonor?" (Romans nine, verse twenty-one). In the prophet Jeremiah, we read that the Lord said to him, "Arise, go down to the potter’s house, and there you will hear my words" (Jeremiah eighteen, verse two and following). When the prophet entered, the potter was making a work from clay with his hands, and suddenly the work he was making was spoiled. Immediately, he turned and made it into another vessel, as it pleased his eyes. Then the prophet was commanded to go and proclaim to the people on behalf of God: "Can I not do to you as this potter does, house of Israel?" says the Lord. "Behold, like clay in the hand of the potter, so are you in my hand," etc. (Jeremiah eighteen, verse seven).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
In this prophetic reading, God reveals that He is the potter, and humanity is like clay in His hands. From this clay, He creates various vessels as He pleases: from one lump, equally condemned in Adam, He forms vessels that are distinct and diverse by His judgment. Some are made for honor, others for disgrace. Even a vessel shaped for destruction by its own merit and divine judgment can be reshaped through the potter's repentance, so it is no longer destined for destruction. Through the wisdom and goodness of the potter, it can be transformed into another vessel, one of honor and pleasing to the creator.

Although the concept of predestination is not explicitly mentioned, the power and truth of predestination are clearly shown, distinguishing the elect from the reprobate, and vessels for honor from those for disgrace. It is presented so clearly that nothing more certain or clearer can be found. We have decided to present these considerations diligently to the readers, so that according to this apostolic perspective, we do not struggle much with the word of predestination in all prophetic Scriptures. The truth about divine predestination is presented so clearly and abundantly that human frailty can hardly comprehend them all.

We have included some examples for clarity, especially those that are straightforward and evident, so that those who listen peacefully and faithfully may be more easily informed, and those who are contentious may be corrected more quickly if they choose to accept the truth. We do not speak now of the predestination of the elect, as prophetic testimonies, as we have shown, are presented clearly by the Apostle, and are entirely sufficient to understand and faithfully believe in it.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Let's not have any doubts about it, thanks to the Lord's generosity, but only about the just judgment of predestination, by which He has foreordained and destined the wicked for destruction. Many people hesitate on this topic, so we'll revisit a few clear examples.

In the Book of Genesis, we read that Almighty God foretold the destruction of the entire human race, except for those saved by His mercy in the ark, due to their overwhelming wickedness and impiety. They would perish both immediately and completely, wiped out by the punishment of the flood, and face eternal damnation in the future.

He spoke to the holy patriarch Noah, saying: "The end of all flesh has come before me. The earth is filled with violence because of them, and I will destroy them along with the earth" (Genesis 6:13).

Regarding this general destruction, Scripture says a little earlier: "And God said, My spirit shall not remain in man forever, for he is flesh. His days shall be 120 years" (Genesis 6:3).

And a little later: "But when God saw that the wickedness of humans was great on the earth, and that every thought of their hearts was only evil all the time, it grieved Him that He had made man on the earth" (Genesis 6:5, 6).

Shortly after, it adds: "I will destroy," He said, "man whom I have created from the face of the earth, from man to animals, to creeping things, and to birds of the air. I regret having made them" (Genesis 6:7).

What could be more evident than such a prediction and predestination of the general destruction of all the wicked, with whom the world was filled at that time? God wanted to announce this long beforehand to the holy and chosen patriarch, and He decided and determined it in His eternal and internal counsel.

This was shown not through an angel or any prophet of that time, but within Himself.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Yet, the most merciful judge and creator did not abandon those he had justly destined to a dreadful end due to their injustices and impieties. He showed them the goodness and compassion of his mercy. He granted them time and opportunity to repent, so that within 120 years, they could either satisfy God through true repentance or, if they hardened their hearts and remained unrepentant, they would store up wrath for themselves on the day of wrath and perish without excuse. Thus, although he predestined them to destruction because of their impiety, he never compelled them to sin, waiting for their repentance over many years.

The book of Ecclesiasticus also speaks sorrowfully about the unfortunate stubbornness and terrible damnation of those who, led out of Egypt by Moses, could not enter the promised land due to their unbelief, and whose bodies were laid low in the desert. It says: "The ancient giants did not plead for their sins, who were destroyed, trusting in their own strength, and he did not spare their journey, and he cursed them for their pride. He did not pity them, destroying the whole nation for exalting themselves in their sins. And like 600,000 foot soldiers gathered in the hardness of their hearts: if even one had been stubborn, it would be a wonder if he had been exempt. For with him is mercy and anger. He is powerful in prayer and pours out wrath. According to his mercy, so his correction judges a person according to their works" (Ecclesiasticus 16:8-13).

Such is the prediction and predestination of God speaking to Abraham about the future oppression, affliction, and deliverance of his descendants, and conversely, the damnation and destruction of their oppressors. He said: "Know for certain that your descendants will be strangers in a land not their own, and they will be enslaved and afflicted for 400 years. Nevertheless, I will judge the nation they serve, and afterward, they will come out with great wealth."

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
You will join your ancestors in peace, living to a ripe old age. In the fourth generation, your descendants will return here, as the sins of the Amorites are not yet complete at this time. Genesis Fifteen: Thirteen to Sixteen.

What could be clearer than this idea of predestination? It predicts that Abraham's descendants will live in a foreign land for many years, endure servitude, and face oppression, but will ultimately be freed from this hardship. It specifies that in the fourth generation, they will return to the land promised to their ancestors. It also foretells that the blessed patriarch will peacefully join his ancestors at an advanced age.

On the other hand, the nation and king of the Egyptians, who will oppress them, are destined by God's judgment for eternal destruction.

Similarly, or even more clearly, is the prophecy and predestination regarding the destruction of the Amorites, or rather, the seven wicked nations, which Almighty God, speaking to Abraham, declared He would destroy and erase because of their wickedness. He said, "The sins of the Amorites are not yet complete at this time." He promised that once they were destroyed, He would give their kingdoms and lands to Abraham's descendants.

However, the just and merciful judge did not plan to do this solely because of His goodness and promise to Abraham, nor did He show favoritism, God forbid. Instead, with His goodness, patience, and long-suffering, He waited for many centuries, giving them time for repentance.

If those nations persisted in their wickedness and filled the measure of their sins, they would be justly punished in the fullness of their iniquities. In their place, the descendants of Abraham, who would serve God—not because of favoritism or their own merit of justice and fairness, but solely by divine goodness—would succeed.

As the time drew near for the destruction of certain nations due to their wickedness and for the introduction of Abraham's descendants into their lands by God's mercy, God spoke to Abraham's descendants, the people of Israel, about their sins and their imminent, just destruction. He said: Do not defile yourselves with the practices that have made the nations I will drive out before you unclean, which have also defiled the land. I will punish its sins so that it will expel its inhabitants. Leviticus Chapter 18, verses 24 and 25.

And shortly after: All these abominations have been committed by the inhabitants of the land before you, and they have defiled it. Be careful, therefore, that it does not expel you too, when you commit the same actions, as it expelled the nation before you. Leviticus Chapter 18, verses 27 and 28.

Now, regarding the ultimate destruction of these nations, by which they perished both in the present and in the future, Scripture speaks broadly, saying: For it was the Lord's decision to harden their hearts, so they would fight against Israel and fall, without deserving any mercy, and perish, as the Lord had commanded Moses. Joshua Chapter 11, verse 20.

What could be clearer about the predestination of the wicked to eternal destruction than the fact that almighty God, who had determined this in his hidden judgment, foretold these things to Abraham long before, frequently warned about them in later times, and finally confirmed in Scripture that it was according to his decision, that is, his plan and judgment, that they should not deserve any mercy but perish utterly and eternally in their wickedness and contempt.

Regarding these divine judgments, even the Book of Wisdom speaks to God, saying: For who will question you: What have you done? Or who will oppose your judgment? Or who will come before you as an avenger of wicked humans? Or who will blame you if the nations you created perish?

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The future of the four great and cardinal kingdoms, their sequence, timelines, and eternal nature, as well as their eventual destruction as foreseen by divine predestination, are revealed through God's remarkable foresight and arrangement. Whether shown as the four metals in the statue seen by the king in a dream, through the diverse four beasts rising from the sea, or through the explicit prediction of kings and wars leading to the Antichrist's downfall and the return of Christ for judgment, these truths are made clear.

Who can truly gauge the extent of the evil these kingdoms, including the kingdom of the Antichrist, have inflicted upon the world, and how much they have oppressed and attacked the Church of God? Yet, all these events, determined by the eternal judgment of divine foreknowledge and predestination, are understood to have occurred or will occur.

These events have been predicted remarkably, each distinguished by its own order, marked by specific times, and brought to their conclusion. They have been known and described long before through prophetic revelation.

If we seek the very essence of predestination, which is the decree and determination of divine judgment expressed in prophetic words, there is a profound and memorable passage in the prophet Isaiah. He speaks historically about the fall of the Babylonian and Assyrian kingdoms, but mystically about the downfall of the entire realm of evil at the end of time, presenting Almighty God swearing and affirming His words with unchangeable truth. Isaiah says, Isaiah 14:24, 26, 27: The Lord of hosts has sworn, saying: "Surely, as I have thought, so it shall be: and as I have purposed, so shall it stand." And shortly after: "This is the plan that I have purposed concerning the whole earth: and this is the hand stretched out over all the nations." For the Lord God of hosts has decreed, and who can weaken it? And His hand is stretched out, and who can turn it back?

In the vision of the great tree, which reached the ends of the earth and was ordered by God to be cut down, we see a symbol of worldly power. Due to pride, this power is often toppled and scattered by divine judgment. Through divine counsel, decree, and the ministry of holy angels, these events are shown to occur.

The king himself describes the dream, saying: I was watching the vision in my head while on my bed, and behold, a watcher, a holy one, descended from heaven. He cried aloud, saying: Cut down the tree, lop off its branches, shake off its leaves, and scatter its fruit, and so on. Daniel Chapter Four, Verses Ten and Eleven.

Soon after, it is stated: By the decree of the watchers, the sentence is passed, and the word of the holy ones is given until the living know that the Most High rules the kingdom of men and gives it to whomever he chooses. Daniel Chapter Four, Verse Fourteen.

These events were not meant for Nebuchadnezzar alone, but to instill terror and humility in all worldly powers who hear or read them. It serves as a reminder that the Most High rules the kingdom of men, granting power to some and taking it from others. Since this is arranged and executed through angelic ministries, it is said that the decree of the watchers and the word of the holy ones are fulfilled in such matters.

However, the prophet confirms that the sentence of the watchers is indeed the sentence of the Most High, saying: This is the interpretation of the sentence of the Most High, which has come upon my lord the king. Daniel Chapter Four, Verse Twenty-One.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
This divine judgment, determined by God, belongs to the Most High and the holy angels.

The Most High judges and commands, while the holy angels, who oversee all beneath Him, obey and carry out His will.

They receive the authority to speak on these matters as if they were commanding.

However, a request is added, ensuring that any actions carried out in the world through them are obtained by praying to God.

This concept of divine judgment is briefly demonstrated by the prophet Ezekiel. He speaks of the entire kingdom and priesthood of Judah, due to its impiety in the last times, when Christ the Lord approaches, and it is said to the reprobate king:

"But you, profane and wicked leader of Israel, whose day has come in the time of iniquity predetermined, this is what the Lord says: Remove the turban, take off the crown" (Ezekiel 21:25).

The crown refers to the kingdom, and the turban to the priests.

We see that both were taken away from that people when Christ the Lord came, and this happened when their day arrived in the predetermined time of iniquity.

The same prophet describes the Lord speaking to the sharpened and polished sword for the slaughter and destruction of the wicked:

"To be set against the necks of the wicked, whose day has come in the predetermined time of iniquity" (Ezekiel 21:29).

Both predestinations are clearly shown by the Apostle in his letters and by the prophets in the ancient Scriptures: through which nothing is unjust or disorderly, but everything is arranged with justice and reason.

The blessed Augustine, faithfully following this apostolic and prophetic authority, confidently spoke about predestination in the just judgments and dispositions of God.

Not in the way this person claims, falsely suggesting two deceitful and false rules, that is, from the similar and the contrary, so that what is affirmed as true by one is completely negated by the other as if it were false.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
He wishes that whatever is simply and truthfully stated in the holy Scriptures or in the teachings of the Fathers about predestination, especially concerning those condemned, should be understood as if the opposite were true. So, actions should be seen as undone, and words as unsaid. Who has ever heard of such madness? Shouldn't anyone who dares to think and even write such blatant and wicked lies against the truth of the Scriptures and the purity of the Fathers' teachings be cast far from everyone's attention?

After writing so much with misleading arguments, almost at the end, as if waking from a dream, he remembered the holy Scriptures, the Apostle, and Augustine. Yet, his claim that the Scriptures and the Apostle say nothing about the predestination of the wicked to eternal punishment has already been shown to be an open lie. He talks about God according to his ridiculous and utterly contemptible rule: claiming that God foreknew what He would not do, instead of admitting He did not know. Who has ever heard such a thing?

Where we read that God foreknew something, we should not understand it as if He did not know. Both ideas are false: that foreknowing should be understood as not knowing, or that God would not do something because He did not know. With His eternal knowledge, God truly foreknew whatever He would do, just as He foreknew whatever He would not do. For instance, He foreknew that He would raise Lazarus, and He did; He foreknew that He would not raise Judas, and He did not. But this person claims: God predestined the wicked to destruction or eternal punishment, instead of admitting He did not predestine; suggesting that where we read He predestined, we should understand, with unheard-of madness, He did not predestine.

He also poses the question: How will the world be justly judged if the necessity of predestination compels it to perish? Let none of us say such a thing. It is the most obvious blasphemy to claim that God, through the prejudice of His predestination, compels someone to sin and perish by sinning.

So that, fearing, they may be corrected. And once corrected, they may not be condemned.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation: Chapter Twelve. In this chapter, he lays out these definitions. First: All of God's foreknowledge is predestination, and all predestination is foreknowledge. Second: All of God's predestination is entirely the preparation of grace, and all grace is a gift. Therefore, all divine predestination is the preparation of His gifts. Third: Punishment justly torments the wicked, which is not a gift; otherwise, if it were a gift, it would not torment but rather liberate. Therefore, there is no predestination of punishment. If there were, it would not be punishment, but grace. It is, however, punishment; therefore, it is not predestined. Hence, predestination should always be understood as the gifts of divine generosity. Fourth: Those predestined to punishment are always understood in contrast, like the elect versus the non-elect: children of God versus non-children. These four lengthy and seemingly pointless propositions, crafted with the artifice of syllogisms, can be easily judged and refuted by anyone who diligently reads and faithfully understands what we have previously said according to the rule of faith, with the Lord's help. For who does not see how blasphemous and impious it is to say: All of God's foreknowledge is predestination? Faith clearly holds that the omnipotent God foresees all things, both good and evil: what He Himself will do and what He will not do; but He predestines only the good things, which He will do, either by mercifully delivering and rewarding the elect, or justly condemning the reprobates, because what is just is surely good. Therefore, according to this definition, if all of God's foreknowledge is predestination, then everything He foresaw, even the evil, He predestined Himself to do, which is far from the truth! Because He only foresaw the evil and did not predestine it, as He was not going to do it Himself, just as He did not decide or determine that all He predestined should happen. Similarly, the foundation of the second proposition starts from falsehood; and thus also ends in falsehood.

mala, praedestinavit se esse facturum, quod absit! Quia mala tantummodo praescivit, nec ea ullo modo
praedestinavit, quia nec ipse ea erat facturus, sicut

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
He claims that all of God's predestination is entirely a preparation for grace. However, we've shown through apostolic and prophetic testimonies that this isn't the case. We find and demonstrate that God's predestination should be understood in two ways: either as mercifully rewarding the good or justly condemning the wicked.

As we mentioned before, the words of blessed Augustine teach that when God's predestination is taken positively, it should be understood as the preparation of grace.

In the third proposition, it's similarly false when he tries to claim that there's no predestination of punishment. If the punishment for the devil, his angels, and all the reprobate wasn't predestined, Truth wouldn't say: "Depart into eternal fire, which is prepared for the devil and his angels" (Matthew 25:41).

His statement at the end of this third proposition, that predestination should always be understood as the gifts of divine generosity, is also false. It's truly understood not only in divine generosity but also in judgments of just condemnation.

His fourth proposition, which states: Predestined to punishment is always to be understood in the opposite sense, reflects the confusion we've discussed earlier. He wants us to interpret "predestined" as "not predestined."

However, what he added as an example—such as the elect for the non-elect; children of God for non-children—will be addressed better in the next chapter, where he explains his thoughts on these matters more fully.

We must remember that blessed Augustine, as his words show, sometimes said that in the Scriptures, the foreknowledge of God signifies predestination (On the Gift of Perseverance, Chapter 18).

From these words, this person took an occasion for his argument, against the true statement, which should sometimes be understood this way. He added "all" and removed "sometimes."

This is understood only in the context of the elect, according to his interpretation. However, this person added "all" and made another false definition by saying: All of God's predestination is entirely the preparation of grace.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
CHAPTER 13.

In the thirteenth chapter, it says this:

Judas is chosen as part of the non-elect, while the children of God are chosen from the non-children, in a contrasting manner: much like a friend who has always been an enemy. It's pointless to search for the children of God outside His elect; it's equally pointless to think His elect are outside those predestined by Him. Similarly, it's wrong to believe that those predestined by God are outside His elect, or to unnecessarily consider God's elect as separate from His children; there are no predestined ones unless they are children of God. Those predestined for punishment, destruction, or suffering should be understood as simply not predestined; they aren't separated from the condemned due to the merit of original and personal sin: therefore, they are allowed to live wickedly and will be punished with eternal fire. In these words, it's understood that Judas was counted among the elect apostles by the Lord, as it says: “Did I not choose you twelve?” (John 6:71) so that the others are truly understood to be elect, but he, in contrast, is called so ironically; it's better understood this way, so the Truth is acknowledged for speaking the truth. So, all twelve are understood to be chosen by the Lord: but the others in one way, Judas in another, meaning they are chosen eternally for the kingdom, he temporarily for ministry. He was chosen temporarily among the others for the apostolic ministry, sent for the duty of preaching: perhaps he even received the grace of miracles; hence blessed Peter speaks of him in the Acts of the Apostles: “For he was numbered among us and received his share of this ministry” (Acts 1:17). And when they appointed two and prayed that God would reveal who should take the place Judas lost through transgression, they prayed, saying: “You, God, who know the hearts of men, show which of these two you have chosen to take the share of this ministry and apostleship from which Judas turned aside to go to his own place” (Acts 1:24-25).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
So, he was chosen by the Lord to join the apostles through a temporary arrangement and share in their ministry and apostleship. However, it's said that he fell from that apostolic rank. The Lord didn't do this out of ignorance of the future, as He always knew, with His eternal foreknowledge, both the steadfast faith of the other apostles and his eventual fall and ruin.

As the blessed John the Evangelist testifies by saying, "For from the beginning Jesus knew who would believe and who would betray him" John chapter six, verse sixty-five.

Therefore, even when the Lord said, "Did I not choose twelve of you?" John chapter six, verse seventy-one, knowing the future, He immediately added, "And one of you is a devil." The Evangelist, explaining whom He was speaking of, immediately added, "He was speaking of Judas, the son of Simon Iscariot, for he, one of the twelve, was going to betray Him" John chapter six, verse seventy-two.

He also knew the place of his damnation in eternal punishment, which he was destined for due to the merit of his impiety. Thus, it was said by the apostles, "That he might go to his own place" Acts chapter one, verse twenty-five.

And the Lord Himself said, "Woe to that man by whom the Son of Man is betrayed; it would have been better for him if that man had never been born" Matthew chapter twenty-six, verse twenty-four.

And yet, as it was said, he wanted him to take up the ministry and the position of apostleship for a time, so that when he misused the Lord's great goodness, the Lord might use his great wrongdoing for our great good. By teaching through such an example, it was shown that there would be bad people mixed into his Church, just as this man was temporarily mixed into that company of apostles. They would share not only in the sacraments and divine ministries but also in the position of governance.

In this way, he provided his people with an example of patience, that they should patiently tolerate bad people, just as he himself, who knew him very well, tolerated this man with amazing patience. This was so that true believers would not think themselves defiled by the company of such people or reject their ministries, which are according to God, just as the blessed apostles were not defiled by his false company, nor was his ministry disapproved, as long as it was done according to God.

And when his misfortune reached the evil of betrayal, he turned the great evil of one man into the good of the whole world, since through this the true Lamb was sacrificed, who took away the sin of the world. Thus, the good Lord chose him for good so well that he granted him his good things and turned his evils into our good. Because what he transgressed and perished was due to his own wickedness; but that he was chosen among the good was due to the Lord's goodness. If he had remained in goodness, as the Apostle says: "Note then the kindness and the severity of God; severity towards those who have fallen, but kindness to you, provided you continue in his kindness" (Romans Eleven, Verse Twenty-Two).

Therefore, as far as the temporary ministry of apostleship is concerned, which the Lord was speaking about at that time when he said: "Did I not choose you, the twelve?" (John Six, Verse Seventy-One), it can rightly be said that this man was chosen among the others.

But as far as the eternal election to happiness is concerned, only those were chosen about whom he, making a distinction between this man and them, said: "I am not speaking of all of you; I know whom I have chosen" (John Thirteen, Verse Eighteen).

And thus, the statement can be well and truly understood, including Judas: "Did I not choose you, the twelve?"

Both truths are clearly evident: for it is written about Saul, when he was chosen as king, that he would be useful in many ways. The words that follow, "The days will come when the bridegroom is taken away from them, and then they will fast in those days" Luke Five Thirty-five, apply only to the others after he was already lost. Even if this is understood as being said with irony, as some interpret it, it doesn't validate the argument of this new and misguided debater. Using irony in human interactions is one thing, such as when we sarcastically say to a bad person, "You are a good man," or to someone doing wrong, "You are doing well," or calling an enemy "Friend," among other examples. But it's entirely different when, following this person's misguided thinking, someone openly denies the truth with falsehoods. For instance, when someone is justly described as predestined to punishment by divine judgment due to their wickedness, and yet this person, with newfound folly, falsely claims that predestined means not predestined. This distorted and untrue interpretation never appears in matters of faith in Scripture, nor has any credible church scholar or honest person ever expressed it.

If no one is predestined by God's just judgment to suffer punishment for sins, then what did the Apostles mean in their prayer to the Lord about Judas: "From which Judas has turned aside to go to his own place"? Acts chapter one, verse twenty-five. And what about Solomon's words: "The Lord has made all things for Himself, even the wicked for the day of evil"? Proverbs chapter sixteen, verse four. Or what is written in the book of Job: "The wicked is reserved for the day of destruction, and they shall be brought forth to the day of wrath"? Job chapter twenty-one, verse thirty. Why does Scripture speak of the Egyptians in the Red Sea, who were destined to be eternally destroyed, saying: "For a deserving necessity was leading them to this end"? Wisdom chapter nineteen, verse four. This clearly shows that the necessity of divine judgment led them to destruction, which was deserved due to their wickedness and contempt. And what about the scripture that says: "And he who turns from righteousness to sin, God has prepared him for the sword"? Ecclesiasticus chapter twenty-six, verse twenty-seven. Also, regarding the Antichrist who is yet to be revealed and extinguished at the end of the world, the angel told the blessed John in Revelation: "The beast that you saw was, and is not, and is about to ascend from the abyss and go into destruction." Revelation chapter seventeen, verse eight.
