This passage also appears in the Letter to the Romans, where the Apostle states:

"We know that in all things God works for the good of those who love Him, who have been called according to His purpose" (Romans 8:28).

The Apostle explains that God's purpose is synonymous with God's predestination. After mentioning "those who have been called according to His purpose," he immediately adds:

"For those God foreknew, He also predestined to be conformed to the image of His Son" (Ephesians 3:29).

From this, we can rightly understand that God's purpose, predestination, and predefinition are one and the same. This predefinition, or predestination, is clearly expressed in the Apostle's words for good, and in the prophet's words, it is expressed for evil, indicating those predestined to life here, and those predestined to destruction there.

These are the vessels of wrath, as the Apostle himself says (Romans 9:22), "fitted for destruction," or as others have translated, "prepared for destruction," by their own merit and just divine judgment.

When he speaks of those left in the mass condemned by the merit of original sin, allowed to live poorly, and ultimately punished with eternal fire, he is, albeit unwillingly and contradictorily, saying nothing other than that they are predestined by divine judgment to eternal fire.

For if that mass is entirely condemned, it is surely condemned by the just judgment of God, and undoubtedly condemned to eternal ruin and punishment. What else is this than saying that this same mass is condemned by divine judgment to everlasting destruction?

Thus, while he tries to resist the truth, he is compelled, even unwillingly and unknowingly, by unyielding reason, to confess the truth itself.

Chapter 14. The fourteenth chapter states:

According to Augustine, only the righteous are considered predestined. He says: "For we do not know who belongs to the number of the predestined, and who does not." He also mentions: "We cannot distinguish the predestined from the non-predestined." Additionally: "Those who fall and perish were never in the number of the predestined." The punishment destined for sinners: they are foreknown only, not predestined. This idea is also reflected in human laws, which do not predetermine a person to sin: by establishing punishments for those who will sin, they aim to deter potential sinners through the fear of severe penalties; in doing so, they achieve both mercy and retribution for offenders. In response to these words: Indeed, from the writings of Blessed Augustine in "On the Predestination of the Saints, Chapter 10, 16," it is shown that the term predestined can also apply to the unjust. When defining predestination, he stated: "The predestination of God, which is in good, is the preparation of grace." He wouldn't specify "in good" unless he knew that predestination could also relate to evil, as he demonstrates from the book of the Acts of the Apostles, citing the passage where it is said: "In truth, in this city were gathered together against your holy servant Jesus, whom you anointed, Herod and Pontius Pilate, along with the Gentiles and the people of Israel, to do whatever your hand and your plan had predestined to take place" (Acts 4:27-28). He added: "Indeed, the hand of God and the plan predestined what was necessary for the Gospel on account of us." Therefore, it is clearly shown from both the divine scriptures and the words of Saint Augustine that the predestination mentioned here was not for the good of those who acted during the Passion against the Lord, but for a great and deadly evil: even though God transformed it into good for us.

If anyone thinks that blessed Augustine misused the testimony from the previously mentioned book, because we read: "What your hand and counsel have decreed to be done," they should know that it was indeed accurately and appropriately used by him as it is in Greek. The word itself, proorisen, appears in Greek where he wrote: "What your hand and counsel have predestined to be done." This is also found in the Epistle to the Romans in Greek, where the Apostle says: "And those whom He predestined, He also called" (Romans 8:30). From this, it becomes clear that the same Greek word is properly translated into Latin as "predestined."

However, it can also be interpreted as "decreed" or "foreordained" to convey the meaning, ensuring that predestined means nothing other than decreed and defined. Just as in the words of the prophet Isaiah: "For the Lord God of hosts has decreed" (Isaiah 14:27), and in the book of Daniel: "By the decree of the watchers it is determined" (Daniel 4:14), this has been clearly demonstrated above.

What benefit is there in falsely claiming, with such intensity and contention, that blessed Augustine defined all predestination of grace as preparation, when he never said all? He only defined predestination that is good in this way, as if suggesting that only the just are to be called predestined. Since it is nowhere found that he said this, the words he used were about the predestination of the just alone, where some are indeed predestined, and others are not; some belong to the number of the predestined, while others do not.

He less stubbornly and shamelessly implies that the holy doctor should have always spoken about both predestinations, of both the good and the bad, simultaneously. Or it follows that when he argues only about the predestination of the good, he seems to deny the predestination of the bad. He clearly mentions and shows this in many places (On the Perfection of the Righteous, chapter 13).

For example, here's a testimony that says: The Psalm criticizes a certain group of people, where not a single person did good.

Psalms fourteen:three

They chose to remain children of men rather than become children of God, through whose grace a person becomes good and does good. We should interpret this goodness as mentioned where it says: God looked down from heaven upon the children of men to see if there were any who understood and sought God.

Psalms fourteen:two

So, this act of seeking God was not done by anyone, not even one, among those destined for destruction; for God's foreknowledge observed these and passed judgment.

But what is the point of using this example of God's predestination of the wicked against someone when he is eager, in his usual madness, to tell his listeners that when they hear from this holy teacher that a group is destined for destruction, they should understand the opposite, not destined? Thus, those who seek truth not in the Scripture of truth, but in the fabricators of lies, are deceived.

He further adds: Punishment is destined for sinners, but they are only foreknown, not predestined. We have discussed this enough in this and the previous chapter, clearly showing with many testimonies that sinners who remain in their sins are destined for punishment by God's just judgment.

However, it is strange in what sense or by what reason it can be understood that God has destined punishment for sinners, but has not destined the sinners for punishment. For when He destined and prepared punishment for them, He knew who would be punished and tormented.

Even this person admits they are foreknown. If God most certainly foreknew who would be justly punished and tormented by these punishments, what else did He do when He prepared the most certain punishments for the most certain people, except that He most certainly destined them for punishment? Indeed, only those will suffer whom He foreknew would suffer.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
What, then, is the difference between God's unchanging foreknowledge of those destined for punishment and His unchanging predestination of their punishment? It wasn't a concern that what He knew would certainly and justly happen, He wouldn't also predestine Himself to justly carry out.

Human laws are different because they establish certain punishments for sinners but lack the knowledge of who will sin in such a way that they justly deserve those punishments. Therefore, they can prepare and predestine just punishments, but they cannot predestine the sinners themselves, as they do not know who they are. However, if they knew for certain which individuals deserved those punishments, they could justly predestine the sinners themselves, just as they set punishments for sins.

In the examination of judgment, when they have undoubtedly found someone guilty of a capital crime, they declare the death penalty according to the laws and sentence them to death with a clear verdict. This is because their certain knowledge in judgment allows them to confidently predestine sinners to punishment, just as they predestine punishments for sins.

If this can both rightly and justly be done in human judgment, which is informed and formed by certain knowledge, such that punishments are determined for sinners and sinners are sentenced to punishments by a just and blameless judgment; and yet none of these offenders are forced to sin by the laws or judges but are justly punished because they have sinned: How much more incomparably and ineffably should we believe it is done in divine judgment, since eternal knowledge knows both the punishments justly due to sinners and the sinners themselves to whom they are due? Although He is the author or cause of no sin, He most justly predestines both the punishments, which He knows to be most just, and the sinners, who are never unknown to Him but are most intimately known by eternal truth, to eternal punishments.

Just as laws themselves, by deciding on punishment, do not compel anyone to sin, but ensure that what was done willingly and voluntarily does not go unpunished by a just condemnation.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
CHAPTER 15. In this fifteenth chapter, he offers these definitions: 1. Sins and their punishments are nothing. 2. When God foresees and predestines sins or punishments, it's as if He has not foreseen, predestined, or prepared them. The example given is Judas, who was chosen instead of not chosen, a friend instead of not a friend, a son instead of not a son. 3. Punishments are evil and therefore not from God, from whom no evil comes; God does not punish what He creates, nor does He take away the natural gifts from them. 4. Pain is the absence of health, darkness is the absence of light, silence is the absence of noise, sadness is the absence of joy, labor is the absence of rest. Similarly, sins or punishments are foreseen or predestined. 5. By feeling pain, one does not know pain itself, but rather health, which would be unknown without some concept of it. 6. The memory of health remains in the senses, but health itself resides in the substance that God created.

In these six propositions, the first one—that sins and punishments are nothing—has already been discussed as much as possible. Even if sins are said to be nothing because they lack their own substance to exist, abandoning justice, which is to sin, can only occur in some substance, either spiritual or corporeal. It's spiritual when truth, justice, and goodness are abandoned in the mind itself, and their opposites—falsehood, injustice, and malice—take hold. Although these lack a nature to subsist, they are still significant vices or weaknesses of nature, particularly of the soul, which they dominate and compromise its health and integrity. Thus, the soul, bent and oppressed by these, becomes enslaved instead of free, and sick instead of healthy, as the Lord says in the Gospel: "Everyone who commits sin is a slave to sin" (John 8:34). And the Psalmist plaintively and miserably implores: "I said, 'Lord, have mercy on me, heal my soul, for I have sinned against you'" (Psalm 41:5).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
However, because these evils begin in the mind and are often carried out through the body, the evil of the spiritual nature, which is the mind, transforms into the evil of the physical nature, which is the body itself. In this way, like a plague, it stains and corrupts the whole being at once, so that sin dominates, and the soul, serving it, brings the body into the same servitude. The members of the body become instruments of injustice for sin, through which injustice and sin have greater and more violent dominion in both.

Hence, the Apostle tells the faithful: Do not offer your members as instruments of injustice to sin; but offer yourselves to God as those who have been brought from death to life, and your members to God as instruments of righteousness Romans 6:13.

This severe and deadly affliction, which claims and wounds the whole person, can be healed and restored to health only by the one true physician, who said of himself: "Those who are well have no need of a physician, but those who are sick" Matthew 9:12, and of whom it is written: "He will save his people from their sins" Matthew 1:21.

The Apostle also says of him: "This saying is trustworthy and deserving of full acceptance: Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners" First Timothy 1:15.

Therefore, the one who constantly says and repeats that sins are nothing, what else is he trying to do, instigated by the devil, but to make them seem trivial in the hearts of the listeners? So they do not grieve, do not recognize how great the evil that holds them is, nor do they care to say with the Psalmist: "Have mercy on me, O God, according to your great mercy, and according to your abundant compassion, blot out my transgressions. Wash me thoroughly from my iniquity, and cleanse me from my sin. For I know my transgressions, and my sin is always before me" Psalm 51:1-3.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Let this deceiver be cast out from the ears and hearts of the faithful, and let us earnestly and simply implore the great mercy of God against such great misery. In the face of so many miseries, let us seek a multitude of mercies, so that iniquity may be erased, and a person may be washed from that iniquity, cleansed from the sin that made them filthy and impure.

Let them acknowledge their iniquity, and not think their sin is nothing, nor put it behind their back, but always keep it before their eyes, imploring the one who said: "I have blotted out your iniquities like a cloud, and your sins like a mist" Isaiah Forty-Four, Verse Twenty-Two.

Similarly, he tries to diminish, lighten, and annul the punishments owed to sins, asserting that they amount to nothing. Although they have no substance of their own, they are nevertheless inflicted through physical realities, such as eternal fire, the lake of sulfur, and the never-ending worms on the bodies and souls of the damned.

As they torment both souls and bodies together. Therefore, even if they do not exist substantially, they are always painful and unfortunate in the souls and bodies of those whom they torment endlessly.

Therefore, let us not delight in hearing from this wretched seducer that the punishments of sinners are nothing. But rather, let us hear what the Truth truly says: "The rich man also died and was buried in hell. And lifting up his eyes, being in torment, he saw Abraham far off, and Lazarus in his bosom; and he cried out and said: Father Abraham, have mercy on me and send Lazarus to dip the tip of his finger in water and cool my tongue, for I am tormented in this flame" Luke Sixteen, Verses Twenty-Two, Twenty-Three, and Twenty-Four.

And a little later, when pleading for his brothers, he said: "That he may testify to them, lest they also come to this place of torment" Luke Sixteen, Verse Twenty-Eight.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Witness the tragic fate of the rich man, condemned and buried in hell immediately after his death, where his soul endured torment. He suffered particularly for his sins of speech, engulfed in a consuming flame. Just as he refused even crumbs from his table to Lazarus, the sore-covered beggar at his gate, he could not get even a drop of water from a finger to ease his suffering. He pleaded for his brothers, hoping they wouldn't end up in the same place of torment.

According to the voice of Truth, hell is a place of torment, where the souls of the wretched are sent after leaving their bodies, punished in the manner of their sins, ensuring judgment without mercy for those who showed no mercy. James 2:13. Let every faithful person hear this and fear, and while there's still time, let them escape the coming wrath that the blessed John the Baptist warned about: "Who warned you to flee from the coming wrath? Therefore, produce fruits worthy of repentance." Luke 3:7-8.

The Lord Himself often refers to this place of torment as the outer darkness, the fiery furnace, and the eternal fire prepared for the devil and all the wicked, where pain never ends, leading to the eternal weeping of eyes and gnashing of teeth. Matthew 25:41.

Regarding such punishment of the condemned, the prophet Isaiah says: "Their worm will not die, and their fire will not be extinguished; and they will be an abhorrent sight to all mankind." Isaiah 66:24.

The blessed Job also pleads tearfully with God, saying: "Will not the fewness of my days soon end? Let me be, so I may weep a little for my pain; before I go and do not return to the land of darkness, covered by the shadow of death; a land of misery and darkness, where the shadow of death and disorder, and eternal horror dwell." Job 10:20-22.

 eorum ascendet in saecula saeculorum (Apoc. XIV,
11). Haec fideliter credamus, veraciter timeamus, et
hunc vaniloquum et seductorem penitus ab auribus
repellamus: Quia, sicut ait Apostolus, corrumpunt
bonos mores colloquia mala (I Cor. XV, 33). Unde et
alia Scriptura admonet dicens: Sepi aures tuas spinis,
et noli audire linguam iniquam (Eccli. XXVIII, 28). 2. Statim namque post haec illa sua regula impia
et furiosa, qua persuadere conatur ut, cum audimus
aliquid factum, intelligamus non factum, cum aliquid
dictum, intelligamus non dictum; adjungit et dicit:
Praescisse et praedestinasse Deum peccata vel poenas,
pro non praescisse, non praedestinasse, non praeparasse. Quod apertissime fidei et veritati contrarium est. Si
 enim non praescivit Deus angelorum vel hominum omnia
futura peccata, non est praescius futurorum. Et quid
jam aliud praestat nisi ut dicat iste insipiens in corde
suo, non est Deus (Psal. XIII, 1), si non praescivit poenas
quae peccantibus juste debentur, quomodo eas
et in Evangeliis et in caeteris Scripturis tam assidue,
tam graviter, tam terribiliter comminatur. Sed dicit
iste: Quia peccata vel poenae nihil sunt, eo quod substantiam
per se existendi non habeant. Et ideo quod
nihil est Deum nec scire nec praescire potuisse. Quasi
Deo ignotum sit quidquid non est, et quod ipse
essentialiter et naturaliter esse non fecit: cum
ille omnipotenti scientia et praescientia sua sicut
novit omnia quae fecit, sic etiam noverit quae non
 fecit : et, sicut novit quae esset facturus, ita semper
noverit quae non esset facturus.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Thus, He was certainly aware of what He wanted to exist and what He did not. Without a doubt, He knew it was a great evil for the nature of angels or humans to exist in a corrupted state due to sin and to be endlessly tormented by punitive punishment.

Regarding the claim that God did not predestine punishments or sins, it's true for sins because He didn't predestine them, except for what He Himself was to do. These actions are indeed good and just. However, concerning punishments, it is utterly false, as He not only predestined them but also prepared them. As the Lord Himself says in the Gospel: "Depart from me, you cursed, into the eternal fire prepared for the devil and his angels" (Matthew 25:41).

He adds the example of Judas in a rather absurd and incongruous manner, as shown above. He immediately adds, saying: "Punishments are evils and therefore not from God, from whom evil does not come." This contradicts what God Himself testifies through the prophet, saying: "I am the Lord, creating peace and bringing evil" (Isaiah 45:7). And elsewhere it is written: "Shall there be evil in a city which the Lord has not done?" (Amos 3:6). And again: "Good and evil, life and death, poverty and wealth, are from God" (Sirach 11:14).

Therefore, it must be faithfully discerned that there is a difference between evil, meaning vice, which is contrary to good and is not from God, but rather invented by the devil or committed by man; and another kind of evil, which signifies some affliction, either temporal or eternal: such as famine, pestilence, hostilities, devastations, death, and those punishments that are called eternal; all of which are from God, because they are prepared or inflicted only by His just disposition and judgment.

However, anyone claiming that those eternal punishments are not from God must be compelled to say from whom they think they are, whether from the devil, for whom they are prepared, from humans, who are to be tortured there together, or from no one, as if they exist coeternally with God without any author.
chunks.original_latin:
Ita namque et
quae vellet esse, et quae nollet esse, nullatenus potuit
ignorare: et quod noluit habere naturam vel
substantiam existendi, novit sine dubio magnum
malum esse naturae subsistendi angelicae vel humanae,
cum peccato in deterius commutatur, et poenali
supplicio sine fine cruciatur. Quod autem dicit Deum non praedestinasse poenas
vel peccata, de peccatis utique verum est, quia non
praedestinavit, nisi quae fuerat ipse facturus. Quae
utique omnia et bona et justa sunt. De poenis autem
manifeste falsissimum est, quas non solum praedestinavit,
sed etiam praeparavit. Sicut ipse Dominus in
Evangelio dicit: Discedite a me, maledicti, in ignem
 aeternum qui paratus est diabolo et angelis ejus
(Matth. II, 41). Adjungit exemplum Judae satis absurde
et incongrue, sicut supra ostensum est. Et statim subjungit dicens: Poenas mala esse ideoque
non a Deo, a quo malum non sit. Contra illud
quod ipse Deus per prophetam testatur dicens:
Ego Dominus, faciens pacem et creans malum (Isa. XLV, 7). Unde et alibi scriptum est: Si erit malum
in civitate quod Dominus non fecit (Amos III, 6). Et
iterum: Bona et mala vita et mors, paupertas et honestas,
a Deo sunt (Eccli. XI, 14). Et ideo fideliter
discernendum, aliud esse malum, id est vitium,
contrarium bono, quod utique non est a Deo, sed
vel a diabolo inventum, vel ab homine commissum;
aliud vero esse malum, quod significat aliquam afflictionem
 vel temporalem vel aeternam: ut sunt fames,
pestilentia, hostilitates, vastationes, mors, et
ipsa quae appellantur aeterna supplicia; quae utique
omnia a Deo sunt: quia non nisi justa ejus dispositione,
et justo ejus judicio praeparantur vel inferuntur. Iste autem, qui poenas illas aeternas a Deo non
esse confirmat, compellandus est, ut dicat a quo eas

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
He begins by stating that God does not punish what He has created, nor does He take away their natural gifts. To delve deeper, it's evident that God created rational beings, both angelic and human, with specific attributes: angels have spirits without bodies, while humans possess both a soul and a body. The natural gifts given by God to these rational beings are crucial to understand, as He has elaborated on this before.

These gifts include the fact that both human and angelic minds naturally possess memory, understanding, will, being, knowing, and wanting. This means they naturally remember, understand, love themselves, exist, recognize themselves, and desire self-love. He also emphasizes that free will is inherently a natural gift from the Creator, as previously demonstrated through His words.

Therefore, he asserts that God does not punish His creations, neither the angelic spirits in evil angels nor the spirit and body in condemned humans. But then, how can eternal fire be prepared for the devil and his angels if angelic spirits are not to be punished by that fire? Similarly, how does he address humans with the words: "But rather fear Him who can destroy both soul and body in hell" Matthew 10:28, if neither the soul nor the body, which God created, are punished in hell's torment?

Indeed, both spirits and bodies will face punishment in hell, as true faith holds, and as Truth itself confirms: not because God created them, but because they committed acts that God did not create, things He detests and does not leave unpunished, specifically sins. These sins cannot exist or be punished without their perpetrators, as they do not exist independently; they are present in the corrupted minds of angels or humans, enacted by them, attached to them, and condemned with them and within them.

Thus, it holds true what Scripture declares in praise of God: "For you love all things that exist, and you hate nothing you have made" Wisdom 11:25. And as the Lord states: "He who can destroy both soul and body in hell" Matthew 10:28.
chunks.original_latin:
Subjungit post haec dicens: Deum non punire quae fecit
nec ab eis naturalia munera tollere. Quod ut diligentius
consideretur, manifestum est illa quae Deus fecit in
creatura rationali angelica vel humana, esse in angelis
spiritus sine corpore, esse in hominibus animam et
 corpus: Naturalia vero munera quae istis rationalibus
creaturis naturaliter Deus dedit, illa vult iste intelligi
de quibus superius multa locutus est, id est quod
habeat in se naturaliter mens humana sive angelica,
memoriam, intelligentiam, voluntatem, esse, nosse,
velle, ut naturaliter meminerit sui, intelligat se, diligat
se, naturaliter habeat esse ut existat, nosse
 ut agnoscat se, velle ut amet se. Liberum etiam arbitrium
naturale tantummodo donum Creatoris asserit
iste, sicut supra satis suis verbis ostendit. Dicit
itaque Deum non punire quae fecit; id est nec spiritum
angelicum in angelis malignis: nec spiritum et
corpus in hominibus damnandis. Et quomodo ignem
aeternum dicit paratum esse diabolo et angelis ejus, si
illo igne spiritus angelici puniendi non sunt? Quomodo
etiam alibi hominibus et de hominibus dicit:
Sed potius eum timete qui potest et animam et corpus
perdere in gehennam (Matth. X, 28), si illo cruciatu
gehennae nec anima, nec corpus, quae utraque Deus
fecit punientur? Sed vere punientur et spiritus et
corpora in gehenna, sicut vera fides credit, sicut
ipsa Veritas testatur: non quia ea Deus fecit, sed
 quia ipsa fecerunt quae Deus non fecit, et quae Deus
odit, et quae impunita esse non sinit, id est peccata. Quae sine auctoribus suis neque esse, neque puniri
possunt: neque enim per se subsistunt, ut in seipsis
puniantur, sed insunt mentibus depravatis angelicis
sive humanis ab ipsis commissa, ipsis adhaerentia, et
cum ipsis atque in ipsis damnanda. Ita et illud verum est quod in Dei laudibus Scriptura
dicit: Diliges enim omnia quae sunt, et nihil odisti eorum
quae fecisti (Sap. XI, 25). Et quod Dominus ait: Qui
potest et animam, et corpus perdere in gehennam (Matth. X, 28).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
He loves His creation because it is made by Him, but He hates it when it becomes corrupted. As it is written: "You hate all who do wrong, you will destroy all who speak falsehood: The Lord abhors the bloodthirsty and deceitful man" Psalm Five, verses five to six.

Therefore, the prophet also says about some: "And they became as detestable as those they loved" Hosea Nine, verse ten; and again: "God likewise hates the wicked and their wickedness" Wisdom Fourteen, verse nine.

He loves everything that exists and hates nothing He has made; yet, He does not let the corrupted aspects of rational creatures go unpunished. It is just that the nature which chose not to be blessed under God, but desired to be free, is arranged and punished accordingly: so that what did not wish to submit willingly might be subjected unwillingly; and what could have been blessed forever there might become endlessly miserable here.

It is impossible to escape the hand of God, as Scripture itself says, Tobit Thirteen, verse two, to whom those who did not want to submit willingly must submit out of necessity.

What benefit is there for these rational natures if, in eternal damnation, natural gifts are not taken away? They are left with them not for happiness, but for the accumulation of torment, so they remember their eternal pain and guilty conscience: they may understand they are always miserable, always condemned; they may love themselves, so they grieve more deeply for the loss of what they love without end.

What kind of free will is there for those who cannot abandon their wickedness, nor do anything good anymore? As Scripture says: "Whatever your hand finds to do, do it with all your might, for in the grave, where you are going, there is neither working nor planning nor knowledge nor wisdom" Ecclesiastes Nine, verse ten.

What good is it for them to exist unhappily forever, to know their damnation, to want but be unable to escape their punishment?
chunks.original_latin:
Diligit enim creaturam suam, in quantum natura
est, et ab eo condita est. Et odit eam in quantum
vitiata est. Unde scriptum est: Odisti omnes qui
operantur iniquitatem, perdes omnes qui loquuntur
 mendacium: Virum sanguinum et dolosum abominabitur
Dominus (Psal. V, 7, 8). Unde et de quibusdam
dicit propheta: Et facti sunt abominabiles, sicut ea
quae dilexerunt (Ose. IX, 10); et iterum: Similiter
autem et odio sunt Deo impius et impietas ejus (Sap. XIV, 9). Ita ergo diligit omnia quae sunt, et nihil odit
eorum quae fecit; ut tamen haec in creatura rationali
vitiata, depravata atque corrupta, impunita et inordinata
esse non sinat. Juste enim ordinatur et punitur
in poenis natura quae non sub Deo et ex Deo
voluit esse beata, sed in se, et per se, velut libera
esse concupivit: ut quae noluit subjici volens, subjiciatur
nolens; et quae illic potuit esse semper beata,
hic sine fine misera efficiatur. Quia manum Dei
(sicut ipsa Scriptura dicit) effugere impossibile est
 (Tob. XIII, 2), cui necesse est, ut quae noluit voluntate,
necessitate subdatur. Quid autem ipsis naturis rationalibus proderit, si
in illa aeterna damnatione constitutis naturalia illa,
ut iste dicit, munera non erunt sublata? Cum ad
nullum beatitudinis fructum, sed ad solum tormentorum
cumulum in eis relinquenda esse manifeste
 intelligantur, ut meminerint sui, ad aeternum dolorem
malae conscientiae: intelligant se semper miseras,
semper esse damnatas; diligant se, ut magis
doleant sine fine perire quod amant. Liberum vero
arbitrium  quomodo aut quale in illis erit, quorum
voluntas nec iniquitatem suam poterit jam deserere,
nec bonum aliquid ulterius operari? sicut Scriptura
dicit: Quodcunque potest manus tua facere, instanter
operare: quia nec opus, nec ratio, nec sapientia, nec
scientia erunt apud inferos, quo tu properas (Eccle. IX,
10). Quid illis proderit semper esse infeliciter, scire
damnationem suam, velle nec posse evadere poenam
suam?

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Everything given here to act well and earn the Lord's grace will, in that place, become a punishment rather than comfort wherever any trace remains. However, if a rational creature's memory, intelligence, and will are directed not towards themselves but towards the Creator, what role will memory serve for those completely abandoned by God and separated from the eternal and true light? There, no one will be able to say: "I remembered God, and I was delighted." (Psalm seventy-seven, verse four) And the scripture will be fulfilled that says: "For in death there is no one who remembers you." (Psalm six, verse six) There will be no enlightenment of understanding to recognize, seek, or find God. There will be no loving devotion to love, desire, or enjoy God. For they will be in outer darkness, away from that light, enjoying none of its illumination. And that dreadful night, about which our Lord, the true light, says: "As long as I am in the world, I am the light of the world. The night is coming, when no one can work." (John nine, verses four to five) Therefore, as long as He is in the world through enlightening grace, He is the light for those liberated from their darkness. But when He withdraws this grace of illumination from those condemned to eternal blindness, what will remain for them but dreadful night, perpetual night, in which no one can work?

Furthermore, if we consider even the senses of the body, which are natural gifts from the Creator, what good will sight be where there is no view of light? Or if there is sight for a time, it will not bring comfort but greater pain, so they may see some good they can no longer have or earn. Just as that rich man, condemned to those same infernal punishments, could see Abraham and Lazarus for a moment (Luke sixteen, verse twenty-three), but it was to increase his pain, not for the comfort of rescue. Although it is believed this happens before the final judgment according to the hidden plan of the Creator, it is read that nothing like this will happen afterward. What will hearing do there, where there will always be a dreadful noise and countless sad groans?
chunks.original_latin:
Omnia ergo quae hic data sunt ad usum bene
agendi, ad gratiam Domini promerendam, ibi quantulacunque
eorum vestigia remanserint, ad supplicium
 valebunt, non ad solatium. Si autem rationalis
creaturae memoria, intelligentia, voluntas, non ad
se, sed ad Conditorem referantur, quid jam illis penitus
a Deo desertis, et ab aeterno illo et vero lumine
separatis, quid in illis, inquam, aget memoria, ubi
nemo dicere poterit: Memor fui Dei, et delectatus sum? (Ps. LXXVI, 4.) et ubi implebitur quod scriptum est:
Quoniam non est in morte qui memor sit tui (Psal. VI,
6). Nulla erit intelligentiae illuminatio, qua Deus
agnoscatur, quaeratur, inveniatur. Nulla dilectionis
pietas, qua Deus ametur, desideretur, fruatur. Ipsae
enim erunt tenebrae exteriores extra illud lumen jam
positis, cujus nulla illuminatione perfruentur: Et
illa nox horrenda, de qua ipsum verum lumen Dominus
noster dicit: Quandiu in mundo sum, lux sum
 mundi. Venit nox quando nemo potest operari (Joan. IX, 4, 5). Quandiu ergo in mundo est per illuminantem
gratiam, lux est mundi a suis tenebris liberati. Cum autem hanc suae illuminationis gratiam
subtraxerit aeterna caecitate damnatis, quid eis aliud
remanebit nisi nox horrenda, nox perpetua, in qua
nemo possit operari? Si autem etiam de sensibus corporis, qui et ipsi
sunt utique naturalia munera Conditoris, tale aliquid
consideretur , quid ibi proderit visus, ubi nullus
erit lucis aspectus? Aut si ad horam fuerit, non ad consolationem,
sed ad vehementiorem dolorem valebit:
ut scilicet videant boni aliquid, quod jam habere aut
promereri non possint. Sicut et dives ille eisdem infernalibus
poenis damnatus, Abraham et Lazarum ad
 horam videre potuit (Luc. XVI, 23), sed ad augmentum
doloris, non ad solatium ereptionis. Licet hoc
ante ultimum illud judicium juxta occultam dispositionem
Conditoris fieri credendum sit, postea vero

ubi semper horrendus fragor, et tristis atque innumerabilis
audietur gemitus?

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Consider the sense of smell, as God warns through the prophet: There will always be a stench instead of a sweet aroma. Isaiah 3:24.

Think about taste, where eternal hunger and thirst will prevail. As clearly stated in Revelation concerning the city of the devil, representing all the condemned: "In one day her plagues will come, death and mourning and famine; for mighty is the Lord God who judges her." Revelation 18:8.

Regarding thirst and the tongue continually burning, the Gospel clearly describes the rich man's condemnation. And what of the touch of the whole body, where there will be no delight or sweetness, but only eternal pain, burning, and torture?

What benefit is there in claiming, as if to comfort fools, that God does not punish what He created, nor takes away natural gifts? Since He eternally punishes corrupted nature for its wrongs, and if any natural gifts remain in damnation, they only serve to increase the punishment, not provide consolation.

What does it mean to say: Pain is the absence of health, darkness is the absence of light, silence is the absence of noise, sadness is the absence of joy, labor is the absence of rest; thus, sins or punishments are foreseen or predestined?

If he intended to suggest that, just as we know pain through the absence of health, darkness through the absence of light, silence through the absence of noise, sadness through the absence of joy, labor through the absence of rest, so God knows or predestines sins through the absence of justice and punishments through the absence of happiness, what could be more terrifying than such a belief, where divine power is equated to human weakness?
chunks.original_latin:
Quid olfactus, ubi juxta
 quod Deus per prophetam comminatur: Erit semper
pro suavi odore fetor? (Isa. III, 24.) Quid gustus, ubi
aeterna erit fames et sitis? Sicut de civitate diaboli,
id est de tota illa multitudine damnatorum aperte in
Apocalypsi scriptum est: Quia in una die venient
plagae ejus, et mors et luctus, et fames: quia fortis est
Deus, qui judicavit illam (Apoc. XVIII, 8). De siti autem
et lingua semper ardente, in damnatione illius
divitis aperte Evangelium declarat. Quid totius corporis
tactus, ubi nulla ejus poterit esse jucunditas,
nulla suavitas, sed sempiternus sentietur dolor, aeterna
exustio, aeterna excruciatio? Quid ergo prodest quod
iste dicit, velut ad consolationem stultorum, Deum non
punire quae fecit, nec ab eis naturalia munera tollere? Cum et puniat aeternaliter naturam vitiatam pro his
 quae male gessit: et si aliquid naturalium munerum in
illa damnatione eam habere permittet, totum valeat ad
supplicii augmentum, non ad consolationis solatium. Quid est autem quod addit: Dolorem esse sanitatis
absentiam, tenebras lucis, silentium clamoris, tristitiam
gaudii, laborem quietis: sic praesciri vel praedestinari
peccata vel poenas. Si enim in his verbis hoc
persuadere voluit, quod, sicut nos per sanitatis absentiam
cognoscimus in nobis dolorem, et per absentiam
lucis cognoscimus tenebras, et per absentiam vocis
cognoscimus silentium, et per absentiam gaudii sentimus
tristitiam, per absentiam quietis sentimus laborem,
sic Deus praescierit peccata, vel praedestinaverit
poenas, ut et peccata non nisi privatione justitiae
scire aut praescire potuerit; et poenas, nisi privatione
 beatitudinis non agnoverit, vel praedestinaverit; si,
inquam, ita sensit, ita persuadere voluit, quid tali
sensu horribilius, quo divina virtus humanae infirmitati
adaequatur?

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
God's power, unchanging and constant, comprehends everything within itself and doesn't need to seek knowledge from outside. It doesn't distinguish between things that exist and those that don't, because it understands the former not by their presence and the latter not by the absence of others.

Instead, with eternal and unchanging wisdom, it equally perceives what it wills to be and what it doesn't. It doesn't recognize sins through the absence of justice; rather, being the highest form of justice, it consistently sees within itself what is dissonant or discordant with it.

Similarly, it doesn't understand punishments by the lack of happiness; being the ultimate happiness, it sees within itself the depth of punishment into which those who stray from its peace must fall.

Therefore, it perceives anything at odds with justice not through justice's absence but within justice itself; it doesn't identify punishments through the absence of happiness but within happiness, it sees the pain and toil faced by those separated from its peace.

Furthermore, it adds: It is not the pain itself that reveals suffering, but the health itself, which wouldn't be known without a clear understanding of it.

These words suggest that the pain of eternal punishments can't be truly recognized by the suffering soul because the pain itself lacks substance. Therefore, since it is essentially nothing, it isn't recognized by the sufferer; rather, health is recognized in contrast, as it naturally exists in the body and opposes pain.

This health would not be known to someone entirely consumed by suffering unless its knowledge remained in memory. To make such seemingly absurd ideas appear validated by reason, it adds: The memory of health stays in the senses, but it truly resides in the substance created by God.
chunks.original_latin:
Dei etenim virtus, semper eodem
modo se habens, omnia novit in se, nec indiget ut
aliquid noverit extra se: nec aliter novit facta,
aliter non facta, quia nec illa novit per eorum praesentiam,
nec ista per aliarum rerum absentiam;
sed aeterna et incommutabili scientia sua aequaliter
videt quid voluerit esse, et quid esse noluerit: nec
privatione justitiae cognoscit peccata; sed, cum sit
ipse summa justitia, in ipsa  incommutabiliter
videt quid ab ea dissonet vel discordet. Similiter
non per absentiam beatitudinis poenas cognoscit,
sed cum sit ipse summa beatitudo, in semetipso incommutabiliter
 videt in quantam poenarum profunditatem
mergendi sunt qui ab ejus tranquillitate
discedunt. Atque ita non privatione justitiae, sed in
ipsa justitia videt quidquid ab ea dissentit: nec privatione
beatitudinis agnoscit poenas; sed, in ipsa
beatitudine, videt quid doloris et laboris incurrat qui
ab ejus tranquillitate separatur. Adhuc addit et dicit: Dolendo non ipsum dolorem,
sed ipsam sanitatem nosci, quam non noscet, si de illa
notionem quamdam non haberet. In quibus verbis affirmare
videtur dolorem illum aeternarum poenarum non
posse nosci, id est agnosci, ab animo patientis, eo
quod ipse dolor nullam habeat substantiam in se
existendi vel subsistendi. Et ideo cum substantialiter
nihil sit, non ipse agnoscatur ab illo qui dolet,
sed potius ex ejus comparatione sanitas agnoscitur;
quae in corpore naturaliter aliquid est, et quae ipsi
dolori contraria est. Quam sanitatem nullatenus
nosset qui totus dolet in poenis, nisi ejus notitia in
memoria remaneret. Et ut haec tam absurda et stulta, velut ratione
quadam reddita, confirmare videatur, subjungit et
 dicit: Recordationem sanitatis in sensibus remanere,
ipsam vero in illa substantia quam Deus creavit residere.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
This might indicate that in the experience of ongoing suffering, pain itself reminds us of health, through the senses by which the body or soul feels that pain. Even in that condemnation, this health can be understood because the essence of a human, created by God, isn't destroyed or erased in the eternal existence of both soul and body. Instead, it endures eternally as a sort of complete health. It seems that all this is expressed so that through that eternal pain, the understanding, memory, and even the health of those who are to be tormented, are not said to be lost.

On the contrary, all these elements—the understanding and memory of health in a mind that suffers forever, and the preservation of a nature that is indestructible—do not bring any grace or joy of salvation. Instead, they add to the weight of the pain. Thus, the condemned suffer not only in body and soul but also through the remembrance and awareness of the good health that is completely lost. They are punished by that memory and awareness. Therefore, it seems absurd to call it health amidst eternal and overwhelming pains when what might appear as signs of health are actually sources of pain. As long as the one being tortured continues to exist, the torments themselves never end.
chunks.original_latin:
Per quod fortassis hoc intelligi vult quod in
sensibus in illa damnatione semper dolentis, velut
ex commonitione ipsius doloris, fiat recordatio sanitatis,
in sensibus videlicet, quibus vel corpus vel
anima ipsos dolores sentiet; ipsam vero sanitatem
in illa damnatione ita posse intelligi, quia substantia
hominis, quem Deus creavit, et in animae et in
corporis perpetuitate non consumitur, non deletur,
sed velut quadam suae plenitudinis sanitate aeternaliter
durat. Quae omnia idcirco dicere videtur, ut
per illum sempiternum poenarum dolorem, nec cognitionem
sanitatis, nec ejus recordationem, nec
ipsam sanitatem in eis qui torquendi sunt, asserat
 perire. Cum e contrario omnia ista, id est et cognitio
et memoria sanitatis in animo semper dolentis,
et conservatio illa naturae nunquam delendae, non

CHAPTER 16.

In the sixteenth chapter, he introduces twelve definitions, stating:

1. No nature is punished by nature itself. 2. The punishments of sins are nothing other than the sins themselves. 3. In eternal fire, the punishment is simply the absence of blessed happiness. 4. Everyone there naturally possesses an innate understanding and desire for the missing happiness. The wretched will understand and know happiness and truth, and thus they are not truly wretched, nor are they punished. 5. In the devil and wicked people, only the perversity of their own will is punished; it is the will that sins, not nature. 6. In the first man, it was not the nature of humanity that sinned, but the individual will of each person. 7. If this nature were to sin, then since it is one, the whole would certainly perish. 8. Therefore, in no one is nature punished, for it is from God and does not sin; instead, the willful and lecherous actions are punished. 9. So, in the wicked, punishments are not endured because of what God created, but because of what pride has found in a faulty manner. 10. The lust of a perverse will is tormented when it is not allowed to have what it wrongly or unworthily desires. 11. No evil comes from any good. 12. Whoever here alters the free choice of will, which is the gift of natural intelligence—that is, the sharpness of the mind for disgraceful use—justly loses the enjoyment of the truth's integrity there and cannot avoid the darkness of eternal ignorance.

In these words, what he initially stated—that no nature is punished by nature itself—appears to be said because every nature, created by the good author, God, is good as nature. For example, the nature of the soul or the body is good; similarly, the nature of fire, as nature, is also good.

Since both are naturally good, he seems to rightly say and define that no nature is punished by another nature; because evidently, two goods, according to his understanding, cannot be contrary to each other, lest one good nature becomes a punishment for another good nature.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
This obvious deception aims to undermine the strongest truth of faith in the hearts of listeners, a truth that all believers confidently hold and confess: that the nature of eternal fire, the nature of evil spirits, and the nature of lost humans—that is, their souls and bodies—are to be condemned, punished, and tortured endlessly by His just and eternal judgment. He who can destroy both soul and body in hell, and who, after having killed, has the power to cast into hell, as mentioned in Matthew 10:28.

It's not only about those eternal punishments where the angelic and human nature will be tortured by the eternal fire. The fire, which was given to humans here by the Creator's goodness for comfort, will be turned into punishment by the judge's just severity. Faith is not just about these future events; it is also a common understanding that nature is never punished except by nature.

Just as the nature of the body is punished either by itself, like when it loses health and succumbs to weakness and languor, with its health diminished, and it suffers from languor, or by the deprivation of another nature that supports or comforts it. For instance, when food, drink, light, or clothing are taken away, the body wastes away and suffers from hunger and thirst, is afflicted by darkness, or tormented by cold. Or it's punished by the nature of another thing: like the bodies of criminals are punished by whips, swords, and various tortures, imposed on them as a penalty by other natures.

Given these facts, and that nature is never punished except by itself, by the removal of another nature's utility, or by inflicted violence, how can anyone claim that no nature is punished by nature?

So that, as far as it is in his power, he may destroy the truth of eternal punishments; where both the nature of spirits and the nature of bodies are judged according to the evangelical and apostolic truth: 'The nature of the eternal fire shall torment them day and night, forever and ever' (Rev. 14:10).
<break time="500ms"/>
If, however, he says this because natures do not harm one another except by their qualities, as, for example, fire and water, whose proper qualities are that water is naturally wet and fire is naturally dry, and therefore the moisture of water can extinguish fire and the dryness of fire can consume the moisture of water—so that these do not seem to oppose each other by their nature but by their qualities being contrary to one another—if he says this, I say, let him know that in our faith there is no difference whether it is said that natures punish natures or that natures, by their inherent qualities, are a punishment to each other.
<break time="500ms"/>
For both were created by the one Creator, that is, both nature and the quality inherent to nature. And therefore, both together are rightly called one nature, though distinguished by the wise Creator by their respective qualities. Furthermore, even though the nature of an angelic or human spirit is immortal, nevertheless, by the power of the Creator and just avenger God, it will be bound painfully and eternally to that corporeal and eternal fire, just as here by the same power of the supreme Creator the human spirit is bound to an earthly body and cannot be released except by His will and judgment who bound it.
<break time="500ms"/>
The nature also of the human body in that eternal fire of the damned will be so painfully immortal that it will never be dissolved by death to escape enduring eternal punishments. It will be both passible (capable of suffering) and incorruptible, so that it may be afflicted without end by every kind of pain, torment, and punishment. For Scripture, in terrifying terms, warns against this punishment, saying, 'Humble your spirit greatly, for the vengeance on the flesh of the impious is fire and worms' (Ecclus. 7:19).

The sins themselves are the punishment for the sinning souls because they corrupt and violate the soul's health, making the conscience miserable, troubled, and full of anxieties. Moreover, for these sins, other severe punishments are immediately inflicted in the present, as mentioned earlier.

Blessed Moses testifies clearly in Deuteronomy about all these present punishments that continuously strike and punish sinners' souls, saying about the almighty God: Showing mercy to thousands who love Him. These are the punishments for sinners, whether they're suffering due to their own sins or being abandoned by God, deservedly so. These penalties are immediately inflicted in the present, or through external punishments like various scourges divinely imposed on sinners now, or in the eternal torment of damnation reserved for the end.

Since Scripture testifies so clearly and the faith of the Church holds this undeniably, let those misled by the deceptions of this vain man hear the Apostle's stern warning to all the faithful: "Let no one deceive you with empty words; for because of these things the wrath of God comes upon the sons of disobedience." (Ephesians 5:6).

Saint Jerome adds to the Apostle's words, explaining: This holy teacher refutes the ancient heretics' error on this matter, dismantling the fraudulent lies and fabrications of this man with apostolic truth.

Yet, this man dares to suggest even more detestable things, saying: In eternal fire, the only punishment is the absence of blessed happiness.

It's reasonable to ask why evil angels and wicked humans are to be sent into eternal fire if they will suffer no punishments or torments. Is the reason simply that those who now dwell in the air or on the earth will have a new dwelling in the fire, where, as it's written about the three holy boys condemned in the Babylonian furnace, the fire had no power over their bodies, their hair wasn't singed, and the smell of fire didn't pass over them?

And what remains now, except that, as Scripture says about them: because the angel of the Lord descended with Azariah and his companions into the furnace, drove the flame out, and made the middle like a blowing wind of dew, so the fire didn't touch them at all, nor did it distress them or cause any harm (Daniel 3:49-50), this man, in his astonishing madness, strives to affirm the same.

Imagine, if it were possible, a miracle among the great wonders and signs of divine power—a countless multitude of fallen angels and lost souls surrounded by vast, raging flames, yet untouched by the fire, as if it forgot its power, leaving the devil and his angels unharmed. Who has ever heard of such a thing, or who could endure the madness of such great impiety?

If there were no punishment in the eternal fire for the damned, then there would be no glory in the eternal reward for the righteous either. The one who promised this glory with the words: "Come, you blessed of my Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world" Matthew 25:34, also threatened the punishment by saying: "Depart from me, you cursed, into the eternal fire prepared for the devil and his angels" Matthew 25:41, and he added with unchanging truth about both: "Then they will go away into eternal punishment, but the righteous into eternal life" Matthew 25:46.

If we ask what the kingdom prepared for the righteous from the foundation of the world is, let us faithfully hear that it is eternal life. And if we ask what we should believe about the fire into which the wicked and angels are sent, let us likewise faithfully hear that it is eternal punishment. There is no greater glory than eternal life, nor greater punishment than eternal suffering: the former for those placed in the kingdom, the latter for those damned in the eternal fire.

Blessed John openly testifies about this punishment of eternal fire in Revelation, saying: "They were thrown into the lake of fire and sulfur, and they will be tormented day and night forever and ever" Revelation 20:9, 10. And elsewhere: "And the smoke of their torment will rise forever and ever" Revelation 19:3.

Therefore, in the eternal fire, neither angels nor humans who are condemned will ever find rest or freedom from punishment. As the Truth states: "They will be tormented day and night forever and ever; and the smoke of their torment will rise forever and ever."

This punishment also applies to those like the rich man dressed in purple who was condemned, about whom Scripture says: "They spend their days in prosperity, and in an instant go down to the grave." Just as it is written about him, they will immediately begin to suffer torment, be tortured in flames, and be assigned to a place of eternal torment.

This person, as we've heard, often says when someone challenges him with words grounded in the truth of faith: "What do you want? Reason defeats you." So, what is this reasoning that lacks true reason, is alien to all truth, and is filled with the spirit of impious error and fanaticism? It encourages people to abandon the truth of Christ and follow his fantastical and demonic shadows.

But when he claims that those condemned in eternal fire feel no punishment other than the absence of blessed happiness, he oddly suggests a form of happiness for them and says: "In that absence of blessed happiness, there is no one who does not have naturally within themselves an understanding and desire for the happiness that is absent."

He further claims that the miserable will have an understanding and knowledge of happiness and truth, and therefore are not truly miserable or punished. With these words, he tries to assert that all who are in damnation, which he perceives as merely the absence of the happiness the saints enjoy, will naturally have an inherent understanding and desire for this happiness, which they will not possess.

Emphasizing this, he insists they will have knowledge and understanding of truth and happiness, and therefore, the miserable are not truly miserable, nor are they punished.

notionem atque scientiam, ac per hoc non esse miseros

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
In this way, by possessing understanding, knowledge, and a desire for happiness and truth—which they lack and therefore are damned—they somehow won't be miserable or punished. Because in lacking happiness and fulfillment, they can be called miserable and damned; yet, because they have awareness, knowledge, and desire for happiness and truth, which are absent from them, they could also be said to not be miserable or damned.

But the faith of the Church truly understands that there's no greater damnation for a rational being than being separated from God; not being enlightened by His light, visited by His grace, saved by His liberation, or blessed by His vision and contemplation.

Therefore, angels and humans damned by such misfortune, utterly excluded from happiness and truth, even if they felt no external punishment or torment, what benefit is it for them to have understanding, awareness, and desire for happiness and truth, as this promises them? When this would serve more as a torment for them, to have even the slightest awareness of truth but never deserve its foresight; to have any desire for eternal happiness, yet never rejoice in its possession.

So let it not be believed that those completely separated from God are not the most miserable, or that those utterly excluded from eternal happiness are not punished. Truly miserable and truly damned forever will be those who are always exiles from truth and happiness, not illuminated by any light of truth, not comforted by any joy of happiness.

And yet, beyond this complete and utmost misery, there will also be endless external punishment for them, so they are tormented internally by the misery of conscience and externally by the fire of hell. The Psalmist briefly shows both aspects, saying to the Judge of the living and the dead: "Your hand will find all your enemies; your right hand will find all who hate you."

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
You'll make them like a fiery furnace in your presence: the Lord, in His wrath, will disturb them, and fire will consume them. (Psalm 21:9-10)

Blessed Augustine explains this clearly and thoroughly with these words:

Given this, we need to carefully consider what, according to the true faith, we should think about those who will face eternal damnation. We should understand from the state of those eternally condemned how much the Lord is willing to grant; why there can be no correction there, and why liberation from it is impossible.

First, it's important to note that the Catholic faith firmly believes that no one who dies can gain any merit that would allow them to leave the wickedness they died in or change for the better.

Even though some, as the faith itself acknowledges, receive forgiveness of sins after death through the prayers, offerings, and alms of the Church, and are purified by purgatorial punishments to be worthy of eternal happiness, this is not due to any new merit after death. Instead, it is because of the merit they gained before death. Their life in the body was such that they deserve to be helped by these remedies even after death.

The Apostle clearly shows this when he says: "For we must all appear before the judgment seat of Christ, so that each one may receive what is due for the things done while in the body, whether good or bad." (Second Corinthians 5:10)

Indeed, the deeds of the body, whether good or bad, are what the soul did while it was in the body. Just as it couldn't do any good or evil before it existed, it also cannot do any good or evil after leaving the body, since the time for action and deeds ends with the death of the body.
chunks.original_latin:

ignis in tempore vultus tui: Dominus in ira sua

Quae cum ita sint, quaerendum nobis est sollicite

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Even those burdened only by the guilt of original sin, who leave this world without a saving remedy, are condemned due to their own actions. They have inherited that original debt with their bodies, which makes them deserving of eternal damnation.

As the Apostle says, everyone must appear before the judgment seat of Christ, so that each person may receive according to what they have done in the body. Second Corinthians 5:10. This means what they have done or incurred while in the body.

They could not have done anything before having a body, nor can they act after losing it, as there will be no time for action, only for receiving the consequences.

It is certain in our faith that none of those destined for eternal damnation on the day of judgment have brought any merit from this life that could free them from such destruction. If any had prepared such merit in this life, they would not be handed over to eternal damnation by the just judge.

Those who face this damnation undoubtedly carry with them such merit that, by just judgment, they will never be absolved or deemed worthy of freedom.

The reason damnation is both just and eternal is that there will be no chance to correct past wrongs or improve future ones. There will be regret for past evils and a desire for liberation, but it will have no effect.

So, where is the mercy of God, who remains unmoved by long and intense repentance or the pleas of the damned?

How can He be just if He overlooks this? How can He not consider such deep pain and affliction of His creatures?

What, I ask, is the reason that nothing wholesome or acceptable can be done there? If it could be done, it would never be rejected by such great mercy or justice.
chunks.original_latin:

; quia in corpore utique et cum corpore

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Why is it impossible for them to have faith, hope, and love unless God completely withdraws from them, leaving no special grace? Without this grace, they can't repent for the past or hope for the future through genuine belief, hope, and love. Since they are fundamentally separated from God and preserved for eternal punishment only by His almighty power, they can never share in the Holy Spirit.

Even if they have some faith, whether from memories of what they heard or learned, or from the fear and revelation of present events: Specifically, when God's power and authority, and that of His Christ, are revealed to all, both in the majesty of His judgment, the eternal reward of the just, and the eternal damnation of the wicked. These truths will be known by everyone, confessed by all, and worshipped by all, even if only out of sheer terror.

At that time, all creation will be perfectly subject to the Creator, either out of devotion, as with holy angels and humans, or out of necessity, as with evil angels and wicked humans. This will fulfill what the Apostle quoted from the prophet, saying: "As I live, says the Lord God, every knee will bow to me, and every tongue will confess to God" (Romans 14:11).

Therefore, what Scripture predicted about the wicked will also happen during this judgment: They will speak among themselves, repenting and grieving from the distress of their spirit: "These are the ones we once mocked and scorned. We foolishly considered their lives madness and their end without honor; how are they now counted among the children of God, and their lot among the saints? We strayed from the way of truth, and the light of righteousness didn't shine on us, and the sun didn't rise upon us" (Wisdom 5:3-6). And they will say many other things full of great sorrow on that day.
chunks.original_latin:
Cur itaque non potest, nisi quia,

quod Scriptura de impiis futurum praedixit: Dicent

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Given the immense power and presence of Christ the Lord, and the fear of such a clear and eternal judge, there is a kind of faith that emerges. This faith might appear in those who once believed or even in non-believers who, faced with this divine majesty and fear, are compelled to believe. In their lamentation, they express: "We have strayed from the path of truth, and the light of justice did not shine for us, and the sun did not rise for us" (Wisdom of Solomon, Chapter 5); However, this faith, as often mentioned, comes from those completely abandoned by God and not enlightened by His grace. It is not born from the devotion of love but from the necessity of fear, similar to the faith that the Apostle James refers to when he says: "Even the demons believe, and tremble" (James 2:19).

Such faith, therefore, will not save them but will rather bring them shame, as the psalm states: "Let them be ashamed and troubled forever and ever, and let them be confounded and perish" (Psalm 83:18). They have no hope, condemned by the eternal sentence and utterly without expectation of liberation. The love with which they might love God truly, and their neighbor in God or for God's sake, cannot exist in them. This is because God Himself, who is love, has abandoned them, and the grace of the Spirit, as the Apostle says: "Because the love of God has been poured into our hearts through the Holy Spirit who has been given to us" (Romans 5:5), is absent from them, and the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, the love of God, and the fellowship of the Holy Spirit have all withdrawn from them.

Even if that rich man, already condemned in hell, appeared to love his brothers, whom he left behind in the flesh, and pleaded for them not to come to that place of torment (Luke 16:27), it was not truly according to God. It was not driven by divine love but by the fear of damnation or a human affection extracted from him.
chunks.original_latin:
Si

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Because there can no longer be any genuine faith in them through God's illumination and the gift of the Holy Spirit, and no expectation of good hope, no repentance for the past or desire for the future will be accepted by the just and merciful judge. These things will not arise from piety and love of divine grace, but only from the necessity of tribulation and distress.

Then, being completely deprived of divine illumination and the joy promised to the good and faithful servant, with the Lord saying: Enter into the joy of your master (Matthew 25:21), they will remain entirely excluded and alienated from the light of God. They will be cast into outer darkness, into that dreadful night of which the Lord said: Night is coming, when no one can work (John 9:4). And elsewhere, He mercifully warns, saying: Walk while you have the light, lest darkness overtake you (John 12:35).

Therefore, those in such darkness and night will no longer be able to do anything pious and fruitful that the just judge can accept, nor will they deserve to be freed from eternal damnation. And because there can be no genuine repentance, there will be no forgiveness of sin; consequently, there will be no end to the punishment.

Whatever memory of truth or blessedness they may have, it will only be what can be faintly grasped by human senses, not as it is usually inspired by God's grace. Then, indeed, what Scripture terrifyingly says to each one will be fulfilled; and only distress will provide understanding to the hearing (Isaiah 28:19); and again: There is neither work nor planning nor knowledge nor wisdom in the grave, where you are going (Ecclesiastes 9:10).

There will be no good work to acquire any merit, no reasoning to excuse justly or satisfy worthily, no wisdom from the illumination of truth, no knowledge in the practice of any virtue. How, then, will they have the knowledge and awareness of truth, from which they will be eternally deprived in both illumination and contemplation?
chunks.original_latin:
Quia ergo nulla jam in eis esse poterit per
illuminationem Dei et donum Spiritus sancti, pietas
fidei, et charitatis nulla bonae spei exspectatio; ideo
nulla eorum poenitentia de praeteritis, nullum desiderium

quia haec tunc non erunt ex pietate, et

et angustiae. Tunc itaque subtracto a se
 penitus divinae illustrationis lumine, et ab illo gaudio,

Domino: Intra in gaudium Domini tui (Matth. XXV,
21), penitus exclusi et alienati remanebunt extra
lumen Dei; et hoc: Erit eis mitti in tenebras exteriores,
et in illam noctem horrendam de qua Dominus ait:
Venit nox quando nemo potest operari (Joan. IX, 4). Et alio loco misericorditer admonet, dicens: Ambulate
dum lucem habetis, ne tenebrae vos comprehendant
(Joan. XII, 35). Et ideo qui in talibus tenebris atque
in tali nocte erunt, nihil jam poterunt pie et fructuose
operari, quod vel a justo judice possit suscipi,
vel unde ipsi mereantur ab illa aeterna damnatione
liberari. Et quia nulla poterit esse pia poenitentia,
nulla erit delicti indulgentia; consequenter

poterit recordatio veritatis sive beatitudinis, tanta
erit quanta humano sensu vel tenuiter potest attingi,

enim implebitur quod terribiliter unicuique Scriptura
dicit; et tantummodo sola vexatio intellectum
dabit auditui (Isa. XXVIII, 19); et iterum: Quia nec

ibi erit opus bonum aliquod meritum acquirendi,

veritatis, cujus et illuminatione et contemplatione

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
How can someone desire true happiness and truth without a love for piety, through which truth is genuinely cherished and true happiness is sincerely desired? They might have some understanding of the truth, recognizing themselves as deserving of punishment, acknowledging they are justly condemned, and will never be freed from eternal judgment. However, this awareness will only torment them, offering no comfort.

Similarly, they might long for a certain happiness, to be rescued from their torments and to find some peace or rest. But knowing and desiring God's truth and happiness is a gift for those who are pious and enlightened by God's spirit, not for the impious who are condemned to perpetual blindness and unhappiness.

Even if some among them once believed and knew, remembering some truth or happiness, this memory only increases their grief and repentance, making them recognize their just condemnation. They wish for time to change their ways and escape punishment, yet they lack the piety needed to deserve God's grace.

Therefore, let those who will not be enlightened by God, and who are alienated from God's life, stop claiming they are not miserable or condemned. True and eternal misery is being alienated from a blessed life. There is no greater damnation than being completely excluded and repelled by God, with no hope or recourse to God anymore.

Hence, let every faithful person consider how vain and foolish it is to claim that those who can never be blessed by God could bless themselves; not through God's grace, but through what they believe to be natural goods.

It seems our Lord refers to both the punishments of hell, in this present age and the future, with the single term "Gehenna" in the Gospels.

He mentions the present punishment: Fear him who, after killing, has the power to cast into hell (Luke 12:5); and the future punishment: Rather, fear him who can destroy both soul and body in hell (Matthew 10:28).

The holy Fathers of the Church often believed that the same eternal fire punishes the wicked both before and after judgment. However, the teacher suggests a significant difference between the two damnations. Now, through divinely arranged visions and manifestations, some light of God might be felt there, compelling the damned to at least confess their crimes.

As they glimpse some divine light, they are granted the respect of the vision to whom they can confess. However, later, being overwhelmed by greater and more irremediable darkness, they will not deserve to see anything that might provoke any confession, fulfilling what is truly written about them: For there is no one in death who remembers you; in hell, who will give you thanks? (Psalm 6:6).

Hence, the prophet Isaiah, foreseeing this irremediable damnation and urgently advising that it be anticipated and avoided, where God will not be found and no grace will be available to call upon Him, says: Seek the Lord while he may be found, call upon him while he is near (Isaiah 55:6).

This clearly shows that in that damnation, God cannot be found, nor can the miserable damned, as though placed far away and completely alienated from Him, appease Him with any invocation or supplication.

Furthermore, he adds that in the devil and wicked people, only the perversity of their own will is punished, not the nature, because the will has sinned.

Behold again, a new and unheard-of thing.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
This means that for the devil and wicked people condemned to eternal destruction, it's not their nature that God punishes, but their twisted will. This is because, based on this understanding, it was their will that sinned, not their nature.

However, the Church's faith truly knows and firmly believes that rational nature, whether in angels or humans, has both a natural reason and a natural will given by God. All of this—nature with its reason and will—together forms one single nature.

Thus, this rational nature cannot exist without a will, nor can a will exist without nature. Whatever this nature desires cannot be separated from the nature itself, as if it only pertains to the will. Because when this nature desires something, it does so completely, not partially.

Therefore, whether it moves toward good, it acts entirely with its will; or if it moves toward evil, it acts entirely in the same way. So, whether it is moved toward good or evil, it is completely moved.

When it moves toward good, it is virtuous; when it moves toward evil, it is vice. Therefore, just as through virtue the whole becomes better when moved toward good, through vice the whole becomes worse when moved toward evil.

Thus, it's not only the will that makes the whole better through virtue, but the entire nature improves; nor is it only the will that makes the whole worse through vice, but the entire nature worsens. This happens not by losing the goodness of its substance, but by being corrupted and depraved by the vice of its will.

Therefore, when this nature acts rightly, it acts wholly because it completely desires it. And when it acts wrongly, it acts wholly in the same way because it completely desires it.

Therefore, it is just before God that for good deeds the whole is glorified, and conversely, for evil deeds, the whole is condemned. If, in evil angels and wicked people, it was not the nature that sinned, but the will.

Therefore, in both holy angels and devout humans, nothing is accomplished or earned by their nature, but solely through their will. Similarly, if not the entire nature but only the will is condemned in evil angels and wicked humans, then likewise, in holy angels and humans, it is not the whole nature but only the will that is glorified. However, it is certain, and faith holds without doubt, that the entire nature of the holy angels is already blessed and glorified; likewise, the whole nature of holy humans is to be blessed and glorified.

Conversely, it must be held without any doubt that in evil angels and wicked humans, not only the will but the entire nature will be condemned because the whole has sinned. However, this person, against all faith and the truth of God, introduced an argument claiming that angels and wicked humans are to be condemned only in will. He argued this so that his misguided deception could take hold, allowing him to say, as he already has, that in eternal fire there will be no punishment other than the absence of bliss. This implies that angelic or human nature suffers no external punishment there, because, according to his view, it did not sin, and only the will is punished internally in conscience, since he claims it alone sinned. And it is punished not by any external torment, but only by the absence of bliss, which it will not have, and the prevention of fulfilling its own evil desire, which it will not be allowed to fulfill.

All these ideas are clearly against faith and truth, and they flatter the will of the devil by deceiving humans. This deception prevents them from truly recognizing that they have sinned, because their nature is defended as not having sinned, nor do they truly believe they are to be punished, since not their nature but only their will is said to be condemned.

This is evident to all who care for their salvation, who reject heretical fictions and delusions, and who faithfully follow the evangelical and apostolic truth.

To make sure that readers clearly understand our arguments against his irrational and impious definition, we include the words of the blessed Augustine, who provides a clear and comprehensive teaching on this matter, stating:

Shortly after, he warns us to be cautious not to fall into that prophetic judgment where it is written: Woe to those who call evil good, and good evil; who put darkness for light, and light for darkness; who put bitter for sweet, and sweet for bitter (Isaiah 5:20).

Moreover, the Lord says: An evil person brings forth evil from the evil treasure of their heart (Matthew 12:35).

So, what is an evil person if not an evil nature, because a person is defined by nature? If a person is inherently good due to their nature, then what is an evil person but an evil good? However, when we differentiate between these two, we see that it is not evil because it is human, nor good because it is wicked. It is good because it is human, and evil because it is wicked.

Therefore, anyone who claims it is evil to be human, or good to be wicked, falls into that prophetic judgment: Woe to those who call evil good, and good evil (Isaiah 5:20). They criticize the work of God, which is humanity, and praise the vice of man, which is wickedness.

Thus, every nature, even if flawed, is good in as much as it is nature; it is bad in as much as it is flawed. The venerable doctor does not claim that only a flawed or vicious will is evil, but that the flawed nature of man is an evil nature. He confirms that what is evil is a nature, stating that an evil person is an evil nature.

He explains: He did not say that an evil person is just an evil will, but an evil nature. Clearly, when a person is evil, it is not by will alone, but by their entire nature. Yet, he faithfully teaches that we must distinguish, when we say an evil person, between the work of God and the vice of man; because being human is the work of God, and being wicked is the vice of man.

Therefore, even if flawed, in as much as it is nature, it is good; in as much as it is flawed, it is evil.
