In all these discussions, he asserts that not only the will, as some claim, but the very nature itself is good, as far as it is nature; yet, the nature is flawed where it is imperfect.

It's crucial to follow this understanding faithfully, grasp it in a Catholic way, and hold onto it firmly. By doing this, we can be certain that it's not just the will of an evil angel or human that's at fault when they sin, but their entire nature is corrupt, and their whole being will suffer eternal punishment when condemned.

This person also argues: It's not the general nature that sinned in the first human, but the individual will of each person. If nature itself were to sin, being singular, it would be completely destroyed.

With these words, he attempts to clearly state that not only in other humans does nature not sin, but only the will; and likewise, in the first human, it was not nature that sinned, but only the will. Therefore, the human race's nature did not generally sin in him because his nature did not sin; rather, it was the specific and personal will of each individual that sinned in him, as he, according to this person's view, sinned solely by will.

He claims that if the whole nature of humans had sinned, it would have been completely destroyed. But since only the will sinned, only it is flawed; nature remained intact.

So, how should we respond to these sophisticated and unheard-of theories? We should counter them with the testimonies of the Scriptures of God, through which we can truly understand and faithfully uphold that the entire nature in that man sinned, perished entirely, and was passed on to his descendants, subject to sin and destruction:

as the Apostle clearly teaches, saying: Through one man sin entered the world, and through sin, death, and so it spread to all humans, in whom all sinned.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Through one man, sin entered the world, affecting the entire essence of being human. Just as sin corrupted him completely, it was passed on, tainting all humans, making the entire human nature sinful. In that one person's sin, all of humanity sinned.

Therefore, as the Apostle states, all became children of wrath not by choice, but by nature. He says: We were by nature children of wrath, like the rest Ephesians 2:3

Truly, everyone born from that corrupted root becomes a child of wrath, not in the nature God originally created, but in the one altered by sin. The Psalmist speaks on behalf of everyone: Indeed, I was born guilty, a sinner when my mother conceived me Psalm 51:5

This is a sinful nature, conceived in iniquity and born in sin. This nature, entirely lost in Adam, was fully passed down to his descendants. Our Lord Jesus Christ came to seek and save not just a part, like the will, but the whole. As He states: The Son of Man came to seek and to save the lost Luke 19:10

And because the whole was lost, He came to save it all. He took on the whole, both the soul and the body of man, to save it completely through His death and resurrection: justifying the soul from sins and raising the body from the dead. As the Apostle says: He was delivered over to death for our sins and was raised to life for our justification Romans 4:25

Therefore, whoever claims that the entire human nature was not lost, what are they trying to do but, to the best of their ability, undermine the mystery of the divine incarnation? For the Lord took on the entire nature through His incarnation for no reason if the whole did not need salvation, if the whole did not need a savior.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
It's astonishing how this person claims that in the first man, each of our own wills sinned, even though they didn't yet exist at all; and that the nature of all of us didn't sin, even though it was in him. But what he says is: if the whole nature of that man had sinned, then the whole nature would have surely perished. Therefore, according to his reasoning, if only the will sinned in him, only the will would have perished; and if it perished, it surely needs someone to free, save, and reform it, so it can be healthy and free through the one who says: "If the Son sets you free, you will be truly free" John 8:36. How can this person, in all his very pointless argument, defend free will as coming from the strength of nature and not from the gift of grace? And if, according to him, only the will perished and nature remained safe, then Truth, heaven forbid, did not speak the truth when it said about itself: "Because he made the whole man well on the Sabbath" John 7:23.

He also adds that nature is in no way punished because it is from God and does not sin, but a voluntary lustful movement is punished. Therefore, punishments in the wicked are not suffered for what God made, but for what pride has wrongfully devised. The lust of a perverse will is tormented when it is not allowed to have what it wrongly or undeservedly desires. What he claims, that nature is punished in no way because it is from God and does not sin, is doubly contrary to faith and truth. Both angelic and human nature, when sinful, as was shown multiple times above, is punished by the just judgment of God and eternal damnation. Since evil cannot, nor should it, go unpunished, it must be punished where it is found and by whom it is perpetrated, that is, in the very natures in which sins were committed and which were corrupted and depraved by sinning; therefore, they are justly condemned for these sins. Even angelic or human nature, although from God not by generation but by creation, not by birth but by origin, can still sin and does sin.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The Catholic faith recognizes both truths: nature is indeed punished because of sin, and this person denies both by neither acknowledging that nature is punished nor that it sins.

According to his claim, no nature created by God exists without sin, just as there is no nature only begotten by God. However, true faith firmly believes that every rational nature, both angelic and human, is capable of sinning, as clearly demonstrated by the rebellious angels and humans who fell through disobedience.

The reason the chosen angels do not sin is due to divine grace and goodness, making them good by nature and remaining good by grace. The only nature that can never sin is the one that comes from God and is what God is—not created from nothing, but begotten or proceeding from Him—which is undoubtedly the only begotten Son of God and the Holy Spirit.

Therefore, by claiming that no other nature is without sin, this person tries, with blatant blasphemy, to equate the creature with the Creator. What else remains for him except to suggest that the angelic or human spirit is of the same nature as God, as the impious ancient heretics claimed?

While they introduced two separate and opposing natures—one good that could not be evil, and another evil that could not be good—this person, with a new and unheard-of error, claims that within the same angelic or human spirit, nature does not sin, implying it cannot be evil, while the will sins, implying it can be evil.

Therefore, after saying that nature neither sins nor is punished, to assert that only human will sins, he immediately added: but the voluntary lustful impulse is punished. Repeating and emphasizing this, he said: In the wicked, it is not what God made that suffers punishment, but what pride has wickedly invented.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
With these words, just like before, he confirms that the essence of angels or wicked humans will never endure punishment. However, what a proud will has wrongly committed should be punished only within the will itself.

And as if we were asking him about the future punishment of this corrupt will, he explained: The desire of a perverse will is tormented when it is denied what it wrongly or undeservingly seeks.

Behold, the kind of torment he describes for the evil in angels and wicked humans. It is not eternal fire, nor any external punishment, but rather the inability to fulfill their wrongful desires, being oppressed and restrained.

Thus, it is confirmed that the nature of bad angels or humans will never sin and never be punished, but the will itself, which is permitted to sin in them, will feel no pain or punishment. Except for what all wicked people suffer in this life when they cannot fulfill their wrongful desires, either due to divine judgment or other necessary constraints.

From this, it is evident that all punishment, torment, and torture of future damnation, which Almighty God so often and terribly threatens, is completely denied. Therefore, as it is contrary to our faith and an enemy of the truth, it should be kept far from the ears and hearts of the faithful.

To these significant matters, he adds a concise definition, saying: No evil comes from good.

To understand this carefully, we must first consider that something good can become evil: just as the very nature of angels or humans is indeed good in its own way and kind. But this good nature can become evil through vice, so that, as far as it is nature, it remains good, and as far as it is corrupted, it begins to be evil. Thus, there is no doubt that good can become evil.

However, for this transformation, for good to become evil, there is no preceding cause from which this consequently happens.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
For example, if we ask what makes a certain nature good, we discover that the highest good is God, and all goodness originates from this supreme source. Similarly, if we explore why someone is wise and just, we find that the greatest wisdom and justice also stem from God. Thus, God is the ultimate and most certain cause by which anyone truly wise becomes wise, and anyone truly just becomes just.

So, to be good, wise, and just, the preceding and effective cause is the highest wisdom and justice. But can we claim in the same way, if asked where evil begins, that there exists a highest evil outside of any angelic or human nature, from which all evil in these beings originates? Could a wicked angel and a wicked human have a preceding and effective cause of their wickedness, turning them from good to evil?

An angel, like a human, was indeed good before becoming evil. What then was the preceding cause that made them evil? Could a good God have been the cause of an angel's fall into evil? Certainly not, because the supremely good cannot be the source of evil.

In the same way, it would be incorrect to assert there is a highest evil as the preceding cause by which a good angel turns evil. If we say this, we clearly introduce two principles contrary to the truth of faith: a principle of good and a principle of evil. But as we have said, let it not be so, because there is no nature of evil at all, nor does it exist substantially to be the principle of anything.

Rather, evil is defined as a deficiency of good, like darkness is a lack of light, and illness is a lack of health. So where did this deficiency of good, which we call evil, originate in the devil, who was the first to sin? It did not come from God, because God is not the author of evil. Nor did it come from any substance of evil, because no such substance exists.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
If someone claims this happened by his own will, causing a good being to become bad, we have to ask whether that will was good or bad. If it was good, how could a good will lead to a bad one?

But if a bad will caused a good being to become bad, who created that bad will? Since there's no answer, we must admit there was no preceding cause for the bad will that made a good angel bad; rather, it's a deficiency because a lack of good is called evil.

Similarly, in a sinning person, neither God's will is the cause, nor is it the nature of evil, which we know doesn't exist; nor the person's good will, which couldn't cause evil; nor his bad will, because if we seek its origin, we find none.

If it's said the devil's bad will influenced the person's will, just as he could accept bad advice, he could also refuse it. Since both choices were within his power, no one pushed or forced him; no one could even persuade him unless, by an inner voluntary deficiency, he fell and became bad from good.

This also happens with others; hence, it's clear that the good itself, meaning the good nature, is from God. But when the good of nature becomes evil through vice, it's from nothing because it has no author, only a deficient cause.

Therefore, it's rightly thought and said about rational angelic or human nature that in them, the good of nature becomes evil from no author, or is understood to be evil. Because, as often mentioned, this evil in rational creatures began not from God, nor any author of evil, but from their own deficiency of good.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
This person argues that neither angelic nor human nature itself can sin, but rather it's the will of that nature that can be flawed. They seem to define it this way to show that while the will can turn from good to bad, the nature itself remains free from evil. The idea is that evil doesn't originate from the nature itself, but rather from the change in the will from good to bad; essentially, it arises from nothing. Evil has no efficient cause from the creator; instead, it's the absence or defect of good that makes it bad. According to their view, evil doesn't come from any good, because neither the good of angelic nor human will causes their nature to become bad, keeping the nature itself blameless. To make the good will turn bad, it comes from nothing, and therefore not from the nature itself.

This misleading argument is taken from Saint Augustine's words in the books of The City of God. What Augustine used to strengthen faith and counter heresies, especially against the Manichaeans, is cunningly turned by this person against faith itself. They twist Augustine's subtle arguments, which were meant to confirm piety, to instead support their own errors.

They also add: Whoever uses the free choice of will, a gift of natural intelligence or sharpness of mind, for disgraceful purposes, will justly lose the honor of truth and face the darkness of eternal ignorance. In saying this, they aren't speaking about the nature or will of angels or humans, but rather about their intelligence, considering the three aspects of the rational mind: being, knowing, and willing.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Now that we've covered the two aspects of existence and will in both natures thoroughly, it seems appropriate to move on to the topic of knowledge, specifically focusing on intelligence itself.

With nature remaining whole and free from all punishments as it understands them, it's not just the will of that nature but also its intelligence that is considered to be punished in future damnation.

This punishment won't come from any external suffering or torment but rather from an internal loss.

It's said that whoever, through their free will, has misused the gift of natural intelligence—which should have been directed towards seeking, discovering, and contemplating truth—by using it for vain, useless, or even harmful purposes, will face a specific kind of damnation. In this damnation, the free will that misused the gift of intelligence will be punished by not being able to enjoy the light of truth.

Instead, it will rightfully lose the benefit of intelligence and fall into the darkness of eternal ignorance.

If this is the case, the punishment for human will is indeed severe. For having misused the gift of intelligence through free will in this life, it will lose that gift in damnation, unable to enjoy the light of truth, and will be condemned to eternal ignorance.

This punishment on the misguided human will, losing the light of intelligence, will be so severe that it seems justified that it should be lost, and in its place, the darkness of eternal ignorance will follow.

We do not dismiss this punishment of the human mind in future damnation because, as we read in the Gospel Matthew...

When the useless servant is condemned for not wisely using and doubling the one talent of understanding he received, instead choosing to wrap it in a napkin or bury it in the ground—meaning he made it unfruitful by living in luxury and being absorbed in worldly concerns.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Chapter Seventeen he introduces seven definitions in the following manner:

One: God is not the author, creator, or predestinator of punishments.

Two: God's predestination applies only to what is good, but His foreknowledge encompasses both good and evil. This distinction arises not from nature but from the way language is used.

Three: Just as it is said that God is present everywhere by His power, but not everywhere by the grace of His dwelling, it can similarly be stated that He has foreknowledge everywhere, but not predestination everywhere. The truth clearly shows this about God: wherever He is present, He will undoubtedly dwell there; likewise, wherever there is foreknowledge, there must necessarily be predestination.

Four: Just as the presence and dwelling of God are only in those things made by Him, so His foreknowledge and predestination apply only to those things He would create. And just as His presence and dwelling do not exist in things that are neither from Him nor made by Him—being contrary because He is not in them—His foreknowledge and predestination are similarly declared contrary in those things He neither made nor gave, because they are nothing.

Five: The eternal fire was created to burn the devil and his angels, not humans, after the devil was cast down from the ether: where in his ethereal body he could not feel punishment, a fiery body was added so he would feel fire.

Six: That fire is not a punishment nor prepared or predestined as such, but was predestined to be part of the totality of all good things, becoming the seat of the wicked, where undoubtedly both the blessed and the miserable will dwell.

Seven: Misery is nothing but eternal death; eternal death is the ignorance of truth, and there is no misery but ignorance of truth: where truth is ignored, there is no life. Therefore, in stating first that God is not the author, creator, or predestinator of punishments, he has clearly spoken against faith, as we have frequently shown before.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The punishments in eternal damnation for the devil, his angels, and all wicked people are not unjust. Each of those who are damned will be tormented according to their own actions and the extent of their wickedness. This aligns with what is written in the psalm by the just and eternal judge: "He will repay each person according to their deeds" Psalm 62:12.

Similarly, the fire of hell is singular, yet it affects those delivered to it in different ways. Just like the sun's heat is one, it is felt differently by different people based on their body's constitution.

These punishments never end because it is just in God's eyes that those who never wanted to stop sinning should never see an end to their torments. Those who did not willingly subject themselves to Him must do so out of necessity, ensuring no creature stands against its Creator.

Whoever did not agree with the truth here, but believed in wickedness, will be completely restrained from wickedness there. They will not be able to deny the evident truth of the divine judgment, God's majesty and power, and His Christ. Thus, the wicked, who were always strangers to God's worship, will be forced to acknowledge the truth. Lamenting and repenting too late, they will say: "We have strayed from the path of truth, and the light of righteousness did not shine on us, and the sun did not rise upon us" Wisdom 5:6.

Therefore, even when Almighty God threatens terrible and eternal punishments through His prophets, He often adds at the end of His threats, saying: "And they will know that I am the Lord" Exodus 29:46. This means they will say this out of necessity, to their own shame, what they never wanted to know out of piety and devotion for their salvation.

The devil himself, the author and instigator of wickedness, along with his impure and damned angel followers, will meet the end of his tyranny there. This tyranny, which he has relentlessly exercised against God and the salvation of the entire human race from the beginning, will end, as it is written: "He will be cast down in the sight of all" Job 40:28.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The holy Scriptures describe hell as useful, similar to how human laws punish wrongdoers to ensure others can live in peace.

As the Scripture mentions regarding a wicked tongue: "Hell is more useful than it" Sirach 28:25.

Since these eternal punishments for angels and condemned humans are so just and well-organized, why wouldn't God be their author? Not because He causes these great evils, but because He is the just arranger and judge of rightful torments.

How is He not the author of these punishments, about whom the Gospel clearly states: "He who can destroy both soul and body in hell" Luke 12:5; and: "He who, after killing, has the power to throw into hell" Matthew 10:28; and who will say in judgment: "Depart from me, you cursed, into the eternal fire" Matthew 25:41.

If these punishments and places of torment are believed to exist somewhere in the created world, that is, within the universe, who else could be their creator but the maker of all? As Scripture clearly states: "He who lives forever created all things at once" Sirach 18:1.

Since that eternal fire is truly a creature, it should not be thought of as co-eternal with God; and since it was created for just and proper purposes, anyone claiming that it or any other creature is not from God, the sole author of all creation, but from some unknown source, is clearly involved in heretical impiety, like the Manichaeans or other very wicked heretics.

Therefore, since that eternal fire is indeed a creature, it undoubtedly shares the same author and maker as all other creation; of whom it is written: "For in six days the Lord made the heavens and the earth, the sea, and all that is in them, and rested on the seventh day" Exodus 20:11.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
If someone claims that God is not the author or creator of punishments because, as they often say, punishment is nothing since it lacks the substance and nature to exist and persist on its own, similar to evil, sin, or death, and therefore could not have been predestined by God as these things do not exist substantially: They must be countered with the clear truth of the matter. The word punishment does not signify a tangible or subsisting nature, unlike when we say: Heaven, earth, or sea. These words indeed immediately convey certain natures of things by their meaning.

Therefore, although the word punishment does not indicate something that exists independently, it does signify a great evil carried out through existing natures of things. So, while it lacks its own substance, it signifies something brought about only through existing things and substances; just as death, when mentioned, certainly does not signify its own substance, because it cannot exist independently: Yet, by this name, it is understood as a very serious evil, which is acknowledged in the division of substances, that is, of the soul and body.

Thus, almighty God did not predestine punishment to exist in its own nature, but he did predestine it within truly existing natures and substances, to which the great evil signified by that name is truly and substantially applied.

He further says: God's predestination is only towards things that are good, but foreknowledge towards both good and evil, which difference is not by nature, but by the use of expressions. This distinction between God's foreknowledge and predestination, as the holy Fathers have passed it down and as the truth itself confirms, we certainly uphold and embrace.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
God, who knows all future events, has eternally foreseen everything that will happen, both good and bad. However, He has eternally predestined only the good things that He Himself will accomplish, whether through His free mercy or His just judgment.

So, it's important to understand that God's foreknowledge includes both good and bad things; but predestination applies only to the good and just things, which He not only foresaw but also determined, defined, and decreed to happen.

This distinction points out that God could foresee evil but did not predestine it, not understanding the difference in evil that we've already discussed. Specifically, there is one type of evil that is contrary to good, which is a vice and does not have God as its author; while another type of evil is contrary to peace, quiet, or health, which never occurs without God as its author and judge.

As He speaks through the prophet: "I am the Lord, who makes peace and creates evil" (Isaiah 45:7). And also, in another prophet: "If there is evil in the city, which the Lord has not done?" (Amos 3:6). And again: "Good and bad, life and death, poverty and wealth, are from God" (Ecclesiasticus 11:14).

Therefore, for that evil understood as vice or sin, God is not the predestinator because He is not the author; but for this evil, understood as some affliction, torment, or punishment, whether temporal or eternal, because these, as Scripture teaches, are from Him and are arranged and inflicted by His judgment, He is clearly both the author and the predestinator, because He both foresaw them as future and predestined them to be justly done.

Given this, highlighting this distinction achieves nothing except to deny the truth and demonstrate ignorance. As for saying that this distinction between divine foreknowledge and predestination is not by nature but by the use of language, it seems better and more accurate to us that it is by nature and according to nature; because even in God's nature: "There is no change or shadow of turning" (James 1:17).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
It's important to grasp that knowing, foreknowing, and predestining are distinct for God. Yet, with His singular, simple, and eternal knowledge, He understands everything equally and all at once, even though, in our temporal world, things occur and are revealed differently. However, since God's foreknowledge and predestination are truly connected to His creations' state and order, they don't differ in God's eternal and unchanging knowledge. Everything there is one simple knowledge, unaffected by time or the diversity of things.

Yet, this difference exists in the realm of time, where some things are present or past, which human understanding recognizes as knowledge, and others are future, where foreknowledge or predestination applies. Within these future things, there's further diversity; some are good, and others are bad. Here, another distinction appears: predestination is recognized only in good things, while foreknowledge applies to both good and bad.

Thus, the difference between foreknowledge and predestination, though not inherent to the nature of the unchanging deity, is acknowledged due to the nature of managing and arranging the changeable creation. We've already explored this more thoroughly earlier, in the second chapter of this discussion. Therefore, we must not allow these concepts, accurately and truly distinguished by their properties and handed down by the Fathers, to be disturbed or confused by any new assumptions.

So, one must not indiscriminately and confusingly claim, as some do, that all foreknowledge is predestination, which is a blatant blasphemy. While God can foreknow even evil things, suggesting that He predestined them is completely unthinkable. Although predestination, because it inherently includes foreknowledge, can also reasonably be called foreknowledge.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
However, when he argues that this difference doesn't arise from the truth and nature of things, but merely from our language usage, he contradicts his own claim. He says: Just as it's said that God can be present everywhere by the presence of power but not everywhere by the grace of dwelling, it can also be said that He is everywhere by foreknowledge but not everywhere by predestination.

The truth clearly states about God: wherever God is present, He will surely dwell. Similarly, wherever there is foreknowledge, there will necessarily be predestination. Here, he suggests that this religious expression in ecclesiastical discipline, which distinguishes and discerns God's presence, is not based on the nature of things but merely on human language usage, which undermines a healthy understanding of all divine Scripture.

Almighty God is presented to us as being generally present through majesty in one way and specifically through the grace of dwelling in another. Concerning the general presence of His majesty, He says: “I fill heaven and earth.”

And the Prophet says to Him: “If I ascend into heaven, You are there; if I descend to hell, You are there: if I take the wings of the dawn and dwell at the end of the sea, even there Your hand will lead me, and Your right hand will hold me” (Psalm 139, verses 8 to 10).

Regarding the grace of His dwelling, which is not everywhere but in His temple, that is, in the holy and rational angelic or human creature, which alone is capable of His knowledge and understanding, illumination, and grace; sometimes signified by the heavens, representing the heavenly life of angels or holy humans, and sometimes by the mention of His special temple.

Scripture expresses this by saying: “He who dwells in the heavens will laugh at them” (Psalm 2, verse 4).

And: “I lift my eyes to You, who dwell in the heavens” (Psalm 123, verse 1).

And: “Look down from Your holy dwelling, from heaven” (Deuteronomy 26, verse 15).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Our Father, who is in heaven (Matthew 6:9)

As the Apostle says: Do you not know that you are the temple of God and that the Holy Spirit dwells in you? (First Corinthians 3:16)

And again: For you are the temple of the living God, as God says, "I will live in them and walk among them, and I will be their God, and they will be my people." (Second Corinthians 6:16; Leviticus 26:12)

Given the immense difference between the general presence of divine majesty across all creation and the special grace of dwelling, which is mercifully granted to rational beings who can truly understand and accept it: why would anyone try to undermine this profound truth, essential for our faith and salvation, by recklessly claiming that wherever God is present, He also dwells?

On the contrary, Scripture always carefully distinguishes this, highlighting God's dwelling only in His temple, whether heavenly or earthly, through His grace. It mentions that sometimes He dwells in a man-made temple, consecrated in devotion to His name, due to its consecration, the worship of His majesty, and the efficacy of prayer: as the Lord Himself illustrates in the Gospel, saying: "And whoever swears by the temple, swears by it and by the one who dwells in it." chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
From this, we learn that in a man-made temple dedicated to His name, God can be said to dwell through a special grace and the sanctification of heavenly sacraments. However, He does not reside there due to the vastness of His majesty or the grace He bestows only upon the chosen and rational beings.

A certain holy and glorious martyr once said about Him: "The whole world is His temple." If he meant the entire world, including heaven and earth, then it's understood that God can be worshiped and adored everywhere. True worshippers no longer worship in Jerusalem like the Jews or on the mountain like the Samaritans, but they worship the Father everywhere in spirit and truth. (John 4:23).

But if he was referring to the whole world as the human race, then indeed, the whole world is God's temple. This means that those from the entire human race who turn to God and become His temple are included. Therefore, the same blessed martyr, after saying "the whole world is His temple," added, "It must be dedicated in our mind, consecrated in our heart."

Thus, from both common language and the truth of things, Almighty God is said to be everywhere by His majestic presence, but not everywhere by the grace of His indwelling. He presents His majestic presence generally to all creation, but grants the grace of His indwelling only to the chosen rational beings.

What is then asserted is that God can be said to be everywhere by foreknowledge, but not everywhere by predestination; and wherever there is foreknowledge, there must be predestination. Who has ever claimed that God is everywhere by foreknowledge, since His foreknowledge is known only to Him?

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Why is it necessary to say that He is everywhere by predestination when His predestination is only known to Himself? Similarly, it's pointless to say: Wherever there is foreknowledge, there will necessarily be predestination. No one actually says this; as some of the ancient Fathers noted, it's merely a new expression and nothing more.

We say that God is everywhere in majesty, power, and virtue because all of these—majesty, power, virtue—are Himself, who is everywhere. However, there's no reason to say He is everywhere by foreknowledge or predestination. Because nowhere is it written that God exists by foreknowledge or predestination.

Therefore, saying that God's foreknowledge and predestination only apply to things He would do is clearly false, because His foreknowledge can also include evil things He would not do. Then, the claim that His foreknowledge and presence are in things neither from Him nor made by Him is equally pointless.

Where has he ever read? Where has he heard it said by the faithful that God is present in things neither from Him nor made by Him? And what are these things which, as he writes, are neither from Him nor made by Him?

If such things exist, is there a creature neither from God nor made by Him? This is certainly not Christian, but Manichaean, because the Gospel cannot lie, where it is written: All things were made through Him, and without Him, nothing was made. John 1:3.

He also added: The foreknowledge of God and predestination is pronounced contrary in those things which He neither made nor gave. He claims it is pronounced contrary, so that according to his own new and insane rule, what is pronounced is understood not to be truly pronounced.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
So, claiming that eternal punishments are nothing or haven't been established is a lie because it goes against the truth. These future events have truly been foreseen by God and are destined for those who deserve them. Since these things are clearly found in the Scriptures as actions that are foreseen and predestined, any rule that claims deeds should be understood as non-deeds should be dismissed.

He further added: The eternal fire was created for burning the devil and his angels, not humans. This is what he and perhaps others seem to say; that the eternal fire is prepared not for punishing humans, but only for punishing evil angels. The Lord does not say in that judgment to those on his left: Depart from me, you cursed ones, into the eternal fire prepared for you, but rather, prepared for the devil and his angels. Matthew 25:41 So it appears to be prepared only for evil spirits, that is, the devil and his angels.

Hence, it's understood that some believed there is one fire where the souls of the damned are tormented now in hell, and another eternal fire where humans will be sent after resurrection, along with the devil and his angels. But whether there is one fire, where both souls now and later, with their bodies, will be tormented, or whether it's different now or then, we should trust the truthful Scripture. Both the punishment of eternal fire and the outer darkness, which will undoubtedly be there, are reserved not only for angels who didn't keep their position and left their dwelling. Whom God has also delivered, having fallen from the heavens, to judgment to be tormented, but also prepared and reserved for wicked humans.

As we've mentioned before, the blessed Apostle Peter talks about some wicked people destined for ultimate destruction: "For whom the gloom of darkness is reserved forever" (Second Peter 2:17).

Similarly, the blessed Apostle Jude speaks of them, saying: "For whom the storm of darkness is reserved forever" (Jude 12).

Just as the gloom and storm of eternal darkness are prepared for the impious and wicked, so is the eternal fire, which is understood to be the same, prepared for them as well. This is why the Lord speaks of the same eternal fire: "Which is prepared for the devil and his angels" (Matthew 25:41).

Therefore, we should faithfully understand that what is primarily said about the devil is also meant for his followers, about whom Scripture states: "They imitate him, who are on his side" (Wisdom 2:25).

Thus, the punishment mainly prepared for him is also accepted as being prepared for them, as the apostolic words clearly show.

He further explains: After being cast down from the heavens, where he couldn't feel pain in a heavenly body, he was given an airy body in which he could feel fire. On this matter, let's not heed the rash and inconsiderate definitions of others, but rather the words of the blessed Augustine, which are pious, moderate, cautious, and more inquisitive than definitive.

He says the higher part of the air, due to its pure tranquility, is joined in common peace with the heavens, which it borders, and is called by the same name. In this part, perhaps, if the transgressor angels were with their leader, now the devil, then an archangel, before their transgression (for some of our people do not think they were heavenly or super-heavenly angels), it's not surprising if after sin they are cast into this gloom, where there is still air, and it is woven with thin moisture.

If those transgressors, before they sinned, had heavenly bodies, it's not surprising they were transformed into an airy form as punishment. Now, they suffer from fire, which is a higher element, and they are not allowed to occupy even the higher and purer parts of the air. They are confined to these dark regions, serving as a prison for them until the time of judgment.

If more needs to be investigated about these transgressing angels, consider the teacher of piety. He assumes nothing rashly but approaches each topic with caution and humility. He explains that the transgressing angels, along with their leader, now the devil and once an archangel, were either in the upper part of the air, the ethereal heaven, before they sinned, or perhaps involved in heavenly activities if they were heavenly or super-heavenly angels like the others. If they were only in the ethereal heaven, they were cast down into this lower and darker part of the air after their sin.

Similarly, if before their transgression, like the other angels, they had heavenly bodies, they could have been changed or were changed as a punishment into an airy quality. Now, they endure the punishment due to them from the fire.

This holy teacher did not definitively state whether they were in the ethereal heaven or even in the sidereal heaven before their transgression. However, he does not deny that either could have happened. Wherever they fell from after their transgression, whether from the higher or lower heaven, even if they had heavenly bodies before, they were transformed as a punishment into an airy form. He considers it reasonable that no other bodies were added to them from the air itself, meaning airy bodies.

qualitatem; non alia eis ex ipso aere, id est aerea
 corpora addita, non inconveniens esse existimat.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Therefore, it doesn't conclude, like this one, that the devil was cast down from the sky into the air, because he could have fallen from the heavenly realms. Nor does it conclude that he had a heavenly or celestial body. But if he did, it was changed for the worse as a punishment. Nor was an airy body added to him, as if he were clothed in both a celestial or ethereal body and an airy one. Rather, if he had a heavenly body, it was transformed as a punishment into an airy nature, so that now it would not be celestial or ethereal, but an airy body, where he could feel the punishment and torment of fire.

Likewise, elsewhere, reconsidering the same matter and deliberating very cautiously and carefully, he says: "With this caution that the blessed teacher shows in his investigations, we should feel and discuss such matters, and not think anything improperly or deceitfully."

This one follows and says: "That fire is not a punishment, nor was it prepared or predestined for that purpose, but it was destined to be among all the good things, and it has become the dwelling place of the wicked, where undoubtedly the blessed will reside no less than the miserable."

In these words, when he says that eternal fire is not a punishment, he clearly contradicts the Truth itself, that is, the judge of the living and the dead, who foretold that he would say in that judgment: "Depart from me, you cursed, into the eternal fire" Matthew 25:41. And so that we may understand that this eternal fire is indeed punishment and everlasting torment, he immediately adds, saying after a few words about the miserable who are to be eternally condemned and tortured there: "Then these will go away into eternal punishment" Matthew 25:46.

He also contradicts the blessed Apostle Paul, who says: "In the revelation of our Lord Jesus Christ from heaven with the angels of his power, giving vengeance in a flame of fire to those who do not know God and who do not obey the Gospel of our Lord Jesus Christ; they will suffer the punishment of eternal destruction from the presence of the Lord and from the glory of his majesty" Second Thessalonians 1:7-9.
chunks.original_latin:
Non ergo definit, sicut iste, quod ex aethere in aerem
diabolus sit detrusus, quia potuit et ex coelestibus
ruere, nec definit aethereum, sive coeleste eum

vel quasi duplici corpore uno coelesti vel aethereo,
altero autem aereo vestiretur: sed ipsum ejus coeleste
corpus, si fuit, conversum esse ex poena in
aeream qualitatem, ut jam non coeleste vel aethereum,
sed aereum corpus esset, ubi ignis poenam et
supplicium sentire possit. Item alibi de eadem retractans, et cautissime ac
suspense deliberans, ita dicit:  Hac ergo cautela quam beatus doctor
in suis inquisitionibus ostendit, de talibus rebus
sentiendum atque tractandum, et non improbe vel
mendaciter aliquid sentiendum. 6. Sequitur iste, et dicit: Non esse illum ignem
poenam, neque ad eum praeparatum vel praedestinatum:

omnium bonorum, sedes factus est impiorum,
in quo procul dubio non minus habitabunt beati

se in illo judicio dicturum praedixit: Discedite a me,

et supplicium sempiternum, statim post pauca de

Christi de coelo cum angelis virtutis ejus: dantis vindictam

et qui non obedierunt Evangelio Domini nostri Jesu
Christi; qui poenas dabunt in interitu aeternas a facie
Domini, et a gloria majestatis ejus (II Thess. I, 7-9).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The text contradicts the blessed Apostle John regarding the lake of fire and sulfur in the Book of Revelation, which states: "And they will be tormented day and night forever and ever" Revelation 20:10. And again: "And the smoke of their torment will rise forever and ever" Revelation 14:10. And the Scriptures say: "He will give fire and worms in their flesh, so they will burn and feel it forever" Judith 16:21. And again: "Humble your spirit greatly, because the punishment of the wicked is fire and worms" Ecclesiasticus 7:19.

Given these points, and since they should be held faithfully for constant fear and correction, how does this person dare, or why is he allowed such impious freedom, harmful to many, to say in the Church, leading to the subversion of the listeners and fostering deadly security, that this eternal fire is not a punishment? When the Lord testifies that it is eternal punishment, and the truth of apostolic teaching clearly proclaims it as the fire and flame of vengeance, eternal destruction, day and night torment, and the smoke of torment rising forever and ever.

Therefore, we must believe these things completely and truly, so that such fear may restrain and mortify our enjoyment of sinning, and awaken and strengthen our diligence in doing good and pleasing God. For this is especially necessary for us, as the Lord himself shows by saying: "I will show you whom to fear: fear him who, after he has killed, has the power to throw into hell" Luke 12:5; and again: "But rather fear him who can destroy both soul and body in hell" Matthew 10:28.

Hence, elsewhere in Scripture, showing the benefit of this fear, and conversely the harm of security, it says: "The fear of the Lord drives out sin" Ecclesiasticus 1:27; for he who is without fear cannot be justified.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The idea presented here is that the eternal fire was not initially prepared and destined for punishment, but rather to have its place among the universe of creatures created by the good Creator. This notion is not in line with our faith. Instead, we believe that the almighty God, who made everything from the beginning, did so for specific reasons and necessary purposes, ensuring that nothing was created uselessly or in vain.

God intended for each creation, made by His omnipotence, to have its own role or utility: like light for the day, darkness for the night, and the heavens as the place for the lights. He separated the waters above the heavens for the stars' regulation, created plants and trees for sustaining life, and appointed the greater light to rule the day and the lesser light along with the stars to rule the night.

Just as He ordained these things from the beginning for their proper roles and uses, we must also believe that He prepared and predestined the eternal fire from the start, among other creatures, not in vain but by His just providence and wisdom. The purpose was shown by the Lord when He said to the wicked and condemned: "Depart into the eternal fire," adding, "which is prepared for the devil and his angels" Matthew 25:41. This means it was intended for the eternal punishment of both angelic and human creatures.

From His words: "Come, blessed of my Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world" Matthew 25:34, we can understand that the eternal fire was similarly prepared from the world's foundation for the eternal punishment of wicked angels or humans.
chunks.original_latin:
Quod autem iste dicit: Eumdem ignem aeternum
non esse ab initio praeparatum et praedestinatum ad
poenam, sed tantum ut, in universitate creaturarum
quae a bono Creatore bonae conditae sunt, et ipse quasi
locum suum teneret, fidei nostrae nequaquam est recipiendum. Sed hoc potius tenendum est quia omnipotens
Deus, qui omnia quaecunque ab initio
creavit, certis utique ex causis, et ad certos et necessarios

nocti, cum stellis: et caetera in hunc modum. Sicut ergo omnia haec ab initio condita et ordinata,
statim propriis officiis et ministeriis atque usibus
deputavit; ita et illum ignem aeternum ab initio inter
caeteras creaturas non inaniter conditum sua
justa providentia et provida justitia statim ad eos
usus credendus est praeparasse et praedestinasse, ad
 quos Dominus eum praeparatum esse ostendit, cum
impiis et damnatis hominibus dicit: Ite in ignem
aeternum: et subjungit, qui paratus est diabolo et
angelis ejus (Matth. XXV, 41). Id est ad utriusque
creaturae, tam angelicae quam humanae, supplicium
sempiternum. Quia et ex ipsis verbis quibus dicturus
est: Venite, benedicti Patris mei, percipite regnum
quod vobis paratum est a constitutione mundi
(Matth. XXV, 34), e contrario recte intelligere possumus,
etiam ipsum ignem aeternum ad aeternum
supplicium angelorum sive hominum impiorum similiter
a constitutione mundi esse praeparatum.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
However, there's no injustice with God in that He prepared and predestined the fire of eternal punishment for so many of the wicked, long before they even existed. Similarly, when a new city is constructed and a dreadful prison is built at the same time, it's not considered injustice but rather a provision of mercy and justice. This way, those living in the city, seeing the grim prison of condemnation, are either mercifully deterred from sinning or, if they do not avoid sin, are justly and inexcusably punished.

Thus, that fire, created for eternal punishment, should be seen as both merciful and just because people are either corrected by its terror or, if they refuse correction, are more justly punished. Regarding the creation of this eternal fire, we must understand it within the works of God when He made the heavens, the earth, the sea, and all that is in them in six days, and on the seventh day He rested from all His work as stated in Exodus chapter twenty, verse eleven.

Thus, the holy Pope Gregory, explaining the words of the book of blessed Job, where it is written about the wicked: "A fire not kindled shall consume him" (Job 20:26), says: Continuing, the most blessed doctor explains the following words, where it is said about the same wicked person: "He shall be afflicted in his tent" (Job 20:26), regarding what should be faithfully understood about the punishments of that eternal fire, he adds: Likewise, when he explained the words of the same book, in which it is written about the wicked: "He shall repay what he has done, yet not be consumed according to the multitude of his inventions, so he shall endure" (Job 20:18), he says:

This holy doctor speaks terrifying things terrifically and true things truthfully, to stir the minds of his listeners to fear, urging them to correction and compelling them to awaken from deadly security to care for their salvation. Yet, this person, still speaking vain things vainly and false things deceitfully, claims that the eternal fire, created for this purpose, has, as he wishes, become the place of the wicked within the totality of all good things.
chunks.original_latin:
Nec
tamen est ulla iniquitas apud Deum quod ipsum

tam longe antequam omnino essent, praeparavit
 et praedestinavit: quia et in novo civitatis aedificio,
si statim cum ipsa simul civitate domus carceris
horrenda et terribilis exstruatur, non potest dici

ut videntes qui in civitate habitant poenale et

a peccando, aut si nec peccata vitaverint,

ad aeternum creatus supplicium et misericorditer et
juste credi debet, dum aut ejus terrore homines corrigantur,
aut si corrigi noluerint, justius puniantur. De cujus ignis aeterni creatione, quam utique in
illis operibus Dei intelligere debemus, cum sex diebus
fecit coelum, et terram; et mare, et omnia quae in
eis sunt, et in septimo cessavit ab omni opere quod patrarat
 (Exod. XX, 11). Ita sanctus papa Gregorius,
exponens verba libri beati Job, ubi scriptum est de
impio: Devorabit ignis qui non succenditur (Job XX,
26), ita ait: . Exponens adhuc idem beatissimus doctor verba
sequentia quibus de eodem impio dicitur: Affligetur
relictus in tabernaculo suo (Ibid., 26), quid de poenis
aeterni ipsius ignis fideliter sentiendum sit, ita subjungit:
. Item cum verba ejusdem
libri exponeret, in quibus de eodem impio scriptum
est: Luet, quae fecit, omnia, nec tamen consumetur
juxta multitudinem adinventionum suarum, sic et sustinebit
(Job XX, 18), ita dicit: . Haec sanctus doctor terribilia terribiliter, et vera
veraciter loquitur, ut audientium animos ad terrorem
excitet, ad emendationem stimulet, a mortifera
 securitate ad curam salutis suae velut vigilare compellat. Iste autem adhuc inania inaniter, et falsa
fallaciter loquens dicit quod ipse ignis aeternus, qui
ad hoc tantum fuerat creatus, sicut ipse vult, ut esset
in universitate omnium bonorum, sedes factus est impiorum.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
He did not refer to it as the torment, punishment, or suffering of the wicked. Instead, he described it as the seat of the wicked. According to his view, just as everyone has their seat, their home where they sit and dwell peacefully, so too, for the wicked, that fire is not the torment of damnation but a peaceful dwelling place.

Thus, he adds about the same fire, saying: In which undoubtedly both the blessed and the wretched will dwell. He stated they will dwell in that fire, not be tortured or punished, or anything like that, completely denying the real punishments of eternal torment, which all Scripture announces with such terror and emphasizes with such attention.

When he says: In which undoubtedly both the blessed and the wretched will dwell, he is clearly trying to affirm that both the blessed and the wretched will dwell in one eternal fire after the resurrection. This follows, of course, a foolish and utterly vain belief, the opinions of secular philosophers who think that the souls of the pious, after the dissolution of the body, will dwell either in the ethereal heaven, in that circle they call the Milky Way, or in the spheres of the stars.

He refers to all these—the ethereal heaven itself, the firmament of heaven where the Milky Way appears, and the stars themselves—as eternal fire, just like the fire of Gehenna. He believes that all these, which are set above the three elements of the world—earth, water, and air—exist from the fourth element, fire, so that the same fourth element of the world is eternal fire in the underworld, prepared for the devil and his angels. As stated in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter twenty-five, verse forty-one, and for all wicked people; and in the heavenly spaces is eternal fire where the dwelling of the blessed will be after the resurrection.
chunks.original_latin:
Non dixit tormentum, aut poena, vel supplicium
factus est impiorum, sed  sedes, inquit, factus
est impiorum: ut, juxta ejus sensum, sicut unicuique
sedes est, domus sua, ubi quietus residet et inhabitat:
sic et impiis ille ignis non sit tormentum damnationis,
sed tranquilla sedes habitationis. Unde
adhuc de eodem igne subjungit, dicens: In quo procul

cruciabuntur, non punientur, aut tale aliquid, negans

tanta attentione commendat. Quod autem
dicit: In quo procul dubio habitabunt non minus beati
quam miseri, manifeste utrosque, id est et beatos et
miseros in uno igne aeterno post resurrectionem
habitaturos affirmare contendit: sequens videlicet,
stulta et vanissima persuasione, opiniones saecularium

post dissolutionem corporis, vel in coelo aethereo,

coelum aethereum et firmamentum coeli, in quo lacteus

omnia haec, quae super tria mundi elementa, id est
terram, aquam et aerem constituta sunt, ex quarto
elemento ignis putat existere, ut idipsum quartum
mundi elementum, et apud inferos sit ignis aeternus,
qui paratus est diabolo et angelis ejus (Matth. XXV,
41), et omnibus impiis hominibus; et in coelestibus
spatiis sit ignis aeternus ubi sit post resurrectionem
habitatio beatorum.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Here is the kind of happiness promised to the holy and chosen ones of God: those who lived as mortals on earth may now live as immortals in the highest element of the world, as he himself says, in eternal fire.

Their reward is to live in any element, no matter how bright, peaceful, or pure. However, the Lord promises eternal happiness not in worldly elements, but in heavenly and super-heavenly blessings, where Christ is seated at the right hand of God Colossians chapter 3, verse 1, exalted above all heavens and interceding for us Romans chapter 8, verse 34.

Regarding this exalted happiness, the Apostle says: Jesus did not enter a man-made sanctuary, which are mere copies of the true ones, but into heaven itself, to appear in the presence of God on our behalf Hebrews chapter 9, verse 24.

To reach this dwelling, he prays to the Father in the Gospel, saying: Father, I desire that those you have given me may be with me where I am, to see my glory, which you have given me John chapter 17, verse 24.

About this blessed and angelic dwelling of the saints, the Apostle also says: We know that if our earthly house is destroyed, we have a building from God, a house not made with hands, eternal in the heavens Second Corinthians chapter 5, verse 1. Hence, he said: I desire to depart and be with Christ Philippians chapter 1, verse 23.

He promises concerning all the elect after the resurrection, saying: We will be caught up together in the clouds to meet the Lord in the air, and so we will always be with the Lord First Thessalonians chapter 4, verse 16.

Regarding this glorious and happiest dwelling of the righteous, the Psalmist says: The upright will dwell in your presence Psalm 139, verse 14. Therefore, this dwelling should be sought and desired, not in worldly elements, but in the presence of God, in the vision of the glory of Christ, in the company of the blessed and super-heavenly angels, when the saints will be, as the Truth itself promises, equal to the angels of God in heaven Luke chapter 20, verse 36.
chunks.original_latin:

Dei: ut qui habitaverunt, cum adhuc essent

et haec sit eorum remuneratio, habitare in quolibet
quamvis lucido, quamvis tranquillo, et puro tamen
elemento. Dominus autem non in elementis mundi

verorum, sed in ipsum coelum; ut appareat nunc vultui
Dei pro nobis (Hebr. IX, 24). Ad quam habitationem
ut sancti ejus valeant pervenire, ipse in Evangelio
 Patrem exorat, dicens: Pater, quos dedisti mihi volo,
ut ubi ego sum et illi sint mecum, ut videant claritatem
meam, quam dedisti mihi (Joan. XVII, 24). De qua
beata et angelica habitatione sanctorum ipse iterum
dicit Apostolus: Scimus autem quoniam si terrestris
domus nostra hujus habitationis dissolvatur, quod aedificationem
ex Deo habemus domum non manufactam
aeternam in coelis (II Cor. V, 1). Unde et ipse dicebat:
Cupio dissolvi et cum Christo esse (Phil. I, 23). Et de omnibus generaliter electis post resurrectionem
promittit dicens: Rapiemur in nubibus obviam
Christo in aera, et sic semper cum Domino erimus
(I Thess. IV, 16). De qua gloriosa et felicissima habitatione
justorum Psalmista dicit: Habitabunt recti
cum vultu tuo (Psal. CXXXIX, 14). Haec ergo habitatio
 quaeratur, haec desideretur, non in elementis mundi,

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The dwelling place of the blessed won't be limited to just one fiery element of the world, nor will they be trapped there like the wicked in eternal fire. Instead, they will have all the elements of the world under their control, so happily and easily subject to them, and so fitting to their immortal state, that they will be able to be wherever and however they wish without delay.

They will see and possess all these not so much as a reward of blessedness but as an abundance of happiness and for the praise and glory of the Creator. Indeed, this power and glory is promised to them by the prophetic Scripture, which says: "Then the kingdom, the power, and the greatness of the kingdoms under the whole heaven will be given to the people of the saints of the Most High. His kingdom is an everlasting kingdom, and all rulers will serve and obey him" Daniel 7:27

After this, he adds and says: There is no misery except eternal death, the eternal death of ignorance of the truth, and there is no misery except ignorance of the truth; where the truth is unknown, there is no life. This indeed, which is said in these words, could be good if it were not said with a bad intention, that is, in a bad sense.

For it is true that for a just and wise person, all toil, all adversity, all misery that can happen in this mortal life, if it does not break him and change him for the worse, but rather exercises him tirelessly, cannot be misery that makes him wretched. Instead, it purifies and tests him and makes him as gold purer in a furnace.

Such a person does not consider anything to be misery except ignorance of the truth, as long as he is still delayed from contemplating it and is somewhat repelled by his own weakness. He does not fear this external death of the body, but the internal death of the soul, which is the complete ignorance of the highest truth, by which surely all unbelievers are dead, who neither believe nor acknowledge the truth of God.

Concerning whom the Lord also says: "Let the dead bury their own dead" Matthew 8:22 and the Apostle says: "They are alienated from the life of God because of the ignorance that is in them" Ephesians 4:18
chunks.original_latin:

 et gloriam Conditoris. Hanc namque eis potestatem

ignorantiam; et ubi ignoratur veritas, ibi nullam
vitam. Hoc quidem quod in his verbis dicitur,
poterat esse bonum si non ipsum bonum male, id
est malo sensu diceretur. Verum namque est quia

 accidere, si non eum frangat, et in deterius mutet,

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The life of the faithful is truly about knowing the truth itself; they understand it here through faith, and in the future, they will know it through direct experience. Here, they gain life through faith in the truth, as it is written: "The righteous shall live by faith" Romans 1:17. There, they will enjoy eternal life through the knowledge and vision of the same truth, with the Lord saying: "And this is eternal life, that they know you, the only true God, and Jesus Christ whom you have sent" John 17:3.

Therefore, whoever reaches this knowledge through true faith and eternal contemplation will undoubtedly have eternal life through the eternal vision of Truth. But for those who are separated from it, whether through disbelief or ultimate condemnation, what will such separation and ignorance of truth be for them, except eternal death?

In this sense, it is said by the teachers; but he distorts what they said well to fit it as much as he can to his errors and lies. He says these things to use such reasoning violently and wickedly, turning good into evil, as if to show and confirm that there will be no other misery for the wicked angels or lost humans damned in eternal fire, except ignorance and, as he said before, the absence of truth itself. He claims that this ignorance and absence of truth alone will be their eternal misery, their eternal death. In this way, he argues they will be free from all the misery of punishments and torments inflicted externally, and from all the death of penal condemnation.

But no matter how much he contends and tries to contradict, apart from that death which they incur internally from ignorance and absence of truth, they will also suffer externally, as Revelation says: "The lake of fire and sulfur, which is the second death" Revelation 20:10, 14.

Judith chapter sixteen, verse twenty-one. They will always remain in death, driven to die by the cruelty of their punishments, yet the strictness of divine judgment will never allow them to be extinguished.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
CHAPTER 18. In this chapter, it states:

1. The mistake of predestination arises from ignorance of the disciplines that wisdom intended to accompany and investigate, as well as from a lack of understanding of Greek literature.

2. The Greek word horo translates to "I see," "I define," and "I determine," and is similarly constructed as prooro, which means "I foresee," "I predefine," "I predestine." Therefore, predestination and predefinition are essentially foresight.

3. God neither foresaw nor predestined death and punishment, as they are nothing.

4. He left sinners within the mass of original sin; those left behind are served, those abandoned by light are tormented by darkness, and those deserted by life are destroyed by death.

5. What God created in them, He neither leaves nor abandons; otherwise, their nature would revert to nothingness if the supreme essence were not within them.

6. However, He rejected pride, which He did not create in them.

7. God always resides in the nature that He created for Himself.

8. God's wisdom has predetermined in His laws the boundaries beyond which the wickedness of the impious cannot proceed. He does not allow anyone's wickedness to extend infinitely, as they might wish, with divine laws setting the limits of their progress.

9. The wickedness of all the impious, and of the devil, seeks nothing but to depart from Him, who is the supreme essence. To such an extent that, if divine law permitted, their nature would return to nothing.

10. But since eternal laws prevent them from falling as much as they desire, they struggle with this difficulty, suffering through labor, punishment, and torment, and thus become miserable in their emptiness of pleasures.

11. This difficulty, which stops them from achieving their lustful desires, results in their penal destruction and the just torment of their wretched desires.

12. The number of both parts is predestined.

13. The impious serve God unwillingly: not through the nature He created in them, which He does not punish, but through the evil will, which He did not make in them and does punish.

14. And in serving Him unwillingly, they are punished within themselves by their own punishment.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
For those whom He does not free, He somehow prepares them by allowing them to prepare themselves.

When he mentions, The error of predestination arises from ignorance of the disciplines, which wisdom itself wanted to be its companions and investigators, and from ignorance of Greek literature, he is certainly encouraging his listeners to gain knowledge of the liberal arts from him, as he is a learned and philosophical man. He might also be suggesting that they learn Greek literature from him in a similar way.

He claims that wisdom itself has these teachings of the liberal arts as companions and associates, so anyone seeking its understanding must engage with these disciplines to discover the truth through them.

Therefore, if ignorance of secular literature has led to misunderstandings about divine predestination among others, what has this man, who prides himself on his skills, discovered about this matter through them, and what truths has he uncovered?

What has he presented in his lengthy speech that is supported by strong reasoning and worthy of acceptance? Where all that is found is excessive labor of vanity, entanglement in infinite error, and a clear attack on truth. He dismisses the Scriptures of truth and is unfamiliar with the very histories of divine words, not meditating on them day and night, nor striving to align his faith with their guidance.

Instead, he spends his days and nights immersed in human vanities, longing to fill himself with the husks that the pigs eat (Luke 15:16), yet gains no nourishment, but withers away and perishes in miserable hunger under the rule of the wicked master who sent him into his field to feed pigs (Luke 15:15).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Let him return to himself, rise up, and come to his father, so he may find bread within, having perished from hunger outside. There, let him be nourished with the feast of the fatted calf, sacrificed for the salvation of the world. There, let him hear the symphony and choir, representing the admirable harmony of the heavenly Scriptures and the sweet unity of the faithful, who, sharing the same wisdom, are united in understanding and judgment, with one voice glorifying God and the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.

In this house, placed by God's mercy and the grace of faith, let us faithfully hear and embrace what the dispenser of eternal bread, the divine word, suggests to us, saying: If anyone among you thinks they are wise in this age, let them become foolish to be truly wise. For the wisdom of this world is foolishness with God. As it is written: He catches the wise in their craftiness. And: The Lord knows the thoughts of the wise, that they are vain First Corinthians 3:18, 20.

Let us also listen to that very wise man who says: I am the most foolish of men, and human wisdom is not with me; I have not learned wisdom, nor do I know the knowledge of the holy Proverbs 30:2, 3.

We do not say this as if nothing of truth can be found even in human writings, or that those disciplines have no use in seeking truth, but because every faithful person must first diligently learn the truth of faith from the authority of God's Scriptures: so that if it becomes necessary to read or know anything from human writings later, everything may be judged by that divine authority and the truth of faith; so that if anything aligns with its standard, it can be accepted without danger, but anything discordant should be rejected as harmful.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Anyone who believes they can uncover the truth of God and the essence of faith solely through human writings and disciplines, without understanding true faith, the trustworthy authority of Holy Scripture, and the careful instruction of traditional doctrine, is undoubtedly deceiving themselves. While trying to present themselves as a seeker of truth, they end up teaching falsehoods.

It's crucial to maintain this order of devotion, so that even the sacred texts in the law and prophets cannot benefit readers unless the faith of Christ is already in their hearts, allowing them to be truly understood, or unless they earnestly seek and find Christ's faith in them with God's guidance. This is why the Apostle, advising his faithful and beloved disciple, says: "And from childhood, you have known the holy scriptures, which are able to instruct you for salvation through faith in Christ Jesus" Second Timothy three:fifteen.

This essentially means that through faith in Christ Jesus, the holy scriptures can guide a person to salvation, because without this faith, no saving instruction can be found there. This person made many errors, believed, and wrote numerous falsehoods and deceptions because they ignored the holy scriptures. They did not humbly and faithfully seek the truth of faith within them but arrogantly believed they could find it through flawed human arguments: and thus they did not find it, but instead attacked it unfaithfully and unfortunately.

So, anyone who wishes to avoid human error regarding the truth of divine predestination and find what they should truly believe, should read the prophetic, evangelical, and apostolic writings diligently and faithfully. They should not defend their own interpretations against them but humbly submit to their authority and truth, lest they harm themselves by resisting.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
From these divine writings, we've already covered this topic extensively before, so to keep things concise, let's recall just one thing from the letter of the blessed Apostle Jude.

When speaking of the most wicked heretics, who have attacked and will continue to attack the Church from the time of the apostles to the end of the age, Jude shows they were given over to a depraved mind by God's eternal and just judgment. This allowed them to make such bold and terrible statements against God, eventually leading to their eternal condemnation by the same divine judgment. He says:

Certain people have secretly crept in (who were long ago designated for this judgment), ungodly people who pervert the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ into a license for immorality and deny our only Master and Lord, Jesus Christ. (Jude 4)

Jude also highlights how long ago and through many ages this was foretold and prophesied about them. After discussing many things, he adds:

Enoch, the seventh from Adam, prophesied about them: See, the Lord is coming with thousands upon thousands of his holy ones to judge everyone, and to convict all the ungodly of all the ungodly acts they have committed in their ungodliness, and of all the defiant words ungodly sinners have spoken against him. (Jude 14, 15)

He also clearly mentions their eternal damnation and the terrible punishment prepared for them, saying:

Wandering stars, for whom blackest darkness has been reserved forever. (Jude 13)

What could be more clear about the predestination of the ungodly to eternal judgment than the fact that these ungodly people were designated for this judgment so long ago, through so many ages, by divine judgment and prophetic prediction?

(Jude 4)

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
We shouldn't be so naive as to think that just because the blessed patriarch and prophet Enoch, from the seventh generation after Adam, prophesied this, God only decided or predestined it at that moment. It was already part of His eternal judgment and counsel.

In God's unchanging eternity, there's no new will or recent arrangement. Instead, what He predetermined eternally, He wanted to be prophesied and fulfilled in the most suitable way over time. This was meant for the judgment and condemnation of those who would dare to commit such acts, and for the testing and strengthening of His Church, which He intended to be more diligently taught and glorified through the challenges and attacks from such individuals.

As the Apostle says: "For there must also be heresies, that those who are approved may be made manifest among you." First Corinthians 11:19.

So, if we seek to understand the just and eternal predestination of God for judging evil, we should know that certain people are appointed to this judgment of the ungodly. They're appointed not just because of prophetic words, but eternally through divine judgment.

What was eternally set by God was prophesied and established by the prophet in time. If we wonder whether eternal punishment and torment are prepared for them by God's judgment, let's hear what is said about them: "For whom the storm of darkness has been reserved forever."

Thus, we should faithfully adhere to divine truth, neither aligning with the wicked nor the punishments prepared for them by divine means. But you, beloved, build yourselves up on your most holy faith, praying in the Holy Spirit. Keep yourselves in the love of God; confront those who are judged, but save others by pulling them out of the fire, and show mercy to others with caution. Jude 1:20, 23.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
He doesn’t say, "Rebuke those who are to be judged," but rather "rebuke those who have been judged," indicating that what would have come in the future for those persisting in wickedness has already fallen upon them now with the terrifying inevitability of divine and eternal judgment, as has been mentioned. This includes the future punishment for those who will be condemned and the present sentence for those already divinely condemned.

Next, we must turn to the point he makes to demonstrate some knowledge of the Greek language: "Look at the Greek word horro, which is translated as 'I see,' 'I define,' and 'I determine,' which is similarly composed with prooro meaning 'I foresee,' 'I predefine,' 'I predestine.' Therefore, predestination and predefinition are nothing other than foresight."

In these words, he correctly explains that horro can be translated into Latin as "I see." However, how this "I see" should be understood—whether simply, as when we see many things pass by; or with a certain and fixed gaze, where we either know something to be certain or direct our attention with such intensity that our actions follow our gaze like an arrow to its target. Just as Scripture describes the blacksmith or any metalworker, whose eye is fixed on the shape of the vessel he is crafting, with such intent that he allows nothing in it contrary to his design. Thus, the word horro, meaning "I see," should be understood as indicating a vision directed with certainty, so that the gaze, the launching, the crafting, or anything similar, is aimed most accurately and unwaveringly.

From this word horro comes horoma, which in Latin is "vision." This vision, for example, in a dream or some revelation, was defined by the ancients in this way because a vision is when someone sees something that will happen exactly as it appeared.
