judicatos, ut scilicet quod in sua impietate
perdurantibus venturum erat suo tempore, jam nunc
eis divini et aeterni judicii, ut dictum est, praedestinatione
terribiliter supervenisse demonstret, et futura
utique punitione damnandis, et praesenti jam
sententia divinitus condemnatis. Post haec ad illud necessario convertimur, quod
iste ut aliquid etiam ex Graecae linguae peritia docere
videatur, addit et dicit: Ecce Graecum verbum ὁρῶ,
quod video, et definio, et destino interpretatur, similiter
compositum προορῶ praevideo, praedefinio, praedestino. Ac per hoc praedestinationem et praedefinitionem nihil
aliud esse quam praevisionem. In quibus verbis bene
quidem ait quod ὁρῶ possit Latine dici video, sed
quomodo istud video intelligi debeat, utrum simpliciter
tantummodo, sicut multa videmus velut transeunter
et ultro se nostris aspectibus ingerentia;
an certo aliquo et defixo intuiti, quo rem aliquam
aut certissime esse cognoscamus, aut tanta illuc intentione
noster dirigatur aspectus, ut quasi signum
ad sagittam eumdem nostrum aspectum actio consequatur. Sicut et Scriptura dicit de fabro ferrario
vel cujuslibet alterius metalli, quia ad similitudinem
vasis quod fabricatur, est oculus illius, cum tanta
illud intentione oculi attendit, ut velut ad regulam
vel ad lineam sui obtutus nihil in eo aliter quam
ipse disposuit esse patiatur. Ita ergo magis ille
sermo ὁρῶ, id est video, intelligendus est, ut talis
ibi visio designetur, quae ita ad certum dirigitur intuitum,
ut ad ipsum vel incursus intuentis, vel jaculatio,
vel fabricatio, vel aliud ejusmodi rectissime
et indeclinabiliter dirigatur. Ex hoc namque verbo quod dicitur ὁρῶ derivatur
ὁρώμα, quod est Latine visio. Quam visionem, verbi
gratia, somnii, aut alicujus revelationis, ita antiqui
definierunt, quia visio est cum id quis videt quod
 eodem modo quo apparuerat eveniet.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
In the Scriptures, any divine revelation, which is seen in the spirit in such a way that it cannot happen otherwise, is read in Greek as horomate, meaning "shown" or "seen."

According to this clear reasoning, when it is said "I see," it is understood as "I define" or "I determine," as this rightly puts it.

When this phrase is combined with a preposition and stated as prooro, it is understood as "I predetermine" or "I predestine," both meaning the same and also interpreted as "I foresee."

This foresight, when attributed to God, is completely certain and will happen as He foresees. Hence, from the word horo, it seems to derive in Greek orismos, meaning "determination," and with the preposition added, proorismos, meaning "predestination."

No one has ever dared to interpret these two words as "vision" or "prevision," but rather as "determination" and "predestination."

Similarly, from the same word horo, derives orisen, which means "determined," and with the preposition added, proorisen, meaning "predestined."

However, prooro, as mentioned earlier, can also be interpreted as "I foresee"; like in the Psalm, where we say in Latin: "I keep the Lord always before me" (Psalm 16:8); in Greek, it reads, prooromen ton Kurion, which certainly shows something certain and predefined as foresight.

Blessed Jerome translated it as: "I have set the Lord always before me," which more clearly relates to what is determined.

What is specifically determined is directed toward a certain view or plan, as shown by Scripture, which says: "Or like an arrow shot at a designated spot" (Wisdom 5:12).

And the Apostle, where he says about himself: "I press on toward the goal for the prize of the heavenly calling of God" (Philippians 3:14).
chunks.original_latin:
Unde maxime
in Scripturis visionem cujuslibet divinae revelationis,
quae utique ita videtur in spiritu, ut omnino aliter
evenire non possit, Graece in ὁρώματε ostendi
sive videri legitur. Et ideo juxta hanc evidentissimam
rationem cum isto modo dicitur video, certissime
intelligitur, definio, vel destino, sicut et iste
recte posuit, ut cum componitur ille sermo addita
praepositione, et dicitur προορῶ, rectissime intelligatur
praefinio, vel praedestino, quod utrumque unius
significationis est, potest etiam interpretari provideo:
quae providentia, cum ad Deum refertur,
omnino certissima est, et omnino, sicut ille
providerit, futurum. Unde et ex hoc verbo quod
est ὁρῶ, derivari Graece videtur ὄρισμος, quod est destinatio,
 et praepositione addita προορισμός, id est
praedestinatio. Quae duo verba nemo unquam visionem
vel praevisionem interpretari ausus est, sed, ut
diximus, destinationem et praedestinationem. Similiter ex eodem verbo ὁρῶ derivari videtur
ὄρισεν, quod est destinavit, et praepositione addita
προορισεν, id est praedestinavit. Potest autem προορω,
ut supra diximus, interpretari etiam praevideo;
sicut in psalmo, ubi nos Latine dicimus: Providebam
Dominum in conspectu meo semper (Psal. XV, 8);
in Graeco legitur, προορωμεν τὸν Κύριον, quae providentia
utique certum aliquid, et praefinitum ostendit. Quod beatus Hieronymus in editione sua ita posuit:
Proposui Dominum in conspectu meo semper: quod
 utique manifestius ad destinatum pertinet. Quod
autem destinatum hoc sit proprie, quod ad certum
intuitum sive consilium dirigitur, ostendit nobis
Scriptura, quae dicit: Aut sicut sagitta in locum
emissa destinatum (Sap. V, 12). Et Apostolus, ubi
de se ipso ait: Ad destinatum persequor, ad bravium
supernae vocationis Dei, etc. (Phil. III, 14).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Blessed Jerome, while explaining, said:

"Therefore, let this person not ridicule our ignorance by altering Greek words with a new interpretation and, as much as possible, diminishing their impact:

so that what all the ancients in the Holy Scriptures have interpreted as either predestination, predefinition, providence, or purpose, this person now wants to call, with an unusual and absurd name, 'foreknowledge.'

Even though foreknowledge, like foreseeing, is very certain in God, we do not in any way allow the meaning of predestination to be weakened or destroyed by this new term.

For things that even God will not do can be foreseen and foreknown by Him; however, only the things that He will do, either by His mercy or by His judgment, are understood to be predestined by Him.

Therefore, let it be far from us what this person said and almost defined, that the predestination and predefinition of God are nothing other than foreknowledge; because this way of thinking is clearly impious, as if God only foresaw what each person would do or what they would suffer for their deeds, and did not predestine or predefine, in His eternal judgment, anything about the one who would act well or poorly.

This person adds and says: God neither foresaw nor predestined death and punishments, because they are nothing.

How vain and contrary to the truth this is has already been shown quite sufficiently, we believe, and often.

Then this person, speaking about God, adds: He left sinners in the mass of original sin and abandoned those left behind;

abandoned by light, darkness torments them; abandoned by life, death destroys them.

Yet what God made in them, He does not leave or abandon; otherwise, their nature would return to nothing if the highest essence were not in them:

but what He did not make in them, that is, pride, He despised."
chunks.original_latin:
Quod beatus
Hieronymus exponens ait:  Non ergo iste illudat nostrae
ignorantiae, ex Graecis verbis aliquid immutans nova
interpretatione, et eorum vim, quantum in se est,
 evacuans: ut quod omnes antiqui in Scripturis sanctis
vel praedestinationem interpretati sunt, vel praefinitionem,
aut providentiam, sive propositum, nunc
iste velit dicere, inusitato et absurdo nomine, praevidentiam. Quae et ipsa, quamvis in Deo, sicut etiam
praescientia, certissima sit, tamen ex hujus novitate
sermonis nullatenus patimur extenuari, vel destrui
sensum praedestinationis, quia praevideri et praesciri
a Deo possunt etiam illa quae ipse facturus
non est; praedestinari autem ab eo non alia intelliguntur,
nisi ea quae ipse facturus est, vel misericordia
vel judicio suo. Ac per hoc absit omnino a nobis
quod iste dixit et quasi definivit, praedestinationem
et praefinitionem Dei nihil aliud esse quam praevisionem;
quia iste sensus manifeste impius est, ut
 quasi tantummodo praeviderit Deus quid quisque
esset facturus, vel quid pro factis suis passurus,
et nihil de illo qui vel bene vel male erat acturus,
in suo aeterno judicio praedestinaverit vel praefinierit. Addit iste adhuc et dicit: Deum nec praevidisse, nec
praedestinasse mortem et poenas, quia nihil sint. Quod
quam sit vanum et veritati contrarium, jam supra
satis, ut putamus, et saepius ostensum est. Deinde subjungit iste loquens de Deo: Peccatores
in massa originalis peccati reliquit, relictos deseruit;
desertos lumine tenebras torquere, desertos vita mortem
interimere. Nec quod in eis Deus fecit, relinquit
vel deserit: alioquin eorum natura ad nihilum rediret,
si summa essentia in eis non esset: sed quod in
 eis non fecit, id est superbiam sprevit.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The statement about God leaving sinners in the mass of original sin would indeed hold true if it referred specifically to the reprobate, or those destined for punishment or condemnation. These reprobates are meant to be punished and condemned within the mass condemned from Adam, because the almighty potter did not separate them, just as He creates one vessel for honor and another for dishonor from the same mass. Romans Chapter Nine, Verse Twenty-One.

However, stating that God left sinners in the mass of original sin isn't entirely accurate, because the one who said, "I have not come to call the righteous, but sinners," as found in Matthew Chapter Nine, Verse Seventeen— and about whom the Apostle said, "This saying is trustworthy and deserving of full acceptance: Christ Jesus came into this world to save sinners," as mentioned in First Timothy Chapter One, Verse Fifteen, did indeed separate and free sinners from it.

Nevertheless, because it wasn't stated that He left all sinners in that mass—which would indeed be blatantly false—but said generally that He left sinners in that mass, it can be understood partially, allowing the statement to stand.

Furthermore, the addition about those left in the mass of sin explains that they are deserted, left to be tormented by the darkness of their mental blindness, and left without true life, leading to spiritual death. This indicates they are forsaken by God, and because they are abandoned by the true light, they suffer from mental blindness; and since they are deprived of true life, they face spiritual death in the soul.

This is to be their punishment and suffering in eternal damnation, so that without any external torment, they are punished solely by the blindness of their mind and the death of their soul, as was previously stated in various ways.

And to show that some good remains for them even in damnation, it's further stated: Nor does God abandon what He created in them; otherwise, their nature would return to nothing if the supreme essence were not within them. But He despised what He did not create in them, which is pride.
chunks.original_latin:
Quod ergo
dicit de Deo quia peccatores in massa originalis peccati
reliquit, si dixisset reprobos aut puniendos sive
damnandos, profecto verum esset; ipsi enim, id est
reprobi, puniendi, atque damnandi remanent, in
massa illa ex Adam generaliter damnanda, quia non
eos inde discrevit figulus ille omnipotens, quia ex
una eademque massa facit aliud vas in honorem, aliud
vero in contumeliam (Rom. IX, 21). Nunc vero quod
dicit, quod Deus peccatores in massa originalis peccati
reliquit, non omnino potest esse verum, quia
utique peccatores inde discrevit ac liberavit ille qui
dicit: Non veni vocare justos, sed peccatores (Matth. II, 17); et de quo Apostolus ait: Fidelis sermo, et
 omni acceptione dignus, quia Christus Jesus venit in
hunc mundum peccatores salvos facere (I Tim. XV). Verumtamen, quia non dixit, Omnes peccatores in massa
illa reliquit; quod utique apertissime falsum esset,
sed dixit indefinite, Peccatores in massa illa reliquit;
quod potest intelligi et ex parte, stet utcunque quod dictum
est. Quod autem subjungit de eisdem relictis in
massa peccati: Relictos deseruit, desertos lumine tenebras
torquere, desertos vita mortem interimere, ita
eos vult intelligi a Deo relictos, et relinquendo desertos,
ut quia deserti sunt a vero lumine, tenebris
caecitatis suae torqueantur in mente: et quia deserti
sunt a vero lumine, tenebris caecitatis suae
torqueantur in mente; et quia deserti sunt a vera
vita, morte speciali in anima perimantur. Et haec
 sit tantummodo eorum poena atque supplicium
in illa aeterna damnatione, ut nullo extrinsecus
tormento adhibito, sola mentis caecitate, sola animae
morte puniantur, sicut et supra multipliciter asserere
conatus est. Et ut in illa damnatione remanere eis
aliquod magnum bonum, ostendere videatur, dicit
adhuc de ipsis: Nec quod in eis Deus fecit relinquit
vel deserit, alioquin eorum natura ad nihilum rediret,
si summa essentia in eis non esset, sed quod in eis non
fecit, id est superbiam sprevit.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Consider the kind of goodness that God declares remains for others, the same kind He graciously shows to even the indifferent elements, granting them existence through His almighty power so they may continue to be, without their nature being reduced to nothingness. It is by this power that He sustains them and allows them to endure.

These elements of the world, as long as they exist, are preserved in their natural state, undoubtedly continuing for the praise of the Creator and for the benefit or honor of rational beings. However, the nature of those damned and lost is preserved by the almighty power of God so that it does not perish, and by God's just judgment, what is preserved only serves to increase their punishment, ensuring it never ends.

The Creator, who did not wish for the good of the nature He created to be completely destroyed, is indeed to be praised. Regarding the statement: Otherwise, their nature would return to nothingness if the supreme essence were not in them.

If he had said: Their nature would return to nothingness if the supreme essence did not allow them to exist or did not preserve their existence, it would have been accurate, as everything that exists has received its being from that supreme and divine essence. However, as he stated, unless the supreme essence were in them, it seems to suggest that even those destined for destruction might appear to be the temple of God.

For if the supreme essence is in them, since the supreme essence is God, who says of Himself: I am who I am from the book of Exodus chapter three, verse fourteen, then God would be in them, and they could be called the temple of God. Thus, God might say of them: And I will dwell in them.

Indeed, they would be more than a temple if the supreme essence were in them, seeming to be united with God by some essential union, which is believed to apply singularly to the one Mediator between God and humans, Christ Jesus, whom the Word of God and the Word God united to Himself by an essential and natural conjunction, that is, assumed into the unity of His person.
chunks.original_latin:
Ecce quale bonum eis
praedicat remansisse, quale etiam insensibilibus elementis
Deus exhibere dignatur, ut omnipotenti virtute
essentiae suae det eis esse et ut esse permaneant,
nec eorum natura ad nihilum redigatur, eadem virtute
ea sustentat et permanere facit. Sed ista, id est
 elementa  mundi, in quantum sunt, in naturali sua
substantia conservantur, permanent utique ad laudem
Creatoris, et ad usum sive honorem rationalis
creaturae: illorum vero damnatorum et perditorum
natura et omnipotenti Dei virtute servatur ne pereat,
et justo Dei judicio ad poenam ei tantummodo proficit
quod servatur, ne unquam ejus supplicium finiatur. Licet etiam mihi laudandus sit Creator, qui
bonum naturae, quod condidit, non omnimodo deleri
voluit. Quod vero ait: Alioquin eorum natura ad nihilum
rediret, si summa essentia in eis non esset. Si dixisset:
Eorum natura ad nihilum rediret si eis summa essentia
esse non concederet, vel esse non conservaret,
esset utique verum: quia omnia quaecunque
habent esse, ab illa summa et divina essentia acceperunt
 ut essent. Nunc autem cum dixerit, nisi
 summa essentia in eis esset, tantum eis attribuere
videtur qui erunt in illa perditione damnati, ut etiam
templum Dei esse videantur : Si enim summa
essentia in eis erit, quia summa essentia Deus est,
qui de seipso dicit: Ego sum qui sum (Exod. III, 14),
ergo Deus in eis erit, et templum Dei dici poterunt:
ita ut de ipsis dicat Deus: Et inhabitabo in illis. Imo
et amplius quam templum erunt, si summa essentia
in eis erit; ut quodammodo essentiali quadam copulatione
Deo uniri videantur; quod de uno et solo
Mediatore Dei et hominum homine Christo Jesu singulariter
est credendum, quem sibi Verbum Dei et
Verbum Deus essentiali et naturali conjunctione
univit, id est in unitatem personae suae suscepit.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
If it's claimed that the highest essence resides in them through its own power, ensuring their substance isn't erased or lost, and not through any grace that allows them to enjoy some good from it, then they should change this unusual way of speaking. They should say that the highest essence is present to wicked people condemned to eternal destruction through the power of the one acting, not through the dignity of the one inhabiting.

There's a significant question that needs to be explored with faithful devotion, as much as divine grace allows, about how Almighty God is believed to be always and everywhere present in the universe, and sometimes even within it. However, we propose this matter is more to be sought than explained here, so that the truth can be faithfully and piously pursued by the devout and faithful, and, with God's help, truly discovered.

This person, not well-versed in church expression or Christian piety, adds about those same wicked condemned ones, saying that God always dwells in the nature He created for Himself. In these words, the nature God created for Himself is meant to be understood as human, which He made in the rational mind in His image and likeness.

He claims that in this nature of the rational mind, God always dwells, both now and in the future, in believers faithful to Him, as well as in unbelievers and pagans who are alienated from Him by their infidelity, and in the chosen whom He made His temple, and in the rejected whom He condemned to eternal destruction.

This is certainly contrary to faith and truth, because if this were true, it would also be said that God the Father, Christ, and the Holy Spirit dwell in the most unbelieving Jews and pagans who, as far as their good nature created by God is concerned, are made in His image and likeness. Similarly, it would mean that God the Father, Christ, and the Holy Spirit would dwell even in those lost to eternal damnation.
chunks.original_latin:
Quod
si dixerit quod summa substantia in eis erit, virtute
 operationis suae agendo, ne eorum substantia aboleatur
et pereat, non per aliquam inhabitationis
gratiam, qua aliquo bono in illo et ex illo perfruantur;
mutet ergo inusitatam et insolentem locutionem,
nec dicat in hominibus impiis aeterna perditione
damnatis summam essentiam esse, sed potius summam
eis essentiam adesse, virtute operantis, non
dignatione inhabitantis. Est autem magna quaestio
et fideli pietate, quantum divina gratia largitur indaganda,
quomodo omnipotens Deus credendus sit in
universitate creaturae semper ubique esse vel adesse,
et aliquando etiam inesse vel inhabitare, quam tamen
hoc in loco magis quaerendam quam exponendam
proponimus, ut a piis et fidelibus pie et fideliter
hujus rei veritas quaeratur, ut eodem Deo adjuvante
veraciter inveniatur. Iste enim et ecclesiasticae locutionis et Christianae
pietatis minus expertus adjungit adhuc propter
eosdem impios damnatos, et dicit: Deum in ea natura,
quam ad se creavit semper habitare. In quibus nimirum
verbis naturam quam Deus ad se creavit, humanam
vult intelligi, quam in mente rationali ad imaginem
et similitudinem suam Deus fecit, et dicit in hac natura
mentis rationalis semper Deum habitare, et in
praesenti videlicet saeculo, et in futuro, et in credentibus,
qui ejus fideles sunt, et in incredulis ac paganis,
qui ipsa sua infidelitate ab eo alieni sunt, et in
electis, quos templum suum fecit, et in reprobis
quos aeterna perditione damnavit: quod utique contrarium
est fidei et veritati; quia si hoc verum esse
posset, etiam in infidelissimis Judaeis et paganis, qui,
 quantum ad naturam bonam et a Deo conditam
 pertinet, et ad imaginem et similitudinem Dei facti
sunt, recte diceretur habitare Deus Pater, habitare
Christus, habitare etiam Spiritus sanctus. Et similiter
de illis aeterna damnatione perditis quod etiam in
ipsis habitaturus sit Deus Pater, habitaturus Christus,
habitaturus Spiritus sanctus.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
What could be more impious and detestable than this? This absurd idea suggests that if angels, who are primarily rational beings, are believed to be made in the image and likeness of God; since they have received no less in their nature than humans; then even in the devil and his angels, who share the same nature with the holy angels, it would be wrongly said that God the Father, Heaven forbid, and His Christ, and the Holy Spirit dwell.

However, this blessed and kind dwelling is believed to be granted only to the chosen and faithful rational beings, as we've shown from the Scriptures. For the Lord promises to the pious and faithful, saying: "My Father and I will come to him, and we will make our home with him." John 14:23

He similarly promises them the presence of the Holy Spirit, saying: "And I will ask the Father, and he will give you another Advocate to be with you forever." John 14:16, 17

He also adds shortly after: "But you will know him, for he will dwell with you and will be in you." Of such people, God Himself says: "I will dwell among them and walk among them." Second Corinthians 6:16

And the Psalmist says: "They will rejoice forever, and He will dwell among them." Psalm 5:12

They also say elsewhere: "If it had not been the Lord who was on our side, let Israel now say, if it had not been the Lord who was on our side." Psalm 124:1

Thus, the blessed Apostle John, distinguishing between God dwelling in the pious and the devil dwelling in the impious, tells the faithful: "You are from God, little children, and have overcome them, because He who is in you is greater than he who is in the world." First John 4:4

If anyone wishes to correct this, let them learn faithfully from the Scriptures and not argue against the truth of God with human and vain arguments, but submit to His gentle mercy.
chunks.original_latin:
Quo sensu impio
et detestando quid horribilius dici aut cogitari potest? Istam namque absurditatem etiam illud sequitur,
ut si angeli, qui sunt utique principaliter rationalis
creatura, recte creduntur ad imaginem et similitudinem
Dei conditi; neque enim minus aliquid
hominibus in sua natura acceperunt; etiam in diabolo
et angelis ejus, qui unius naturae cum sanctis
angelis existunt, et Deus Pater, quod absit, et Christus
ejus, et Spiritus sanctus habitare dicendus sit:
 cum hoc donum beatae et benignae habitationis suae
soli electae et fideli rationali creaturae, sicut supra ex
Scripturis ostendimus, largiri credendus sit. Piis
namque et fidelibus Dominus promittit dicens: Ego
et Pater ad eum veniemus, et mansionem apud eum
faciemus (Joan. XIV, 23). Quibus et de Spiritus sancti
habitatione similiter repromittit dicens: Et ego
rogabo Patrem, et alium paraclitum dabit vobis qui
maneat vobiscum in aeternum (Joan. XIV, 16, 17). De
quo etiam paulo pos subjungit: Vos autem cognoscetis
eum, quia apud vos manebit et in vobis erit. De
talibus ipse Deus dicit: Et inhabitabo et inambulabo
in illis (II Cor. VI, 16). Et Psalmista ait: In aeternum
exsultabunt, et habitabit in eis (Psal. V, 12). Qui
etiam alibi dicunt: Nisi quia Dominus erat in nobis dicat
 nunc Israel, nisi quia Dominus erat in nobis (Psal. CXXIII, 1). Unde et beatus Joannes apostolus distinguens
inter habitatorem piorum Deum, et habitatorem
impiorum diabolum, dicit fidelibus: Vos ex Deo
estis, filioli, et vicistis eos, quoniam major est qui in

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
But since everything he says about those who remain in the state of original sin is repeated solely to assert that they are bound only by original sin and not predestined to punishment by any divine judgment, we must ask him and others who think this way whether it was by any divine judgment that such a large portion of humanity became subject to original sin, and thus deserving of eternal death, or not. If it wasn't by any divine judgment, but only by the natural course of a corrupted origin, then sin was naturally transferred to them from the first man, but not the condemnation of his sin. Sin alone came to them from Adam, not the just penalty of sin. However, the Apostle clearly states that through one man sin entered the world, and through sin, death, and so it spread to all men Romans 5:12. Therefore, truly, through one man, not only did sin enter the world, but also the penalty of sin, which is death. By whose judgment, if not by the one who had foretold to the man: On whatever day you eat of it, you will surely die? Genesis 2:17.

Eating from that forbidden tree was indeed sin, and the penalty for sin was what followed: you will surely die. God did not threaten him only with the first death of the body, but also with the death that occurs in the soul through sinning, as the soul that sins shall die Ezekiel 18:4; and also with the second death, which is eternal damnation, to which the guilt of that first sin inevitably drags all mankind, unless they are freed by the grace of Christ. Therefore, when God said these things, He did not merely intend to instill fear in the listener, but He revealed through that threat what He had determined by His just eternal judgment: namely, that by His just and eternal judgment, if man committed that sin, first the death of the soul would occur, second, he would also face the death of the body, and third, he would be condemned to the second death.
chunks.original_latin:
Sed quia totum hoc quod de illis qui in massa originalis
peccati relicti sunt, dicit, non ob aliud replicat,
nisi ut eos tantummodo peccati originalis vinculo obstrictos,
nullo Dei judicio asserat ad poenam praedestinatos,
quaerendum ab eo est et a caeteris qui ita
sentiunt, utrum aliquo Dei judicio factum sit ut tanta
 multitudo generis humani illi peccato originali fieret
obnoxia, ac per hoc etiam aeternae morti debita, an
non? Si enim nullo Dei judicio, sed tantummodo
naturali cursu vitiatae originis hoc factum est, ergo
sic peccatum tantummodo in eos naturaliter ex illo
primo homine transfusum est, ut nulla peccati ejus
damnatio in eos transfunderetur, et cucurrit in eos ex
Adam sola origo peccati, non etiam justa poena peccati,
sed manifeste Apostolus dicit quod per unum
hominem peccatum intravit in mundum, et per peccatum
mors, et ita in omnes homines pertransiit (Rom. V, 12). Vere ergo ex uno et per unum hominem non
solum peccatum, sed etiam poena peccati mors intravit
in mundum. Cujus judicio, nisi illius qui homini
 praedixerat: Quacunque die comederis ex eo,
morte morieris? (Gen. II, 12.) Quia comedere ex
illo ligno vetito, hoc fuit utique peccatum, poena vero
peccati hoc quod consequenter adjunctum est, morte
morieris. Quod utique non de sola ista prima morte
corporis ei comminatus est Deus, sed et de illa quae
peccando facta est in anima, quia anima quae peccaverit,
et ipsa morietur (Ezech. XVIII, 4); et de secunda
etiam morte, quae erit in damnatione aeterna, ad
quam reatus illius primi peccati omnino omnem hominem
trahit, nisi Christi gratia liberetur. Cum ergo haec Deus dixit, non solummodo terrorem
audienti incutere voluit, sed quod justum aeterno
judicio suo statuit, illa comminatione manifestavit,
ut videlicet justo et aeterno ejus judicio, si homo
 illud peccatum admitteret, primo animae mortem
incuteret, secundo etiam corporis morte dissolveretur,
tertio etiam secunda morte damnaretur.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
This entire condemnation, affecting both the soul and the body, would be passed down through time to all descendants along with the sin itself. Therefore, the judgment of God's eternal counsel and justice, which He decided to initiate with that first and only man, was passed on to all his descendants. Thus, in His just judgment, anyone not separated by the grace of Christ from that condemned group in Adam would be destined for eternal condemnation by that original divine judgment.

Therefore, God did not just leave the reprobates in the mass of original sin without making any decisions about them. He also determined that His eternal and just judgment, which began at the root, would continue through the offspring; what started with the parent would necessarily be fulfilled in the progeny. There is no doubt among the faithful that Almighty God, even before man sinned, foresaw that he would indeed sin. Just as He foresaw the sin, He also predestined what man would endure under His just judgment. What He rightly judged in that one man, He completed in all his descendants with the same foreknowledge, the same predestination of judgment, and the same justice of condemnation.

However, these unsupported words, suggesting that God left the reprobates in that mass of damnation without predestining anything regarding their damnation, seem to come from a booklet called "Hypognosticon" by the Greeks, which many falsely attribute to Saint Augustine. The style and sense of this booklet show that it is not by Saint Augustine. It not only contradicts the writings of Saint Augustine but also the faith itself. The new edition that we use contains testimonies that contradict the heretics and instruct the faithful, while the ancient edition, which Augustine used in his arguments about faith, does so continuously.

It further adds: "The wisdom of God has predestined in His laws the limits beyond which the wickedness of the impious cannot progress," etc., up to where it mentions "the most just torment of desire."

Et haec

est quod omnipotens Deus antequam peccaret

appellant, quem etiam ex falso titulo plerique

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Here, some truths are presented initially to lead to a false conclusion. It's undoubtedly true that God's wisdom has predetermined and set the boundaries and limits of the wickedness of the impious, whether they are angels or humans. Thus, their wickedness cannot extend as far as they desire if they are restrained by God's hidden laws within certain boundaries.

It's clear that both the devil and wicked people always have the intention to do evil or cause harm. However, they do not always have the power to do so, except to the extent and at times permitted by God. For instance, when the devil maliciously wished to harm blessed Job, a limit was set, and he could not harm him as much as he wanted, only as much as he was allowed.

Regarding wicked people attempting evil and perverse deeds but failing because God imposes a limit on them, Scripture clearly states: "They devised plans they could not establish" (Psalm 20:12). And again: "He thwarts the plans of the crafty, so that their hands achieve no success" (Job 5:12).

When this person adds that the devil's and all wicked people's malice desires nothing but to sin and act unjustly, thus departing from God, who is the highest essence, it is evidently true. Because, as mentioned, by sinning and acting unjustly, they distance themselves from God, becoming far from Him and perishing. As it is written about them: "Those who are far from you will perish" (Psalm 73:27).

Moreover, when this person further adds that both the devil's and wicked people's unrighteous desire is so inclined and eager for evil that if divine power allowed them, they would immerse themselves in sins to the point of potentially destroying their own nature, it may be exaggerated, but perhaps not entirely false.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Similarly, it adds that because of the difficulty and impossibility imposed by divine power and providence, which prevents them from committing as much evil as they desire, both evil spirits and the worst people experience a struggle and torment in their minds. They contemplate many ways to achieve what they cannot. This effort becomes a torment, punishment, and torture to their souls as they are twisted and punished by their own evil will.

What follows is that from this internal torment and punishment of the soul, when they cannot fulfill their desires because God opposes them, the soul becomes miserable, enduring the emptiness of their vain pleasures. It is true that this twisted desire of the soul, whether fulfilled or not, makes the soul wretched. But the soul is much more miserable when it is allowed to engage in such things than when it is prevented by divine power. For it is more unfortunate to be able to do evil than to merely wish and be unable.

Thus, the statement of a certain secular philosopher is true: "O miserable one to whom it was permitted to sin!" Indeed, the one who said this spoke truthfully, because if the person about whom this was said were prevented from sinning, they would be less miserable, merely having the desire to sin. But when they were permitted to sin, with that most unfortunate permission, they were much more miserable both in the desire for evil and in affection.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The reason we're discussing all these matters upfront is explained at the end. It says that the difficulty and impossibility faced by wicked angels or humans, who are stopped by God from getting what they greedily and perversely want, is only realized in the eternal damnation of punitive destruction and the just torment of unhappy desires. They endure this destruction and torment in their souls because they're no longer allowed to fulfill their twisted desires. There's no external punishment or torment inflicted on them from that eternal fire. This is clearly a lie, contrary to faith and truth, as has often been shown before.

After this, it's mentioned that the wicked serve God unwillingly. It's not the nature God created in them, which He doesn't punish, but the evil will, which He didn't create in them, and which He punishes. So, the fact that they serve Him unwillingly is punished by their own penalty, which those He doesn't justly liberate are somehow prepared for, while He allows them to prepare themselves for it. His intention is similar in these words.

He states that all the wicked, both angels and evil humans, will unwillingly serve the divine order in submission to the power and judgment of God in eternal damnation. According to his understanding, they're unwillingly subjected to God, not by the nature within them that God made and never punishes, but by the evil will, which He didn't create in them, and which He alone punishes. Because they serve the divine judgment unwillingly, they are punished not by any external torment but only internally within their own will. Their will becomes their own punishment when they desire to be wickedly free but are nevertheless restrained by divine power from that perverse freedom, unwillingly. He states that this alone is the punishment of wicked angels and humans. In wanting to have, but being unable to achieve, the worst kind of malicious freedom, they are tormented in and by that very will alone.

Quod vero iste aperiens et exponens cur omnia
 ista praemiserit, subjungit in fine et dicit, quod ea

Deo obsistente prohibentur pervenire ad ea quae

et angelorum et hominum impiorum, ut hoc
modo cupiendo habere nec valendo assequi pessimam

crucientur.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The nature in which they exist, whether in spirit or body, since it was made by God, never sins, is never punished, and never endures any torment. Regarding all these matters, it has already been adequately addressed above, as the Lord has allowed.

We propose one thing here for everyone to consider, or even to denounce: how this person claims, against human understanding and apostolic truth, that nature does not sin, but only the will of nature does. For who has ever been, or is there, who would say that when someone commits adultery, gluttony, or drunkenness, it is only the will that sins in them, and nothing of the soul or body sins?

On the contrary, according to the truth of the Catholic faith, all souls, along with their bodies, are to be brought to the judgment of Almighty God. As they have sinned in both and by both, they are judged and punished in both.

For if the nature of the body of the wicked is entirely free from sin, what need is there for it to rise again, which deserves no condemnation? Or how can it justly be condemned with its soul, when it had no partnership in sinning with it, and incurred no guilt of sin?

If this were so, it would be sufficient for only the soul to be present at judgment, and for the evil will, since it dwells in it, which he says alone sins, to be punished in it. Thus, this assertion of such impiety not only attacks the faith of truth but also the faith in the resurrection.

The Apostle says: "Therefore, do not let sin reign in your mortal body, so that you obey its desires. Do not offer any part of yourself to sin as an instrument of wickedness, but rather offer yourselves to God as those who have been brought from death to life, and offer every part of yourself to him as an instrument of righteousness." (Romans 6:12-13).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation: So, according to the words of the speaker in the Apostle of Christ, sin reigns in our mortal body and holds its power when we obey its desires, turning our members into instruments of wickedness that overpower and harm our soul. How is it, then, that the body does not sin, nor is sin attributed to it, even though both the reign and the forces of sin operate within it?

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
CHAPTER 19. This is the final chapter, and it says the following:

1. This eternal fire is the same as the fourth element of the world, where the bodies of the holy will transform into an ethereal quality, while the bodies of the wicked change into an aerial quality.

2. In this state, the remarkable joy among the natures will be perfected, while the unspeakable torment of evil wills will occur.

3. Thus, all the bodies of wicked angels and humans will endure the punishments of eternal fire, maintaining the integrity of their substance without perishing, their beauty without fading, and their natural wholeness intact. All the good aspects of nature will then shine in a wonderful order for the adornment of the universe, except for the blessedness from which they will be deprived.

4. With the higher corporeal fire clashing with the bodies of the lower air, and the natural force preserved, the intention of the unhappy souls will suffer eternal hardships from their bodies.

5. Thus, the same fire will become glory for all bodies, while for the souls to be damned, it will be filled with punishment from within by their own iniquity and from without. In these fantastical words, full of madness and delirium, the simplicity of faith and the apostolic confession is overlooked. The whole Church believes and confesses that our Lord Jesus Christ rose on the third day from the dead, ascended into heaven, sits at the right hand of the Father, and will come from there to judge the living and the dead. At His coming, the resurrection of the flesh will occur, and eternal life will be given to the saints. This simplest and purest confession of devotion is overlooked, I say, never mentioning the coming of Christ from heaven, never recalling the resurrection from the dead. Thus, everything is confused and obscured with certain inventions, making it difficult to recognize the truth of the resurrection, the truth of divine judgment and eternal punishment, nor any mention of the future life of the saints in these writings.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
He explains that in this eternal fire, which he sees as the fourth element of the world, naturally positioned above the earth, water, and air—in this fiery element of the world—the bodies of the saints will transform into an ethereal quality, while the bodies of the wicked will become airy. This perspective clearly conflicts with the apostolic doctrine, which asserts that the resurrection of all and the transformation of the saints will take place in this earthly realm, where both the righteous and the unrighteous lived and died.

This transformation will occur with astonishing and indescribable speed, as the Apostle himself notes, "in a moment, in the blink of an eye," which is the fastest motion possible. He states: "We will all rise, but we will not all be transformed. In a moment, in the blink of an eye, at the last trumpet: for the trumpet will sound, and the dead will rise incorruptible, and we will be changed" (First Corinthians 15:51-52). These words clearly describe the general resurrection of everyone.

However, he distinguishes this general resurrection with a specific feature, by saying that we will all rise, but not all will be transformed. And when he adds: "The dead will rise incorruptible, and we will be changed," he indicates that while everyone will rise by receiving their bodies, not everyone will be transformed with the glorification of the righteous.

The wicked will rise only incorruptible, not glorified; incorruptible only in that they can no longer be destroyed by death. But they will be entirely corruptible in terms of feeling and enduring eternal punishments and torments. They will be so consumed by these endless torments, as Scripture says, that fire and worms will enter their flesh, causing them to feel pain forever (Judith 16:21).

 enim resurgent tantummodo incorrupti, non etiam
glorificati: et incorrupti in eo tantummodo quod
jam non poterunt morte dissolvi; ad poenas autem et
ad cruciatus aeternos sentiendos atque perferendos
ita omnino corruptibiles erunt, et ita ipsis suppliciis
sine fine corrumpentur, ut omnino, sicut Scriptura
dicit, dentur in carnes eorum ignis et vermes, ut urantur
et sentiant usque in sempiternum (Judith XVI, 21).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
However, the righteous, for whom the Apostle says, "we will be changed," will rise incorruptible and will no longer face death. They will have the unique privilege of their bodies being transformed for the better, as the Apostle further explains, clearly describing this change: "For this perishable body must put on imperishability, and this mortal body must put on immortality" First Corinthians 15:53.

This means that the very body, which the saints now carry as perishable and mortal, will, by the power of the resurrection, become imperishable and immortal, essentially clothed in imperishability and immortality. This incorruptibility of the saints will be so profound that it cannot be touched by any pain, labor, trouble, or need.

Through this immortality given to them, death will be swallowed up in their bodies, so that not only will death itself be somehow erased, but even the cause of death, the sting of sin, which brought about death from the beginning, will be completely destroyed.

However, the sting of sin will never be removed from the bodies of the damned, and therefore they will never truly be free from death. Regarding this most blessed transformation of the righteous, the Apostle adds and says: "When this mortal body puts on immortality, then the saying that is written will come true: 'Death has been swallowed up in victory. Where, O death, is your victory? Where, O death, is your sting?'"
chunks.original_latin:
Justi autem, ex quorum persona Apostolus dicit, et
nos immutabimur, et incorrupti resurgent, ut nulla
ulterius morte solvantur; et hoc speciale habebunt
quod corpora eorum immutabuntur in melius, dicente
eodem Apostolo, et aperte qualis futura sit
ipsa commutatio exponente: Oportet enim, inquit,
corruptibile hoc induere incorruptionem, et mortale
 hoc induere immortalitatem (I Cor. XV, 53); scilicet
ut hoc ipsum corpus quod nunc a sanctis corruptibile
et mortale gestatur, illa resurrectionis virtute
fiat incorruptible et immortale, id est, incorruptione
et immortalitate induatur. Quae incorruptio
sanctorum tanta ac talis erit, ut nullo jam dolore,
nullo labore, nulla molestia, nulla indigentia tangi
possit. Et ita per illam immortalitatem quae eis dabitur,
absorbebitur mors in corporibus eorum, ut non
solum ipsa mors ibi quodammodo deleatur, sed etiam
causa mortis, id est peccati stimulus, cujus punctione
mors ab initio facta est, penitus conteratur. Qui utique
peccati stimulus in corporibus damnatorum
nunquam evacuabitur, et ideo nunquam vere a
 morte liberi erunt. De hac itaque felicissima immutatione
justorum subjungit Apostolus et dicit: Cum
autem mortale hoc induerit immortalitatem, tunc fiet
sermo qui scriptus est: Absorpta est mors in victoria;
ubi est, mors, victoria tua? ubi est, mors, stimulus
tuus? Stimulus autem mortis peccatum est: Deo autem
gratias, qui dedit nobis victoriam per Dominum
nostrum Jesum Christum (Ibid. V 54-57). Non ergo
prius resurgent corpora justorum, et postea, sicut
iste dicit, in elemento igneo, velut in conflatorio,
immutabuntur: sed in ipso momento et ictu oculi in
quo resurgent divina virtute immutata, incorruptionis
et immortalitatis gloria vestientur.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
When discussing the transformation of the wicked and the eternal punishments of the condemned, this person talks about their bodies changing into an airy quality—a new and unheard-of kind of error—about which the Apostle says nothing at all. So, we should dismiss these fantasies rather than listen to them, to avoid becoming itching ears, turning away from the truth and instead turning to myths.

How, according to him, will they change into an airy quality? If they become airy from earthly, it will not be a true resurrection, because the same bodies that fell through death will not rise; those were earthly, these will be airy. But if the nature of earthly bodies remains, and yet they take on the quality of air, transformed by the subtlety of the air and winds, the faith of the Church does not accept this novelty since, as mentioned before, the Apostle says nothing about the transformation of the wicked.

However, regarding what he says about the bodies of the saints being changed into a heavenly quality, if he believes this transformation will happen while the nature of their bodies remains, so that the same bodies that fell in death and were raised in resurrection will be glorified with heavenly brightness and be made bright from dark, it's enough for us to believe what the Lord says will happen to them: "Then the righteous will shine like the sun in the kingdom of their Father" (Matthew 13:43).

But if he claims the same bodies will change into a heavenly quality so that they lose their nature and become heavenly instead of earthly, he clearly contradicts the truth of the resurrection, and therefore should not be listened to at all. Whoever desires to feel simply, purely, and truly about the resurrection of the saints and the nature of spiritual bodies, let them listen and hold onto what the blessed Augustine sincerely teaches about these things, saying:

He adds and says: "And in this, the wonderful joy of the natures within themselves will be perfected, but the ineffable torment of the evil wills; that is, according to his understanding, only the wonderful joy of the natures that have not sinned at all will be perfected there."
chunks.original_latin:
De immutatione autem iniquorum et aeternis suppliciis
damnatorum, quorum iste corpora, novo et
 inaudito genere erroris, commutanda dicit in aeream
qualitatem, nihil omnino Apostolus loquitur: et ideo
etiam nos talem phantasiam contemnere potius quam
audire debemus, ne simus prurientes auribus, et a
veritate auditum avertentes, ad fabulas autem convertentes. Quomodo enim juxta ipsum transibunt in
aeream qualitatem? Nam si de terrenis aerea fient,
non erit vera resurrectio, quia non eadem corpora
resurgent quae per mortem ceciderunt; illa enim terrestria
erant, ista aerea erunt: si autem ipsa natura
terrenorum corporum permanebit, et tamen qualitatem
aeris accipiet, ut videlicet ipsius aeris et ventorum
subtilitate immutetur, hanc novitatem fides Ecclesiae
non recipit, quia, sicut jam dictum est, de immutatione
impiorum nihil Apostolus dicit. Quod autem
 dicit corpora sanctorum immutanda in aetheream
qualitatem, si istam immutationem manente ipsorum
corporum natura futuram credit, ut scilicet ipsa corpora
quae ceciderunt in morte, quae suscitata sunt in
resurrectione, glorificentur coelesti claritate, et de
obscuris lucida fiant sufficit nobis de hac eorum
mira clarificatione illud tenere quod Dominus in eis
futurum dicit: Tunc justi fulgebunt sicut sol in regno
Patris eorum (Matth. XIII, 43). Si autem ita dicit
eadem corpora in aetheream qualitatem immutanda,
ut amittant naturam suam et pro terrenis coelestia
fiant, manifeste veritati resurrectionis contradicit,
et ideo nullatenus audiendus est. Quicunque autem
desiderat simpliciter et pure ac vere de sanctorum
resurrectione et spiritualium corporum natura sentire,
 audiat et teneat fideliter quod beatus Augustinus
de his sincerissime docet, dicens: 
Subjungit iste et dicit: In eoque naturarum intra
se mirabile perfici gaudium, malarum vero voluntatum
ineffabile tormentum; id est, ut juxta ejus sensum
loquamur, naturarum ibi tantummodo mirabile perficiatur
gaudium, quae secundum istum minime peccaverunt.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
To make this the joy of creation, the nature of the earthly body, as some believe, will transform into an airy quality for the wicked, and for the holy into an even higher glory, that is, into an ethereal quality. However, for those with evil intentions, who are said to be the only ones who have sinned, there will be an indescribable torment, as they will be tortured by their own guilty conscience. It has already been shown how empty and false this idea is.

He goes on to say that the bodies of all the wicked, both angels and humans, will suffer the punishment of eternal fire, enduring without the destruction of their substance, without losing their beauty, and maintaining their natural safety. All the good aspects of nature will shine in a wondrous order for the ornament of the universe, except for the blessedness from which they will be deprived. It is truly remarkable how he claims that the bodies of all the wicked, angels, and humans will suffer the punishment of eternal fire, despite having previously denied this so openly and repeatedly. Certainly, in this instance, he either confessed it falsely and deceitfully, and he is detestable to God who holds a lie about his faith in his heart and tries to present truth with his mouth, as it is written: Psalm Five, Six through Seven: "You will destroy all who speak falsehood: the Lord abhors the bloodthirsty and deceitful man." Or if, indeed, he confessed this truthfully out of fear of offending the Church, so as not to be judged completely unfaithful, such a confession is entirely empty and void, given his previous repeated denials. However, we are not allowed to say one thing now and another later concerning matters of faith in God. What the Church once received from the very mouth of the Lord and his apostles must be believed and confessed; it should be held with unchangeable and inviolable truth, so that what the Lord commanded may truly be fulfilled in us, saying: Matthew Five, Thirty-Seven: "But let your word be 'Yes, yes'; 'No, no'" Namely, that our truth may be confirmed by an immutable truth and our falsehood rejected by our confession.
chunks.original_latin:
Ut hoc sit gaudium naturarum, quod natura
terreni corporis, sicut iste putat, in impiis
transitura est in aeream qualitatem, in sanctis vero
 adhuc in excelsiorem gloriam, id est in aetheream
qualitatem; malarum vero voluntatum, quas solas
dicit peccasse, tunc futurum ineffabile tormentum,
cum ex ipsa sua mala conscientia torquebuntur. Sed
hoc totum quam vanum et falsum sit, jam satis est
demonstratum. 3. Addit post ista et dicit: Et ita impiorum omnium,
angelorum hominumque, corpora supplicia ignis
aeterni perpessura, ut integritate illorum substantiae
nullo modo peritura, eorum pulchritudine nullo modo
defutura, eorum naturali incolumitate permansura,
omnibus deinde naturae bonis ad universitatis ornamentum
mirabili ordine fulsuris: excepta beatitudine
qua privabuntur. Mirandum est nimis in his verbis
quomodo dicat: Omnium impiorum et angelorum, et
 hominum corpora aeterni ignis supplicium perpessura,
quod superius tam aperte et multipliciter ubique
negavit. Quod utique in hoc loco aut ficte et dolose
confessus est et abominabilis est Deo qui de fide ejus
in corde tenet mendacium, et in ore vult praeferre
veritatem, sicut scriptum est: Perdes omnes qui loquuntur
mendacium: virum sanguinum, et dolosum
abominatur Dominus (Psal. V, 7, 8). Aut si vere ipsa
rei veritate et timore offensionis Ecclesiae superatus,
ne omnino infidelis judicaretur, hoc confessus est,
vacua est omnino et cassa talis confessio, quam superius
tanta et tam multiplex praecessit negatio. Nobis autem non licet in rebus ad fidem Dei pertinentibus
aliud modo, aliud postea dicere: sed quod
semel ex ipso ore Domini et apostolorum ejus accepit
 Ecclesia, credendum et confitendum; ita inviolabili
et immutabili veritate retinere, ut fiat in nobis verissime
quod Dominus praecepit, dicens: Sit autem
sermo vester, est, est: non, non (Matth. V, 37); videlicet
ut immobili veritate et veritas nostra confessione
confirmetur, et falsitas nostra confessione
respuatur.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Yet, he clearly reveals how strongly he believes in the punishments of eternal fire. After stating that the bodies of wicked angels and humans will endure these torments, he immediately adds: This is so that the integrity of their substance, meaning the wicked angels and humans, will not perish in any way, ensuring that beauty is not lacking and their natural wholeness remains.

Notice the good things he attributes to them in the eternal fire's punishments, specifically the integrity of nature, beauty, and wholeness. They possess the integrity of their nature because their entire being, both soul and body, will remain forever. But as for how or where they might have beauty, let any faithful person consider, for beauty pertains either to the soul or the body. Yet, who among the faithful would believe there could be any beauty of souls in a place where all virtues are lost and all vices are present? For the soul is either beautified by virtue or deformed by vice. And what beauty of bodies could exist there, when overshadowed by the eternal horror of sadness, the eternal burning of fire, and the eternal torment by worms?

What natural wholeness could exist in those damned angels and humans when their nature is preserved whole only to ensure they're tormented without end? Yet, he is not content with such nonsense and absurdity of his depraved mind and adds the most blatant error of heretical impiety. What he harbored in his heart to attack truth and mislead listeners, he also expresses openly.
chunks.original_latin:
Et tamen iste quam fideliter de aeterni ignis suppliciis
credat, in sequentibus manifeste aperit: postquam
enim dixit, ita impiorum angelorum hominumque
corpora supplicia ignis aeterni perpessura ut
intelligere  modum quo id credit esse
futurum, subjunxit statim: Quod hoc ita fiet, ut integritas
substantiae eorum, id est angelorum et hominum
 malignorum nullo modo sit peritura, ut pulchritudo
eis nullo modo sit defutura, ut naturalis incolumitas
sit in ipsis permansura. Ecce quae bona eis tribuit in
suppliciis ignis aeterni, videlicet integritatem naturae,
pulchritudinem, incolumitatem: ut integritatem
naturae suae habeant, quia tota eorum natura in
anima et corpore perpetuo permanebit: pulchritudinem
vero ubi aut quomodo habere possint, fidelis
quisque consideret, pulchritudo namque aut animae
est aut corporis. Quis autem fidelium credat ullam
ibi esse posse pulchritudinem animarum, ubi erit
amissio omnium virtutum et foeditas omnium vitiorum? anima enim aut virtute pulchra est, aut vitio
deformis. Quae autem ibi esse poterit pulchritudo
corporum, ubi aeterno horrore tristitiae, et aeterna
 ignis exustione, aeterna vermium laceratione offuscabitur et tenebrabitur? Quae etiam in damnatis illis
angelis et hominibus, sicut iste dicit, poterit esse
naturalis incolumitas, cum natura ad hoc eis integra
tantummodo servetur, et nunquam a sua naturali
compage solvatur, ut plenius tota sine fine crucietur. Sed iste non contentus tanta ineptia et absurditate
depravati sensus sui, addit in fine apertissimum haereticae
impietatis errorem, ut quod corde gestabat ad
impugnationem veritatis et subversionem audientium,
etiam ore evomeret.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
He immediately adds that, in the same nature of demons and condemned humans, after the torments of eternal fire, they will shine with all the good qualities of nature in a wonderful order. This means their souls will be endowed and illuminated with the natural goods of memory, intelligence, and free will. Their bodies will be radiant and outstanding, with the vibrant senses of the five natural senses and perfect beauty in form.

He claims they are freed from punishments and adorned with all natural goods so that, shining with such beauty, they may contribute to the universe's beauty. This is so that among the other creatures of the world, earthly or heavenly, they too remain part of the world’s adornment, having once been in the damnation of punishment.

And after this, to not appear completely against the faith of the Church and the truth of the Gospel and the apostles, he added, except for the blessedness from which they will be deprived. This means that demons and humans freed from punishments will shine with all natural goods, except for the blessedness of the vision of God, which alone will be denied to them, so it may seem that nothing good is lacking for them.

See what he dares to think, what he dares to say, and what he even dares to write—a man who wants to appear Christian but strives for nothing else but to oppose Christian truth and introduce the doctrines of heretics, with whom he is unfortunately aligned, into the purity of the Church.

For the Church of Christ denies and detests both, as both are heretical and completely contrary to the truth. That is, both the liberation of demons and humans from those eternal punishments and the existence of some intermediate place where these demons and humans might be in rest and abundance and brightness of all goods, so they are neither in the damnation of eternal fire with the devil nor in blessedness with God. And it firmly holds that after that universal judgment, no one can be except either in eternal blessedness or, conversely, in everlasting misery.
chunks.original_latin:
Addit namque statim de eisdem daemonum et hominum
damnatorum naturis, quod deinde (id est post
illa aeterni ignis supplicia) omnibus naturae bonis mirabili
ordine refulgebunt: id est ut et in anima sint
 praediti et illustrati naturalibus bonis memoriae, intelligentiae
et liberae voluntatis; et in corpore clareant,
atque praepolleant, et quinque naturalium sensuum
vivacitate et formae perfectae pulchritudine. Dicitque eos propterea exemptos suppliciis, et exornatos
omnes omnibus naturalibus bonis, ut tanta
pulchritudine refulgentes proficiant ad universitatis
ornatum: videlicet ut inter caeteras mundi creaturas
terrestres sive coelestes, etiam ipsi permanentes sint
in ornamento mundi qui fuerant in damnatione supplicii. Et posthaec ne ex toto videretur venire contra
Ecclesiae fidem et evangelicam atque apostolicam veritatem,
subjunxit dicens, excepta beatitudine, qua
privabuntur, id est quod sic fulgebunt omnibus naturalibus
bonis daemones et homines suppliciis exuti,
 ut excepta beatitudine visionis Dei, quae eis sola denegabitur,
nihil boni eis deesse videatur. Ecce quid
audet sentire, quid audet dicere, quid audet etiam
scribere homo qui vult videri Christianus, et nihil
aliud laborat nisi ut Christianae veritati adversetur,
et haereticorum dogmata, quibus ipse infeliciter conjunctus
est, et sinceritati Ecclesiae intromittat. Nam
Ecclesia Christi utrumque negat, utrumque detestatur,
quia utrumque est haereticum et omnimodis
contrarium veritati, id est et liberationem daemonum
atque hominum ex illis suppliciis sempiternis, et
aliquem medium locum esse ubi ita sint ipsi daemones
et homines in requie et bonorum omnium copia
et claritate, ut nec in damnatione ignis aeterni sint
 cum diabolo, neque in beatitudine cum Deo. Et omnino
certissime tenet neminem esse posse post illud
universale judicium, nisi aut in beatitudine aeterna,
aut e contrario in miseria sempiterna.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Once someone has been sent to either judgment or punishment, or welcomed into the joy of eternal life, they will never be anywhere else or in any other condition. The Lord made this clear for both groups: the condemned on the left and the blessed on the right, with an unchangeable verdict when He says: "Then these will go away into eternal punishment, but the righteous into eternal life" (Matthew 25:46).

If there were ever to be an end to eternal punishment, then—God forbid—there would also be an end to eternal life. But since eternal life has no end, there's no doubt that eternal punishment will never end either.

Therefore, contrary to what some might think, there won't be anyone in a middle state, neither blessed nor miserable, who finds rest outside the Father's house. The Lord clearly states: "In my Father's house are many rooms" (John 14:2), indicating that outside His Father's house, which is the fellowship of the holy angels and chosen people where He dwells forever, there is no place or resting space.

All the multitude and variety of rooms are only in the Father's house, where, like one star differing from another in brightness in the sky, there will be diversity of rooms based on the diversity of merits. Following this, he adds: With the quality of the upper fiery bodies interacting with the lower air bodies, maintaining natural strength, the unfortunate souls will suffer eternal distress from their bodies.
chunks.original_latin:
Qui enim semel
fuerint in illo judicio vel in poenam missi, vel
in vitae aeternae gaudium intromissi, nunquam ulterius
alibi vel aliter esse poterunt. Sicut Dominus
certissime ostendit de utraque parte, id est et damnatorum,
qui erunt a sinistris, et beatorum, qui
erunt a dextris, irrevocabilem sententiam proferens,
cum dicit: Tunc ibunt hi in supplicium aeternum,
justi autem in vitam aeternam (Matth. XXV, 46). Si
enim erit finis aliquando illi poenae aeternae, erit etiam
aliquando (quod absit) finis vitae aeternae. Si autem
vita aeterna nullum omnino habebit finem, procul
 dubio et poena illa, id est supplicium aeternum, nullum
unquam habere finem poterit. Non ergo erunt
aliqui, ut iste delirat, ita in medio positi ut nec beati
sint nec miseri, et tamen extra domum Patris aliquam
requiem habituri. Dominus enim manifeste dicit: In
domo Patris mei multae sunt mansiones (Joan. XIV, 2),
ostendens extra domum Patris sui, id est extra sociotatem
sanctorum angelorum et hominum electorum,
quam ipse in aeternum inhabitat, nullum esse
locum, nullam mansionum quietis. Quia omnis illa
multitudo et multiplicitas mansionum non est, nisi
in domo paterna, ubi sicut in uno coelo stella ab
stella differt in claritate, sic in una eademque
domo erit diversitas mansionum pro diversitate meritorum. Post haec addit iste, et dicit: Superioris ignis corporei
cum inferioris aeris corporibus qualitate colluctante,
naturali vi servata, infelicium animarum intentio
de corporibus suis aeternas patiatur aerumnas.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Consider how he believes, if he truly does, in the punishments of eternal fire. This fire, being the higher element, is said to act on the bodies of demons, which he considers to be airy, as well as on the bodies of wicked humans, which he previously mentioned would transform into an airy nature.

Now, he openly claims these bodies are airy, just like the demons. The nature of both elements, that is, the fire he believes to be eternal and the air he thinks resides in the bodies of demons and lost humans, clash and conflict in that prison of damnation, causing the unfortunate souls of both humans and demons to endure the eternal pains of the air from their airy bodies.

Even in that furnace of eternal fire, these two elements, fire and air, will maintain their natural force. Just as in this world, where the heat of the upper fire through the sun's warmth vaporizes and heats the lower air, severely affecting our bodies with vapor and heat; so in that so-called furnace of everlasting punishment, the fire naturally ignites the airy bodies of demons and humans, causing the souls within to experience the eternal pains of affliction from the heat and burning of their own bodies.

Let him who feels and writes this now explain how the unfortunate souls of both angelic and human creatures will ever be rescued from these punishments and, as he says, will shine with all the good things of nature if they suffer eternal pain due to the violent burning of their airy bodies by that fire.

If they are to be freed from these punishments, they will certainly be free from pain; but if they remain in everlasting pain, they will never deserve liberation. Yet, while explaining further how he believes this fabricated and laboriously constructed punishment will occur, he adds:

So that the same fire becomes glory for all bodies, by which the souls to be damned will be filled with punishment from their own wickedness both within and from outside.
chunks.original_latin:
Ecce quomodo credit, si tamen credit, supplicia ignis
aeterni exercenda: videlicet quod ignis ille, qui est
hujusmodi superius elementum, corpora daemonum,
quae putat esse aerea, et corpora hominum impiorum,
quae superius dixit transitura in aeream qualitatem,
nunc autem aperte dicit aerea sicut et ipsorum
daemonum, dum utriusque elementi natura, id
est et ignis, quem putat esse ignem aeternum in suppliciis
damnatorum, et aeris, quem credit esse in
corporibus daemonum et hominum perditorum, in
illo damnationis ergastulo inter se colluctantur atque
 compugnant, efficiat infelicibus animabus et hominum,
et daemonum de corporibus suis aeris aeternas
poenarum aerumans: quia scilicet etiam in illo camino
ignis aeterni naturalem vim servabunt haec duo
elementa ignis et aeris, ut sicut in hoc mundo ardore
ignis superioris per calorem solis iste aer, qui est
inferior, ita vaporatur et fervet, ut suo vapore atque
fervore corpora nostra graviter afficiat; ita in illo,
ut dictum est, camino ignis supplicii sempiterni,
dum ignis naturali vi inflammat corpora aerea daemonum
atque hominum, ex ipso fervore atque ardore
corporum suorum, animae quae in eis sunt, sentiant
et patiantur aeternas afflictionis aerumnas. Dicat
nunc ipse, qui hoc sentit et scribit, quomodo infelices
 animae utriusque creaturae angelicae et humanae
aliquando illis suppliciis erunt ereptae, et omnibus
naturae bonis, sicut ipse dicit, refulsurae, si per vim
illius ignis corporibus suis aereis atrociter inflammatis
aeternas patientur aerumnas? Si enim liberabuntur
illis suppliciis, carebunt utique aerumnis; si
autem in sempiternis erunt aerumnis, nunquam liberationem
merebuntur. Sed exponens iste adhuc modum qualiter illud
tam fictum et tanto labore concinnatum futurum putet
esse supplicium, adjungit et dicit: Ita videlicet ut
idem ipse ignis omnibus corporibus fiat gloria, quo
damnandis animabus intrinsecus iniquitate propria,
extrinsecus cumulabitur poena.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
In these words, it seems to assert that the same eternal fire torments the souls damned by their own wicked conscience internally, and also adds to their punishment externally by burning and heating their bodies. Thus, they suffer not only from their conscience internally but also from fiery punishment externally. Yet, this same fire gives a kind of glory to their bodies made of air.

We believe that just as the fire in the stars illuminates the dark and gloomy nature of this air, making it bright with its glow—naturally dark unless lit by the sun's rays by day or by the moon and stars by night—this fire is thought to illuminate and glorify the airy bodies of demons and humans with the light of that eternal fire, much like the blackness of iron is transformed into brightness by the heat of a furnace.

How then did he say earlier that the airy bodies of angels and humans will suffer the punishments of eternal fire? For if this eternal fire is a punishment to them, it certainly will not be glory; if, however, it is glory to them, it will not be punishment.

Therefore, by rejecting and pushing far away such twisted and deceitful arguments and extremely laborious and harmful paths, let us hold onto the simplicity of faith: believing in the true bodies of damned humans, that is, earthly bodies, and the true and eternal punishments in them, which they will undergo in that damnation.

For the word of Truth is very true, as it says in the Gospel: The hour is coming when all who are in the graves will hear the voice of the Son of God: and those who have done good will come out to the resurrection of life; but those who have done evil, to the resurrection of judgment John 5:28-29.

For at that voice of the Son of God, all who are in the graves will come out, because they will receive the same bodies that were placed in the graves, and they will rise in the same bodies, in which they will have either the resurrection of life or the resurrection of judgment; so that they may either possess eternal life in them or suffer eternal death in them.
chunks.original_latin:
In quibus verbis hoc
videtur asserere quod idem ipse ignis aeternus et
 animabus intrinsecus ex conscientia sua propria iniquitate
damnatis, et exterius earum corpora inflammando
et fervefaciendo accumulet poenam, ut scilicet
non solum interius torqueantur conscientia, sed
etiam exterius affligantur poena ignita: et tamen eorum
corporibus aeris idem ignis quamdam gloriam
conferat. Putamus quia sicut iste ignis qui lucet in
sideribus, obscuram et caliginosam hujus aeris naturam
sua infusione illuminat, suo fulgore lucidam
reddit, qui est utique naturaliter tenebrosus, nisi
aut in die radiis solis aut in nocte radiis lunae et
siderum illustretur: ita iste existimat illa aerea daemonum
et hominum corpora aeterni illius ignis fulgore
illustranda et clarificanda, sicut etiam nigredo
ferri calore fornacis in lucidam vertitur qualitatem. Quomodo ergo superius dixit: Angelorum hominumque
corpora aerea supplicia ignis aeterni perpessura? Si enim supplicium eis erit ille ignis aeternus, non
erit utique gloria; si autem gloria eis fuerit, non
erit poena. Abigentes itaque et procul repellentes hujusmodi
tortuosas et vipereas ambages, et anfractus laboriosissimos
ac perniciosos, teneamus fidei simplicitatem:
vera damnatorum hominum corpora, id est
terrena, credentes, et in eis vera et aeterna supplicia,
qui in illa fuerint damnatione passuros: quia verissimus
est sermo Veritatis quae in Evangelio dicit: Quia
veniet hora quando omnes qui in monumentis sunt
audient vocem Filii Dei: et procedent qui bona fecerunt
in resurrectionem vitae; qui vero mala egerunt,
 in resurrectionem judicii (Joan. V, 28, 29). Ad illam
namque vocem Filii Dei omnes qui in monumentis
sunt procedent: quia eadem corpora quae in monumentis
erant posita recipient, et in eisdem resurgent,
in eisdem habituri vel resurrectionem vitae,
vel resurrectionem judicii; ut aut in ipsis possideant
vitam aeternam, aut in ipsis mortem patiantur aeternam.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
It's essential for us, and absolutely necessary for our salvation, to be grounded in the truth and simplicity of faith. With the Lord's help, we must avoid the evil that the Apostle warns the Church, which is betrothed to Christ and blessed with the purity of chaste faith, to fear. "For I have betrothed you to one husband, to present you as a pure virgin to Christ. But I fear that, as the serpent deceived Eve by his craftiness, your minds may be corrupted from the simplicity that is in Christ." Second Corinthians 11:3

He also warns elsewhere, saying: "Avoid irreverent and silly myths." First Timothy 4:7 And again: "Avoid profane and idle chatter, for it will lead people into more and more ungodliness, and their message will spread like cancer." Second Timothy 2:16-17

The blessed Apostle Peter, with the same piety and concern, also advises the faithful, saying: "Therefore, dear friends, since you have been forewarned, be on your guard so that you may not be carried away by the error of the lawless and fall from your secure position. But grow in the grace and knowledge of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ." Second Peter 3:17-18

We should not think of these matters as jokes or games, because the Apostle also refers to Ishmael's playing with Isaac as persecution. So, wherever we recognize such things, we must be driven by zeal for faith against them. We are informed and aided by Him who says in the psalm: "Zeal for your house consumes me." Psalm 69:9 He also made a whip of cords and drove out the violators of God's house with their goods, because they had turned that paternal house into a den of robbers. John 2:15

Truly, they turn the house of the Lord, which is the Church of the living God, the pillar and foundation of truth, into a den of robbers. First Timothy 3:15

They are indeed robbers themselves, who, under the guise of the Christian name, as if established in the Church, attempt to hide their infidelity and lay traps for the lives of the faithful through deceitful and malicious discussions.
chunks.original_latin:
Bonum est nobis, et omnino saluti nostrae ante
omnia necessarium, ut in fidei veritate et simplicitate
fundati, timeamus et, Domino auxiliante, caveamus
illud malum quod Apostolus Ecclesiae Christo
desponsatae et casta fidei virginitate praeditae timere
se denuntiat, dicens: Despondi enim vos uni viro virginem
castam exhibere Christo. Timeo autem ne sicut
 serpens Evam seduxit astutia sua, ita corrumpantur sensus
vestri, et excidant a simplicitate, quae est in Christo
(II Cor. XI, 23). Unde et alibi admonet dicens: Ineptas
autem et aniles fabulas devita (I Tim. IV, 7). Et iterum:
Profana autem et inaniloquia devita: multum
enim proficiunt ad impietatem, et sermo eorum ut cancer
serpit (II Tim. II, 17). Unde et beatus Petrus
apostolus eadem pietate, eadem sollicitudine fideles
admonet, dicens: Vos igitur, fratres praescientes
custodite vosmetipsos, ne insipientium errore traducti,
excidatis a propria firmitate. Crescite vero in
gratia et cognitione Domini nostri Jesu Christi et Salvatoris
(II Pet. III, 17, 18). Non nobis efficiantur ista velut jocosa et ludo similia,
quia et ludum Ismaelis cum Isaac persecutionem
 vocat Apostolus. Et ideo ubicunque talia agnoscimus,
zelo fidei contra haec excitari debemus: illo
nos informante et adjuvante qui in psalmo dicit:
Zelus domus tuae comedit me (Psal. LXVIII, 10); qui
etiam flagello de funiculis facto, violatores domus
Dei cum suis mercibus ejecit, eo quod eamdem domum
paternam fecerint speluncam latronum (Joan. II, 15). Vere enim domum Domini, quae est Ecclesia
Dei vivi, columna et firmamentum veritatis (I Tim. III, 15) in speluncam latronum vertunt, et vere latrones
sunt, qui sub praetextu Christiani nominis velut
in Ecclesia constituti, infidelitatem suam occultare
conantur, et insidiosis etiam ac malitiosis disputationibus
vitae fidelium insidiantur.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Since this individual, whose words we've addressed with the Lord's help, takes pride in philosophical principles and logical arguments, let's listen attentively to the most blessed bishop and confessor of Christ, Hilary, who admonishes and speaks to such people.

This glorious confessor also explained the Apostle's words: "See to it that no one takes you captive through philosophy and empty deceit, according to human tradition, according to the elemental spirits of the world, and not according to Christ." Blessed Hilary commented on this.

Now, let's consider the punishment and condemnation awaiting not only the authors but also the supporters of falsehood. With a pious intention, we should distance ourselves from such individuals so that every faithful person, pure and cleansed in faith, may be worthy of a place in the tree of life. Let's listen to the Lord Himself, who both warns and promises in Revelation: "The one who conquers will inherit these things, and I will be his God, and he will be my son. But as for the cowardly and the faithless, the abominable, and all liars, their portion will be in the lake that burns with fire and sulfur, which is the second death" (Revelation 21:7, 8).

And again: "Its gates will never be shut by day—and there will be no night there. They will bring into it the glory and honor of the nations. But nothing unclean will enter it, nor anyone who does what is detestable or false, but only those who are written in the Lamb's book of life" (Revelation 21:25-27).

And again: "Blessed are those who wash their robes so that they may have the right to the tree of life and may enter the city by the gates. Outside are the dogs, the sorcerers, the sexually immoral, the murderers, the idolaters, and everyone who loves and practices falsehood. I, Jesus, have sent my angel to testify to you about these things for the churches" (Revelation 22:14-16).

verbis, auxiliante Domino, utcunque respondimus,

gloriatur, audiamus in fine fideliter et obedienter
beatissimum Christi antistitem et confessorem
Hilarium, ita istiusmodi homines redarguentem
atque dicentem: . Item idem gloriosus confessor cum verba
Apostoli exponeret dicentis: Videte ne quis vos spoliet
per philosophiam et inanem fallaciam, secundum

sed etiam fautores mendacii maneat, et quanta
pietatis intentione a talibus recedendum sit, ut unusquisque

Qui vicerit possidebit haec, et ero illi Deus,
et ille erit mihi filius. Timidis autem et incredulis, et
 exsecratis et omnibus mendacibus, pars illorum erit
in stagno ardenti igne et sulphure, quod est mors secunda

in sanguine Agni et mendacium (Ibid., vers. 25-27). Et iterum: Beati qui lavant stolas suas ut sit
potestas eorum in ligno vitae, et per portas intrent in
